description:
Lifograph is a sponsor of HustleCon and they negotiated a 50% discount for our meetup. Yay!! 

Use discount code - lifograph at checkout. Go to  http://www.hustlecon.com/ to register and get your ticket.

HustleCon is a one-day conference for non-technical founders (or technical founders who want to learn how to hustle). Last year's event sold out. It might happen again this year.

Breakfast, lunch and cocktail break are provided.

What will you learn at Hustle Con?

- How to build a minimum viable product without knowing how to code 
- Going from 0 to $25M+ in online sales 
- How to build an audience without a product 
- How to presell a product (before you build it) 
- How to create a brand that people LOVE! 
- How to write copy that sells 
-How to grow your site from 0 to 2,000,000 monthly users 


Inspirational stories and workshops from founders of Buffer, BranchOut, Appsumo, Eloqua, CrazyEgg, Polyvore, etc. 

http://www.hustlecon.com/

BIG THANK YOU TO OUR SPONSOR WHO NEGOTIATED THIS DISCOUNT

Lifograph - "Who's Who" and "Who knows Who" in Silicon Valley

description:
This will be our guided ride (fee based) as part of the Park City week ride series. If you plan to join us for this one, RSVP now so we will have a bike count to base the fee per person on. Guide cost is $250 for 2 ppl. $75/adtl person. Total amount divided by number of riders = your cost.

RIDE SUMMARY:

The Mid-Mountain Trail is a classic ride that everyone from strong intermediates to experts will enjoy. It will just take the intermediates the better part of a day. The climb up Spiro or Armstrong is a dichotomy of long and pleasant (with Spiro being the steeper of the two,) and the cross-mountain trip, while lengthy, is just pure fun. (An alternate route involves a shuttle to a starting point at Deer Valley which skips the big climb but the total length stays almost exactly the same.)

Part of the pleasantry comes from the scenery, and one of the highlights is that virtually the whole ride is through thick aspen groves. In the summer, the shade is welcome, and in the fall you feel like you’re riding through a fast changing kaleidoscope.<a href="http://www.jans.com/mountain-bike-tour-mid-mountain-epic#"></a>

DESCRIPTION:

The ride starts with an unrelenting 3.3 mile climb that takes you from 6900’ up to 8136’.  This is a long ride with a big climb at the start and you need to be in pretty good shape.  It’s not recommended for your first day at altitude.  There are countless switchbacks along the way, which a solid intermediate can handle. 

We will use this starting point: (Using the alternate starting point in Deer Valley means a climb of only about 300’ and an extra 6 miles of Epic cross-mountain riding.)

After the climb there’s a pretty substantial section of rock garden which requires some intrepid riding or some patience walking, but the rest of the ride is not particularly technical, and the pay-off is more than worth it.  After working up a sweat, you are rewarded with more than 15 miles of great cross mountain single track with rolling elevations ranging from 7800’ to 8300’ and views of Park City, White Pine Canyon, and Snyderville Basin. Once across the Canyons Resort, the downhill is long, fast, and fun. The ride finishes with either a road and paved bike path ride back to the shop or the White Pine shuttle can come pick you up.</a><a href="http://www.jans.com/mountain-bike-tour-mid-mountain-epic#">

 

Release of Liability:

By joining this group for any event, you hereby RELEASE and DISCHARGE it's owners, principals, affiliates, presenters, organizer, assistant organizer, hosts and participants from any and all liability, claims, demands or causes of action that you now have, or may have in the future, for injuries, damages, death and/or economic loss of any kind or nature, arising in whole or in part out of the activities, advice or information contained herein. You further agree that if you or someone under your supervision uses the information on this website you assume all risks of injury, damage, and economic loss, without limitation, and release providers from all liability therefore.
name: Mid-Mountain (an IMBA Epic Ride)

description: Starting at the McAbee entrance we'll hike up mine hill and come down Senador trail. This is about 3 1/2 to 4 miles and takes around 1 1/2 hours. There are some hills (probably 600 feet elevation gain).
name: Hike at Almaden Quicksilver Park (McAbee entrance)

description:
This hike has some hills, but LOTS of shade, so perfect for an August Friday hike.

Give or take 6 miles, about 2 1/2 to 3 hours hiking time, not including drive time.

We will carpool from the Springtown Golf Course Parking lot at 830am which should put us at the park by 9-915am with hopefully "friday light" traffic. 

AT THE PARK MEET AT THE CANYON MEADOWS STAGING AREA, this is at the very end of the road after you enter the park.

There can be a charge to get in the park if there is a Ranger, I have an EB parks permit so I am happy to drive. If we need more than one car, please chip in to your drive for the fee (I think around $5 total).

There are flush toilets and water at the beginning of the hike, but bring plenty of water and maybe a snack if you like for the hike.

We start along the lovely stream, under the Redwoods you just can't beat it.

description:
Join us for free at one of our highly-innovative business-networking meetings - in your city! View our full calendar of business-networking meetings. We welcome anyone to attend a GoRampUp! meeting, once, for free as our guest, so you can learn what the innovative GoRampUp! business-networking experience is all about. Note, we are not able to give you a free meeting at more than one of our many locations.

YOU MUST obtain a free-access GoRampUp! Golden ticket by registering for a specific meeting athttp://GoRampUp.com/calendar/. This ticket must be presented at your complimentary meeting for you to gain admittance. Without this ticket you will, unfortunately, be declined access to our innovative and exclusive business-networking meeting. WITH a GoRampUp! Golden Ticket, you will be welcomed with open arms!

It can be too difficult to attract new clients. We help you fix that! We're a business-impact community. We're informal and fun, yet, by design, we're extremely effective!

We help people who work for a living to get a much greater payoff from working. We do this in three specific ways under our three CoreSuccess Platforms: 1) We help you move toward mastery with business-networking, 2) We help you move toward mastery with business performance, and, 3) We help you move toward mastery with personal development.

How do we deliver on this promise to our community members? Each month we conduct dozens of business-networking meetings in more than a dozen cities in the SF Bay Area. A member may attend all of our "OpenConnect" business-networking meetings. And our members are welcome and encouraged to attend any and all of these meetings and locations.

Each month we introduce and emphasize a learning and development subject under each of our three CoreSuccess Platforms. For each of the three learning and development subjects that we introduce and emphasize each month, we give you four different ways to learn it: We produce written learning guides, video learning guides, audio learning guide, and we cover the subjects as 15-to-20-minute mini-workshops inside of our 60-minute business-networking meetings. There's no registration or initiation fee to join. Membership in GoRampUp! is month to month. You enroll when you like, even mid-month, and you depart when you like.

Be sure to see our website to learn about our generous enrollment incentives

Also, be sure to learn about our 100-Satisfaction Money-Back Guarantee

Would you care to come to this meeting, at no cost, to see if there’s business-value for you?

description:
The Dinosaur Feather by S.J. Gazan (448 pages)


Please join us for socializing anytime between 9.00 and 9.30.  The meeting begins promptly at 9.30. 


We welcome your book suggestions.  Please give your recommendations to Kate G.


This from amazon.com;

S.J. Gazan's debut novel The Dinosaur Feather is a classic of Scandinavian noir. With keenly observed and deeply flawed characters, this scintillating thriller uniquely employs one of the most controversial and fascinating areas of contemporary dinosaur and avian research in its diabolical twists. The Dinosaur Feather has been published in more than a dozen countries and won the Danish Crime Novel of the Decade Award. The Financial Times called it “a top-flight thriller—smart and outrageously entertaining.
  Biology postgraduate, PhD hopeful, and single mom Anna Bella Nor is just two weeks away from defending her thesis on the saurian origin of birds when her academic supervisor, the highly respected yet widely despised Dr. Lars Helland, is found dead in his office chair at the University of Copenhagen. The police discover a copy of Anna’s thesis in the dead man’s bloody lap. 

When the autopsy suggests that Helland was murdered in a fiendishly ingenious way, brilliant but tormented young Police Superintendent Søren Marhauge begins the daunting task of unraveling the knotted skeins of interpersonal and intellectual intrigue among the scientists at the university.

Everyone involved with the investigation— from Anna Bella Nor to Helland’s numerous rivals to Marhauge’s own ex-wife, who is pregnant with her current husband’s child— has something to hide, complicating the investigation and presenting the detective with the greatest professional and personal challenge of his career.

I'll bring all the materials, and you're welcome to bring bits of nature that you've found also. This may get messy - I recommend bringing an extra change of clothes too.

Hope to see your little artists there!

description:
Join us for this ongoing series of classes to learn how to choose happier thoughts and to lessen the effects of negative people. As you begin to change from the inside, you’ll see the world around you reflect your happier attitude. You’ll become a powerful positive influence in your world.


Each week we’ll practice simple tools and techniques for creating positive changes in your life, your work, and your relationships. You'll not only find yourself contributing your own personal good news stories, but you’ll leave each class feeling better than when you came in.


You’ll learn something new each week. Drop in to any class or join us for the whole session. We'll be practicing a number of exercises from the book, "Ask and It Is Given" by Esther and Jerry Hicks.

Note: This class is repeated on Fridays. You can show up for either class. This summer session contains new material and a review of material from prior sessions.


Feel free to call or email me if you have any questions. [masked]. [masked]. Or go to www.haveabetterday.net

Thanks, Mary Ursettie

description:
Meet and mingle with PWN members and guests at the Delancey Street Restaurant on the corner of Brannan St and the Embarcadero in San Francisco.


Networking - 12:00 noon - 12:30 p.m.

Lunch and Program: 12:30 p.m. - 2:00 p.m.

Bring your business cards and be prepared for your 30-second introduction.

August Speaker – Wendy Newman<a href="http://pwnetwork.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/Screen-Shot-2013-05-30-at-4.36.37-PM.png"></a>

Wendy is a workshop leader, consultant and writer on the subject of Women, Men, and Relationship.

HOW TO GET THROUGH TO MEN

• Have you ever had a magnificent idea to incorporate in a project, and then have that idea thwarted by a man?

• Have you ever felt dismissed when collaborating on a work project or in the strategic planning phases of something new?

• Have you ever told a man something important like “the car needs to be picked up from Tony’s shop no later than 3p.m. tomorrow or we won’t have a car for the weekend” and he didn’t hear it at all? Even after an “Uh huh” came right out of his mouth?

Sometimes it’s challenging to get through to men. Learn what’s really going on by understanding the difference between single focus, diffuse awareness and how the need for transition time can impact your conversations and communication. Find out about the energy shift when a project is getting “underway”.

When you can see how differently men and women think, speak, listen, collaborate, and approach planning and implementation, you can knowingly commit to any journey and ambition in a partnership with men, and get more of what we need from them along the way.

description:
Today's smart mobile devices are the new creative tools! These are not just devices for consumption but powerful tools for "creation" . Unleash your creativity, reinvent the inner artist in you - Paint, Draw, Animate, 3D-sculpt, 3D print, e-book creation and much more at 

mDAC Summit 2014!

 You have an artist's canvas to a full professional animation studio in your pocket. I am creating this meetup so that people who love to create on mobile devices , tablets , iPads can meet at one place. 

What: The Mobile Digital Art and Creativity Summit 


Where: The Pacific Art League,  668 Ramona Street, Palo Alto (across from City Hall).  

When: August 1st 5:30pm - 8pm  (Grand Opening - FREE event)

              Aug 2nd and Aug 3rd  8:30am - 5pm (Paid Summit - great value)   

Details:  It will be kicked off on Friday August 1st with the grand opening of the second International Mobile Art Exhibition on Friday, August 1st featuring a juried selection of work from artists around the world. COME ENJOY SOME nice ART, FOOD, WINE and LIVE iPad Painting DEMO!! And if you like to learn about iPad Paintings & other creative aspects, join us on Aug 2 & 3 for two day Summit. 

Please RSVP and Register here!  

http://youtu.be/_qoTzShtPQY

The program consists of two tracks. 

• The Mobile Digital Art track focuses on creation of artwork using different art apps such as Sketchbook Pro, Art Rage and Procreate. 

• The Mobile Creativity track focuses on creative apps which enable you to do pretty well anything from digital sculpting (with 3D printing) to caricaturing, photo manipulation, animation and creating comic strip characters. 

You can mix and match any session from any program

Click here for Program Agenda

 We look forward to seeing you for both the events. RSVP Today LIMITED SEATS !!!
name: Come Paint, Draw, Animate, 3D model, Create Comic, ebook - all on your iPad!

description:
EQ#101 is kicked off in July 2014. This group of EQ Warriors will meet every other Friday from July to November for total of 10 sections. We encourage you to participant all sections to maximize your take away though it is not compulsory.

We meet at 5:30 – 7:30 pm. The meeting room is sponsored by Cisco in Milpitas. I know It’s Friday night, we will start on time and finish on time so everyone still have time to hang out for the weekend.

All the dates are listed here FYI. Your RSVP is for the current date only.


1. July 18: Introduction and Meaningful Connection

2. Aug 01: Intro to 6Seconds and Emotional Literacy

3. Aug 15: Recognizing Emotional Patterns (RRP)

4. Aug 29: Navigating Emotions in Action (ME)

5. Sept 12: Consequential Thinking in Action (ACT)

6. Sept 26: Intrinsic Motivation

7. Oct 10: Optimism in Action

8. Oct 24: Empathy in Action

9. Nov 07: EQ in Action: Know-Choose-Give

10. Nov 21: EQ in Action: summary, a-hah moments, and next step

We require a small fee to increase attendance rate.  The fund will cover light refreshment and water.  The fee is non-refundable, so please make sure you can attend before RSVPing.  If you cancel, you lose the RSVP fee regardless of how far out you cancel. If you cancel in less than 24 hours, it will be treated like a No Show, in addition to losing the fee.  After three No Shows you will be asked to no longer RSVP.  You may attend as a guest of someone in the group who has RSVPd and indicated they are bringing a guest.  We hope this is reasonable. We're trying to be considerate of everyone who genuinely wants to attend.

Attendees are requested to be mindful at all times of their own personal emotional well being and the care and support of others in the group. If you have concerns about your own ability to remain emotionally and psychologically well in a group where deep life issues are being addressed we urge you to seek professional medical or psychological care. The group facilitators, while experienced healers and coaches, are not acting as licensed healthcare professionals and cannot be responsible for your personal care in a meetup group setting.
name: EQ#101：Creative Solutions for Life Challenges

description:
Hi all,

First Friday Happy Hour/Movie Night again! People can come for drinks/food, or meet us at the movies, or come for both.  I list the movie choices and times as the date gets close.  We don't all have to see the same movie :) Applebee's has great happy hour food and drink prices - which do end at 6, but the regular menu's very reasonable, too.  It's a short drive (or even a good walk) over to Pacific Commons for the movie. 


This is a casual, stress-free event.  It's Friday!  I don't care whether you arrive at 5:30 or 6-ish (please don't be scared off by the 5:30 start time), but do NOT be a no-show or a party-crasher, because that affects our reservations and Applebee's has been really good to us.  They're happy to seat the first few to arrive and let the rest seat as they get there, plus they do separate checks so late arrivals don't affect anyone else.  


It's been a nice monthly thing we have going :)  See y'all at the next one! 


Erin
name: "1st Friday" Happy Hour/Movie Night! (arrival time very flexible :)

July 18 -- Shane Dwight

July 25 -- Soul Kiss

Aug. 1 -- Sugadady

Aug. 8 -- Usual Suspects

Aug. 15 -- Entourage

Aug. 22 -- Super Bad

Aug. 29 -- Sage

Sponsored by the Morgan Hill Chamber of Commerce and its many business partners, this summer concert series takes place in/on the grassy knolls of the city's outdoor ampitheatre complex.

Bring: Lawn chairs and/or blankets to sit upon, and your favorite portable foods and beverages. You can purchase assorted wines and soft drinks in the venue, too.

Combine Romance, Serenity & Tradition with Outdoors & Free, toss in some guys with really tight pants and what do you have?  My Attention!  How about yours?

Once again the San Jose Symphony offers its free Summer Pops concerts on the lawn at San Jose State University. These are terrific events to picnic, socialize and listen to great music! Tonight will be Sol de México offering traditional mariachi sounds embellished with fresh contemporary passion and powerful new rhythms.

With their joyful pulse, this 14-member orchestrated mariachi group mirrors the romance, serenity and cultural tradition of old Mexico. Sol de Mexico is an inspiring, artistic mariachi ensemble, mesmerizing and animating the voice of their culture.


SJSU has plastic chairs if you want to sit on those or you can bring your own or sit on the grass. You will want to get there a bit early to get the best space.

description:
PLEASE NOTE: This is not a workshop.

COST: free


In the next couple of weeks I'll be co-leading an experimental Tarot and Art school in West Marin. The culmination of the project will take place at Krowswork Gallery on August 1st! Come out for free Tarot readings by the students, meditations and art!

"The Golden Dome is a nomadic school dedicated to investigating intentional living and art as it relates to cultivating ideas for sustaining and optimizing life on Earth. Each school session takes a figure from the Major Arcana as it's central theme, and focuses on the study of the spiritual dimensions within the natural sciences and the expansion of these insights into the physical art practice.

Our first program, 'Performing the Fool's Planetary Rites", takes place at a sustainable land art project in West Marin and centers around the study of the Tarot and it's relationship to performance.

The Golden Dome will take residence at Krowswork gallery offering performances, meditations, and tarot healing sessions for Oakland's First Friday on August 1st, 2014. The life and work of Eliza Swann and Laura Zuspan will also be featured." -E. Swann

ALSO: MY SUMMER HEALING PACKAGE

For the summer season I’m offering a special 2 month package consisting of one 60-min Tarot Reading and two follow up 90-minute Intuitive Coaching & Tarot Readings for only $195. This is a $90 savings.

The first 60-min session is designed to illuminate your current life story, where you’re headed and what your potential life purpose is revealing. From this first session I’ll assign homework and recommend readings. The following two sessions will be a hybrid of intuitive coaching -maintaining your success vision, the strategy to get there and your mindset coupled with relaxation techniques and a ceremonial Tarot Reading/Healing to help encapsulate the previous days/weeks work. This program has empowered and inspired many clients and jumped started change, flow and a general sense of purpose.

Please feel free to set up a phone consultation to answer any questions you might have on the program @ [masked]

“Sometimes our hearts need to open to the realm of new possibilities. Sometimes the path in front of us is hidden by distractions. Shift is inevitable. Laura is deeply intuitive and can hold space as your cards unfold.  She engages without judgment, patiently listens while we learn and sends us home feeling light, calm and clear.”

-Hannah Weiss, Midwife in Oakland

‘Laura’s reading’s are empowering and intuitive. I would recommend her to anyone, whether you have a specific question or are simply looking for insight and perspective.’ 

-Jessica N, Artist in Oakland
name: Tarot Readings and Art

description:
We’ve all had times when life has felt effortless and ON. Maybe we’ve felt it in work, or in art, or in sex. The problem is that most of us spend our lives grasping for this state with no clear way to get back, maybe we fall back into our familiar patterns. Some never wake up - it’s 2014 and it feels like 2012 was just yesterday. The antidote to this is total immersion – total immersion into your life, and total immersion into your relationships. And you can have it. It just takes a life or death attitude. That’s what you can expect from experts Nicole Daedone and Steven Kotler. Nicole and Steven both credit orgasm and flow with saving their lives, and are now widely recognized as the top experts on how to have orgasm and flow in your life.

This weekend is an opportunity to be on the front lines of this work. You’ll be put into experiential learning where you can learn not just the theory of what it means to live a life of total immersion – you’ll get both the nuts and bolts, and you’ll actually be in flow and orgasm this weekend, which research has shown increases learning by 5x. Benefits Spend a weekend in flow and orgasm (not your normal vacation) Hands on experiential learning into how to reproduce flow and achieve optimal states of performance In depth training on orgasmic meditation from Nicole Daedone; learn how to elevate sex to an art and a craft Achieve 5x learning potential, accelerate your path to mastery.

Be among the first in the world to get expert level training in both of these arenas; take optimal living into your life and into your relationships.

Faculty

Nicole Daedone is the author of Slow Sex: The Art and Craft of the Female Orgasm (Grand Central/Hachette, May 2011) and is the founder of OneTaste, a company that offers training in orgasm, sex, and man-woman relating through online media and in-person coaching and courses. The practice at the heart of her work is called OM or Orgasmic Meditation.

Steven Kotler is a New York Times bestselling author, award-winning journalist, and cofounder and director of research for the Flow Genome Project. His work has been translated into thirty languages and his articles have appeared in more than seventy publications, including New York Times Magazine, Atlantic Monthly, Wired, and Forbes

For questions feel free to contact Eli Block

name: A Living Experiment in Flow+Orgasm w/ Nicole Daedone+Steven Kotler *Tix Required

group.name: Play Games in Oakland Every Friday!

description:
We play and teach games all night long until midnight.  Drop in any time from 7:00 to 11:00 or so and you're sure to find something to play!  Bring your games from home or use any of the games from our extensive used game library.  We often have many tables going on at once for lots of variety.  The earlier part of the evening is ideal for families with kids.

We play all sorts of board games and card games on Friday nights, but also:

Got a favorite game you'd like to find others to play? Bring it along!  Let us know in advance if possible so we can help with recruiting players.

Our chess and Go guru Steve Bloom is often on hand to teach and play both, and will always confirm here if he's coming.  (Plus we have a separate Meetup for each every Sunday; for details see chess here and Go here.)

Very recently we've added Magic the Gathering every Friday (reserved table in the back) and on Thursdays too, hosted by Jimmy Freeman and both starting at 7:00 PM.  See our separate MTG Meetup page for details on these plus special MTG events. 

(We have had to drop our 2nd/4th Friday Pathfinder Beginner's Box offering for the time being due to the rapidly advancing pregnancy of the GM's wife -- congrats to both!  For now, check out our separate Pathfinder Society Meetup, held every Wednesday, here.)

In addition to these Friday Meetups and the ones linked above, there are yet more game-specific events for adults and youth over the course of each week, including Scrabble, youth Pathfinder, youth chess and youth Go classes/play, so check out our full schedule here. There's more to come, so be sure to stay in touch!

We request a donation of $3 to help offset the cost of keeping the store open so late every Friday.

Hope to see you soon!

-- Chris Specker and Will Kreber (owner/managers)

description:
<b style="font-size : 16px">Speaker: Vlad Ureche, EPFL

<b style="font-size : 16px">Title: What do autoboxing, value classes and specialization have in common?

Description:

Would you answer "a lot"? In this talk, Vlad will present a theory that unifies autoboxing, value classes, specialization and staging in a single transformation mechanism. This theory has been successfully used to implement three program transformations: miniboxing specialization (scala-miniboxing.org), multi-parameter value classes (github.com/miniboxing/value-plugin/wiki) and staging (github.com/miniboxing/staging-plugin/wiki).

The aim of all these transformations is to replace the data representation of certain objects in the program without altering the semantics. For example, we may want to unbox “scala.Int” to Java’s more efficient “int” representation whenever possible, to avoid the overhead of heap objects. However, unboxing even a single method parameter requires adapting all its callers plus the method’s body. This makes it very hard to transform a program without introducing inconsistencies.

Yet, tracking the data representation in the type allows us to add coercions between representations in an automatic, reliable and optimal way. This mechanism can later be customized to unbox primitive types, inline value classes, to perform specialization, to optimize closures or to allow multi-stage programming, which peels away the abstraction layers slowing down high-level code. Now, the question is: what’s YOUR use case for the transformation mechanism?

<b style="font-size : 16px">Speaker's short bio.

Vlad is a PhD student in the Scala Lab at EPFL, where he's working on optimizing high-level patterns in the Scala programming language down to fast JVM bytecode. His main project, miniboxing (scala-miniboxing.org), is aimed at compiling generic classes down to very efficient bytecode.<b style="font-size : 16px">

Schedule

• 6:30-7:00 - networking

• 7:00-7:10 - announcements etc

• 7:10-~8:40 - talk

• 8:40-9:00 - networking
name: What do autoboxing, value classes and specialization have in common?

description:
Join Yalla Arabi for an enchanting evening combining theater and live Arabic music based on the stories of "The Arabian Nights." (Alf Layla we Layla).  An Improvised "Arabian Nights" will tell stories in the style of Shahrazad 
of magic, heroes and wanderers.

An Improvised "Arabian Nights" Directed by Basel Al-Naffouri and Music by Joshua Raoul Brody and the Aswat Ensemble
Friday, August 1 @ 8:00 pm
Stage Werx, 446 Valencia St, San Francisco, California 94103
Ticket Prices: $20 (general) and $25 (VIP). Note there is a small service charge when you purchase your ticket online)
For tickets, visit: http://improvarabiannights.bpt.me/

An Improvised "Arabian Nights" is a *long-form improv performance brought to you by some of the Bay Area's most celebrated improvisers and classical Arabic musicians from the ASWAT ensemble. Our heroes and heroines inhabit an exciting world filled with genies, robbers, viziers, magical creatures, kings, princesses, demons, fishermen, merchants, ghouls and more. 

Each evening's show is created entirely in the moment without any script. Actors create stories on the spot, ranging from 20-90 minutes in length. Though completely improvised, performances display well-acted narrative arcs similar to that of scripted movies and plays.

NOTE: The show will be performed on Friday, August 1 and on Saturday, August 2. Each night will be new and completely different from the one before. 

Stage Werx, which is located at 466 Valencia Street in San Francisco's Mission District, is a few blocks away from the 16th Street BART station. Street parking in that neighborhood can be difficult so car pooling and public transportation is recommended.

There are also a lot of affordable restaurants in the Mission District, which are close to the theater. 

I will update the invitation if I can find a suitable place to meet before or after the show.
name: An Improvised "Arabian Nights"--Theatre and Live Arabic Music

description:
Hey guys.

It's time yet again for another Donner pass AND Big Chief weekend filled with my fave area for easy trad. 1, 2 to 3 multi pitch routes (school rock, snowshed, & grouse slabs - Saturday) Or some fun sport climbing at Big Chief (Sunday) or even top roping at Green Phantom. See link below for beta.

Things you will need:

*Camping gear (tent, pad, bag, headlamp, stover or boiler, food - Optional, wood etc)
*Gear - See as follows

Trad - Rope, Rack (alpine draws, biners locking/non locking, webbing, rack and or doubles as needed. Nut tool helpful

Sport -Rope, quickdraws, webbing enough for 2 basic anchors, carabiners (locking or non locking or both)

Helmet, shoes, harness, etc

*Sunscreen and bug spray as needed
Food & water 

-Friday - On you own for dinner

-Saturday day - snack food & water. 

Saturday night - cook at campsite or eat out)

Carpools eccouraged - I plan in taking off early Friday so I can up to Truckee early and beat traffic. Coming from Nob Hill, San Fran

Lakeside Campground:

Sites 21 & 23 - 6 per site, 1 car per site, rest in overflow. Camp assignment will be posted soon. We prefer you camp Fri-Sun

From Truckee, take Interstate 80 to Highway 89. Turn onto Highway 89 and travel north for about 5 miles, then turn right at the Prosser sign. Continue just over a mile to the campground.

description:
http://www.ticketfly.com/event/518409-magda-items-things-san-francisco/

Public Works & Sunset Sound System Presents:

+ Mossmoss (As You Like It)

www.soundcloud.com/magda-official
www.residentadvisor.net/dj/magda


Magda is an artist who can never be pinned down, no matter the timeframe or time signature. Any one of the Detroit-raised artist's DJ sets or productions breeds a rare feel of mystique and discovery. "I'm really obsessed with finding a line between things - between sounds and between genres. My influences come from a life spent in very different environments, which plays a huge role in the way I connect with music."

Dramatic sounds and eccentric basslines carry her multilayered sound, which veers everywhere from funked-out space disco to the intricately-programmed, metallic feel of Detroit to stripped down techno, all the way to Italian horror film soundtracks. The only thing that remains consistent is the element of surprise.

Her accidental entry into Detroit's underground party scene as a teenager was the kick-start she needed for a lifelong love affair. Soon all became a blur of "cities, record stores, and parties." In 1998, she joined Minus and began touring the world as Richie Hawtin's sole opener. From there, her distinctive sound began to develop and the rest is history.

Stylistically, Magda grooves through opposition - creating sets that are emotion-led yet clinical, having profound expertise with analog and digital technology. Her sound is otherworldly but visceral; dark with a warm sense of beauty and grace; sparse yet wondrously full-bodied with density and bass-swathed extremes. Magda's DJing style has been encapsulated on her mixed CDs 'She's A Dancing Machine,' and her mix for London club Fabric 'Fabric 49' (a mix CD with as much artistry and vision as an original album).

In the fall of 2010, Magda revealed her debut, 'From The Fallen Page,' a darkly- tinged, transportive album that curiously combines natural, organic sounds, and modern electronic grace. Similar to her unpredictable DJ sets, 'From The Fallen Page' took listeners from one end of the spectrum to the other, treading the fine lines of extremities along the way.

These days Magda isn't home very often. In-between touring, she's fully focused on her recently resurrected label 'Items & Things.' The label's vision always pinpoints the off-kilter and the uncommon, seeking out new artists and sounds that push boundaries. "Items and things are bits and pieces of uniqueness we come across. The label is a platform to launch the music that we love. There are no rules, just sounds we like and artists we believe in."

VINCENZO BIO:

An artist who has such talent, style and longevity is a rare creature nowadays... and Italo‐German Vincenzo Ragone, known to the House world as Vincenzo, is indeed one of these special creatures! Hard to track down and often a man of the night, Ragone has been casting his deep and truly one‐of‐a‐kind takes on House and Techno out into the ether for well over a decade. Vincenzo was a true child of the Acid House explosion, and one of an original cast of Hamburg based Djs and Producers, hanging out and collaborating with friends who would later become some of the trend setting icons of the present ‐ notably Poker Flat's future ringmaster Steve Bug offered him some crucial gigs at the revered 'Reduced' parties at Hamburg's 'Front' Club! From here on the star in the making went on to produce his first ever productions for the Raw Elements label, alongside Sandro Catallo in 1995, and then released his first ever solo tracks with the label in '97. His production energies began to draw him further and further into this magical music, which knew no bounds, and in 1998 Vincenzo released his debut album, the classic '1‐800‐Vincenzo,' on none other than the newly blossoming Dessous Imprint to great International applause. Numerous solo and collaborative releases followed, notching up studio time in New York with Alexi Delano (aka A.D.N.Y), leading to the A.D.N.Y & Vincenzo project. Clearly picking up a heavy dose of those soulful, US House flavours that would never wash away... His year spent living in New York proved Vincenzo had real International appeal, and increased touring to play gigs in House Clubs stateside, as well as globally, confirmed this musical passion was meant to be. His relationship with the funky yet stripped, Deep House movement continued through his enigmatic 'Strip Joint Grooves' series on Dessous, and also through further collaborations with San Francisco's Dj Rasoul, Nottingham's John Buckby aka Schmoov, Marc Schneider (aka Snider) and many, many more. Indeed his name and musical offerings continued to elevate and inspire, and recent releases and remixes on Dessous and Hamburg's Liebe*Detail records suggested a more mature, techy sound had sprouted from the seasoned house‐head's mixing desk. 2007's notable remix for the Liebe*Detail offshoot label 'Spezial', a stunning re‐think of a Move‐D modern classic, 'Anne Will', won him notoriety for effortlessly transcending both the Deep House and Minimal Techno worlds.... creating a reduced beach party track that also had the power to deeply rock the clubs! Vincenzo racked‐up a serious amount of air miles over his long and busy career (and he continues to do so!) He has worked with some of the most important producers and labels within his field of expertise, yet he maintains a humble existence, not wanting to over ‐play his part in the grand scheme of things. In fact, he shouldn't be so humble, as his records, both old and new, are consistently played and charted by a spectrum of Djs that most producers could only dream of... No surprise then that his most recent EP ́s for Pokerflat,Freerange and his own new imprint Teardrop picked up big support from steve bug,laurent garnier,josh wink,ian pooley and sasse.only to name a few: proof once more that this traditionally‐underground impresario of House is here to stay, and continues to share his unique sound with the world.
name: Magda, Vincenzo @ Public Works

Join us for friendship, camaraderie, fun, men's work, and personal growth. The South Bay Nation of Men meets on the first Saturday of each month, rain or shine, promptly at 8 AM. Breakfast (no charge) is served immediately afterwards. New members are always welcomed. 8-10 AM, Bramhall Park in San Jose. 

Attendance is generally 50 or so men. The Nation of Men is about friendship and camaraderie with mutual support to help us all be better men. Meetings mix social interaction with opportunities for introspection or personal growth and fun. 

The free breakfast after the meeting gives you an additional chance to meet members. All men are welcome and there is no charge to attend the meetings. We might even give you a cigar!

New to the Nation of Men and Want to Find out More? Plan on staying for the orientation that takes place after the general meeting. It helps men become part of the organization quickly. You will meet many of the members, learn our customs and principles, and have opportunities for growth and relationship. 

See photos from past events on our Facebook page: www.facebook.com/nationofmen

description:
Berkeley, California.

The second annual Effective Altruism Summit will take place from July 27- August 2. We are now accepting applications through the Summit website: www.effectivealtruismsummit.com

Effective altruism is a growing intellectual movement that uses evidence and reason to identify the most effective ways of improving the world. This approach often involves reframing the problem in order to get at less conventional and less obvious solutions. For example, if you want to improve the lives of the poor, society tells you to do something like join the Peace Corps. But in fact it may be more effective to work on Wall Street for two years, earn hundreds of thousands of dollars, and give most of it to a charity proven to save lives.

The Summit is largest annual gathering of the effective altruism movement. This year’s conference will be in two parts: a 5-day retreat for committed effective altruists looking to hone their strategy skills and make connections with like-minded people, and a 2-day conference for anyone interested in learning more about effective altruism and being part of the largest annual gathering of the community. The weekend conference will be a mixture of presentations, interactive workshops and social time. Speakers include:
  Peter Thiel, Thiel Foundation, co-founder of PayPal
Holden Karnofsky, co-founder of Givewell
Max Tegmark, co-founder of the Future of Life Institute, professor at MIT
 

Members of the following organizations will be in attendance: Machine Intelligence Research Institute; GiveWell; Centre for Effective Altruism; 80,000 Hours; Giving What We Can Center for Applied Rationality & Leverage Research.

You should apply if:
you want to be part of the largest collection of people trying to improve the world in a strategic way
you work at an NGO or charity and feel dissatisfied with the size of your impact
you want to improve the world and feel discouraged by the current options
you’re willing to look beyond simplistic solutions to figure out how the world really works
you want to apply more rigorous methods of evaluation to your current projects
you want to know how to select your next project

Financial aid is available. Inquire through the website or here: [masked]
name: Effective Altruism Summit

description:
Please join me for an easy 5-mile hike at Angel Island! We will follow dirt paths and fire trails (there are some stairs) to go around the island and then hike up to the top of Mt. Livermore (about 700 ft elevation change).


Let's meet at the Angel Island-Tiburon Ferry terminal at 9:30 am. The fare is $13.50. Cash, checks and credit cards are accepted...cash is easiest though! The ferry leaves at 10 am.


This is a fun hike that offers unique views of San Francisco, Marin, and the East Bay. Once at the top of Mt. Livermore we will stop for lunch and then return along the same trails to the ferry terminal. The ferry leaves Angel Island for Tiburon at 20 minutes past the hour. The last ferry leaves at 4:20 pm.


Once we are back on the mainland we will stop at Guyamas for margaritas and snacks/dinner.

Hope to see you there!
name: Angel Island Hike with post-hike margaritas at Guyamas!

Bicycle Trails Council of the East Bay has a group ride for women only, the first Saturday of the month. The emphasis of these rides will be fun and to meet other women who love to ride. We have rides geared towards all level of riders with experience leaders.

Our next outing will be somewhere fun (hey we can't plan THAT far in advance [:)]).  Plan on a 2-3 hour ride depending on your pace. Members and nonmembers welcome. If you have questions please email Amy.

description:
Summer Pie Run!

Can ya believe there are riders who have never been to Gizdich Ranch?!  It's totally true!  They don't know about the really cool roads to get there, the killer sandwich lunch, and yep, somehow they haven't even heard about the amazing Gizdich pies!  But they've probably heard of the revered Gizdich apple juice.

Well, this is the place and this is your time to see more of our fantastic roads!


This ROUTE <- click) is a stunning crowd pleaser.  The beautiful favorites, Soquel, Old Santa Cruz, and this time including the little traveled and simply gorgeous Browns Valley and Green Valley Roads.  But wait!  The beauty's not done yet - our return trip take us through Hicks Road.  For a route like this it's good to be a Pillion!  

We have new members at every meetup and today we want to meet you!


So, grab your handlebars, lets have lunch and some...

Meetup at 9:30am.  Mandatory Safety Talk 10am - it's true, miss the talk, you miss the ride.

This route is up/downhill and has many tight turns.  Not newbie friendly. 

Don't miss these upcoming Friends events...
Alice's Ride & Dinner  Thur, July 31
Ride to Danville Hot Summer Nights Car Show Thur, July 17
The 75th Anniversary - Sturgis 2015!  July 29, 2015
name: Pie Run!

description:
Lets meet at 10:00 AM. Tires roll at 10:10 AM.

We will do a tour of Skyline Ridge, Russian Ridge, Coal Creek, and Monte Bello Open Space Preserves. Get a taste of what each has to offer while meandering up and down through them all (approximately 2,000 to 2,500 feet of total climbing).

Distance: 12 miles on fire roads and single track, with a small bit of pavement riding

Riding Time: 3 hours

Difficulty Trail Rating: 3 "Moderate with a few modest climbs". On my scale of 1 -5, 1 being easy - I will say this may be a Level 3

Stamina rating: 3 - Modest climbing

Pace rating: 2 - Relax ride

Directions: Page Mill Road to Skyline Blvd. Then turn left (south) at the stop sign. You will drive about a mile and the parking lot will be on the right. After entering the Skyline Open Preserve, turn right and go to the farthest parking lot (visitor parking lot). The drive up Page Mill will take about 25 min from the 280/Page Mill area.

You have read the past ride reviews and seen the pictures, this is a fun group!!! As always, we will never leave anyone behind, take needed breaks, and regroup often. If your not sure where you are going or think you will be late, please leave earlier. We want you to join us for this ride.

As event host, I will reserve the right to change your RSVP should I feel you are not ready for this ride location.

Remember, all riders need to be members of Meetup.com & South Bay Mountain Bike Group. Guest are no longer allowed. All riders need to RSVP as a member.

Rain 48 hours before the ride may cancel. Check here for updates Sunday morning. ***Please remember, a helmet is required for all our rides.***

description:
Let's take a hike through the Presidio. It's a beautiful time of year- everything is green, and the park comes alive.

We'll meet at the Inn at The Presidio, and head over to the Ecology Trail. We'll follow the trail past the vista point to the Paul Goode Field, and the West Pacific Grove path. From there, we walk over to the Goldsworthy TREELINE installation- our pups become part of the artwork!. The installation follows Lover's Lane, and a connector path will take us back towards the Main Post to our starting point. I reckon this walk will take an hour and a half or so, depending on how much we dilly-dally. There will be plenty of places for our dogs to stop and have a romping game of chase (either each other, a toy, or their tail. Whatever works).

There's paid parking at the lot attached to the Main Post, and free parking at various spots throughout the Presidio.  Muni bus #43 lands about 5 minutes away.

Rain cancels

Join her, her dad the Tesla Officer on the Airship Albatross, and some genuine local Steampunkers to see this Bay Area treasure. We’ll have a tour of the museum and docent-led lecture on history of airships plus airship dress and uniforms. Any costumes are appreciated, from Victorian sundresses to leather jackets or vests. Normal clothes are perfectly acceptable.
We will provide light refreshments. You can bring a lunch and can eat in the meeting room if you wish. Cost $10 per person including refreshments. [Please note: This activity takes place right smack-dab in the middle of Shabbos.  We don't usually plan activities on Saturdays but for Valerie we will make an exception.] ;)

description:
If you love Renaissance Faires, this full scale, interactive experience is not to be missed. San Jose Renaissance Faire offers you a chance to visit the days of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth I.
​ Lose yourself in the magic and merriment of the Renaissance. Rub elbows with nobility, beautiful ladies, and Knights. 800 costumed performers will bring Shakespeare’s England to life with parades, pageants, and fun townsfolke, offering continuous entertainment of spectacular variety spread throughout the village. You’ll enjoy musicians, jugglers, and the ribaldry of actors drawing you even deeper into the Renaissance.
​ This year's San Jose Renaissance Faire will feature three stages of continuous entertainment, Action packed shows, Music, dancing, jesters, Shakespearean vignettes, expertly staged battles, storytelling for children and adults, archery and much more.
​ See brave and bold knights competing for the favor of the Her Majesty’s Court and for their lady’s affection during full-contact jousts held in the Queen’s Tiltyard each day!
​ Close to 100 merchants selling a wide array of arts and crafts, one of a kind jewelry items, woodcrafts, artwork, ceramics, clothing, historic weapons and leather goods. Whether you thirst a delicious drink or ALE or hunger for a Turkey leg WE will satisfy your taste buds with a wonderful variety of food and drink!!!

August 2-3 2014 10:00am - 6:00pm sat / 5:00pm sun
Guadalupe River Green, San Jose, CA ​

Daily Admission: $18 for adults * $13 for seniors 62+, military, ages 13-17 * $8 for children 6-12 * Under 6 FREE

Parking: $5.00 @ SAP Center / Shark Tank

Website: http://www.sanjosefaire.com/
name: San Jose Renaissance Faire

August 3rd: 10-2 PM and 2-6PM

Don't worry! There will be two people handling per cart so you won't be alone. Be sure to bring a hat and/or sunscreen as it gets pretty warm and we don't want you to get sunburnt. description:
￼

Voted East Bay's Best Source for Old Treasures!
The Main Street Martinez
2014 Peddlers Faires
Sat., May 17 & Sat., Aug. 2 | 8am-4pm
Featuring Vintage, Antiques, Collectibles and Arts & Crafts
in Downtown Martinez
The Antique & Collectible Capitol of Contra Costa County!

Join us for the 2014 Peddlers’ Faires in downtown Martinez.

One of the largest outdoor antique and collectible shows in northern California. Held on the streets of historic downtown Martinez on Sat., May 17th and Sat., Aug. 2nd, from 8am-4pm. Get here early to get the first pick of that special item to add to your collection.

You will find plenty to choose from as dealers will be showing a huge variety of antiques and collectibles including glassware, porcelain, pottery, furniture, old advertising, toys, native American wares, paper items and much more.

While at the Faire, be sure to visit the 14 stores downtown Martinez Antique and Collectible stores. The 50+ plus dealers in the stores will be bringing in new inventory for the Faire in preparation for the thousands of visitors on Faire day. In addition to the antiques and collectibles, there are over 50 arts and crafts vendors so there will be something for everyone at the show.

John Humphries, radio and TV collectibles talk show host, and the author of several books on collectibles, will again be on hand during the day to give evaluations of one (1) carry-in item for a $5 donation to the Martinez Historic Society. John will be located at the information booth on Ferry St. near Main St. from 8am-4pm. John is always a popular feature at the Faire so be sure to get in line early and get a number. Bring in that old piece of pottery, glass, toy or other collectible but remember, no furniture, carry-in items only please.

Directions to the event:
From I 680 - Take the Marina Vista Ave exit, West on Marina Vista. Arrive downtown in approx 2 miles.
From Hwy 4 - Take the Alhambra Ave. exit. Go North 2 miles to downtown. 

Parking and admission are free.
See you at the Faire!


Download VINTAGE, ANTIQUES, COLLECTIBLES Vendor Application,click here

Download ARTS & CRAFTS, COMMERCIAL Vendor Application, click here

For more informaton email
[masked]
Or call [masked]

description:
Let's meet for a quick fun walk for a exercise before it gets too hot.  We are meeting at the Starbucks on Santa Cruz Ave (NOT the one next to Safeway) at Highway 9 where there's plenty of parking spots on Saturday, June 28, 10 AM, then we'll walk through a nice quaint residential area to the trail entrance off of Roberts.  

*** Getting to the downtown Los Gatos, avoid taking 880 after Hamilton Exit on, as it'll be jammed with the beach goers.  Instead, take Winchester or Bascom into Los Gatos.

** RSVP if you plan to join the walk.  Join us even if you didn't RSVP.  NO need to RSVP "NO" if you're not attending.

The nice flat trail from downtown Los Gatos to Vasona Lake County Park is a very pleasant 1.1 mile, 20-minute walk along the creek on a flat paved trail.  Since the the trail to/from the Vasona Park is mostly shaded by the trees, you won't feel overheated even on a hot summer day.  

We can add more miles by walking along the scenic lake a bit, so we can make this a moderate 3-mile stroll of 1 hour.  

Bring a bottle of water, sun screen, hat, layer of clothing to adjust for the warmer/cooler weather.

Moderate to heavy rain cancels.

description:
As an Android developer, do you wish you could solve the issues on your own?   Does seeing cryptic error messages from the compiler or IDE want to make you run for hills?   Do you wonder if you're the only one who spends hours trying to get your apps to run?

This workshop is geared for Android beginners who have already built one basic Android app who want to develop or enhance their debugging skills.  You must have Eclipse or Android Studio along with a working Android emulator installed.

In this workshop, we'll also talk about some of the approaches and mentality you'll need to have to troubleshoot your own code.  We will go through a few exercises in which you will have to fix issues in intentionally broken Android programs.  We hope this workshop will allow you to feel more self-sufficient and capable at uncovering the issues in your own Android programs.  

Please make sure to bring your own laptop and power cable.  WiFi and power will be provided.   You must signup and be on the final list in order for security to permit you in the building.

The event will be led by instructors Ari Lacenski and Roger Hu. Two other teaching assistants will be helping out as well!  Coffee, Breakfast and lunch will be provided.


Email us at [masked] if you have any questions. Look forward to seeing you all there!
how_to_find_us: For entrance, you need to tell guests to enter through Lobby 4 and check in w/ Security. There will be signs pointing guests from Lobby 4 through the corridor to our Lobby 5.
name: Android Debugging Workshop

description:
This is one of my regular spots. They used to be located in the Danville Hotel on Hartz Ave, but moved to a new location across the street from Trader Joe's. The new location is much larger and retains a lot of the indoor mixed with outdoor atmosphere the old location had. Even though it lost the patio that overlooked all the pedestrians walking up and down Hartz, I think they did a good job with the new place to retain the character. 

NEW THIS EVENT: We will have a donation box for $1 per person showing up. The donation will fund name tags, flag stickers if I find them, and as a fund to secure future venues for BBQs, Pot Lucks, wine tasting etc.... This was a suggestion by a member to improve the cross socializing, and start adding different types of events. All good ideas deserve a chance :)

On the weekends they serve Beignets with raspberry sauce. Not quite Cafe Du Monde in new Orleans, but good. They also have a good breakfast menu.

They serve Blue Bottle coffee (based in Oakland), which is one of the gourmet brewed one cup at a time brands. If you stay for lunch, I think their hamburger is one of the best in the area. 

The place is popular,  but they have more space at the new location so I will expand the limit to 20, and we can test how that goes. 

The new Location is approximately a block from the Iron Horse Trails for those of you interested in hiking/biking before or after. 

The format for Coffee is the same. Come when you please and leave when you please, making this a good on the way spot if you are driving up or down 680 that day, or live close to Danville. For the rest of us, this is a great place to start our day. Hope to see you there.

venue.name: Sideboard Neighborhood Kitchen and Coffee Bar

how_to_find_us: Sign on Table
name: Blue Bottle Coffee and Beignets

description:
This is a Monarch butterfly...the only insect to migrate about 2500 miles twice yearly from the northern US to parts of Southern California and Mexico in the winter.  The migration begins in late September but can be earlier or later depending on the weather.  In honor of our hard working butterfly friends, we're making a woven wire butterfly this morning.

The technique we'll be using is wire weaving--techniques that have been honed through courses this summer, so this is the perfect time to elevate your skills to include wired insects!  For this course, designed for the beginning to intermediate jeweler, we'll be making TWO butterflies (one full and one profile).


This is a great project, so get your wires, pliers and BEADS ready for this.  Here's what you'll need to bring

1 Chain Nose Plier

1 Round Nose Plier

1 Flush Cutter

1 Planishing Hammer (Crowned or Domed)

1 Bench Block

18 Gauge wire

24 Gauge wire (can be colored if you want that)

Beads and Crystals

Prerequisites:  All participants MUST have completed Jewelry 1 and 2, and it's highly recommended that you finish at least TWO (2) wire weaving classes in order to take this course.
how_to_find_us: Across from Stevens Creek Nissan and at the Corner of Stevens Creek & Albany
name: Woven Wire - The Butterfly (Class 4)

description:
We will meet at 10:30 AM. Shuttle will roll at 11:00 AM even if you are not present. If you have a Yes RSVP on July 18th, you will be required to pay for your shuttle spot. All shuttle spots are being held for our group but must be paid for by each participant individually. Call [masked] to pay for your shuttle spot. The cost is $15. Please give them your name and tell them that you are with South Bay Mountain Bike Group. If you do not pay by July 18th you may loose your spot on the shuttle!

Ride Description:

Mt. Rose to Marlette Lake via the Flume Trail:

950 feet of climbing. 20 miles

Pack a lunch! We will eat at Marlette Lake.

The beginning of this beautiful section of the Tahoe Rim Trail is at 8700' above the Sheep Flats (aka Tahoe Meadows) on the Mt. Rose Highway above Incline Village.


It is often quite cool in the morning at the shuttle drop off site so bring a wind shell to start the ride. The first part of the trail parallels the highway and then descends through the meadows and briefly joins the Ophir Creek trail.

After a 300' climb out of the meadows (the biggest climb until you reach the Tunnel Creek road) you begin to contour your way to the Tunnel Creek road. There are many great vistas of Lake Tahoe as well as Washoe Lake in Nevada. The contrast between the Tahoe basin and the Great basin is startling. There are many small climbs and descents along the route toward the Tunnel Creek road in the Lake Tahoe Nevada State Park. This section is moderately technical due to the many solo rock steps. Lofting your front wheel over the steps is a very useful skill to have in your quiver.

At about nine miles, you will come to the Tunnel Creek Road (8000'). Down this road to the right a half a mile brings you to the North end of the Flume Trail. The views on the Flume trail are awesome. It is truly one of the best trails to get views of Lake Tahoe.

As you ride the Flume Trail it will take you past Marlette Lake. The ride will then head back along the Flume Trail to Tunnel Creek Road. Yes, you will be doing the Flume Trail twice. At the intersection at Tunnel Creek Road, it will be truly all downhill back to the cafe parking area. The road down is very sandy in places so watch your speed. Please smile and say hi to all trail users.

</a>

<a href="http://photos3.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/5/5/a/2/highres_138021922.jpeg" target="_blank">

</a>

<a href="http://photos3.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/5/5/a/2/highres_138021922.jpeg" target="_blank">

http://www.theflumetrail.com/

Shuttle Fee: $15

Directions:

From South Lake Tahoe and the casino district, after the casino district continue north on US 50 about 12 miles to the junction of State Route 28. Turn left onto State Route 28 and proceed about 15-20 minutes north. The new bike store/cafe is located on the right.

Places to stay: http://www.therealplaces.com/hotels-on-street/CA/South%20Lake%20Tahoe/Ski%20Run%20Boulevard

Remember, all riders need to be members of Meetup.com & South Bay Mountain Bike Group. Guest are no longer allowed. All riders need to RSVP as a member.

Please remember to wear a helmet, bring plenty of water (this will be a long ride!), and check that your bike is ready to ride. Also remember to carry an extra tube and a chain master link with you that fits your bike. Its ok if you need help to repair it, you will have the items needed to keep your ride going.

As organizer, I will reserve the right to change your RSVP should I feel you are not ready for this ride location. I am going to give priority seating to our regular members. How do you become a "regular" member? Simple, RSVP for rides and show up!

By joining this event, you hereby RELEASE and DISCHARGE it's owners, principals, affiliates, presenters, organizer, assistant organizer, hosts and participants from any and all liability, claims, demands or causes of action that you now have, or may have in the future, for injuries, damages, death and/or economic loss of any kind or nature, arising in whole or in part out of the activities, advice or information contained herein. You further agree that if you or someone under your supervision uses the information on this website you assume all risks of injury, damage, and economic loss, without limitation, and release providers from all liability therefore.
name: Tahoe Rim Trail & The Flume Trail - Lake Tahoe

description:
This will be a day long session for photographers interested in photographing the female nude with additional post processing instruction. The time will be split into two halves- first we will work with our model under studio lights of various set-ups and available light, studying the possibilities available with each. Photographers will work individually with the model to create unique images with guidance from Billy Monday.

In the second half of the workshop, we will take some of our images to the computer, studying digital processing for satisfying results in both color and black-and-white. Digital SLRs of any level are encouraged, and if you're not familiar with your camera you should remember to bring it's manual.

Software demonstrated will include Adobe Lightroom, Adobe Photoshop, and the Google Nik Collection. At the workshop's close, you will have a handful of carefully conceived, nicely lit and creatively processed photographs, a greater working skill-set, and new friends who love this art as much as we. Billy Monday, traveling all the way from Frederick, MD, will be leading this workshop. Billy has extensive experience in capturing the beauty and complexity of the female human form. "My photographs can be placed in two general categories: those images which I make in the studio are studies in lighting, contrast and geometry; whereas the images made in the natural environment are an attempt to fuse landscape photography with figure art". All of his photographs, whether captured on film or digitally, go through a digital post-processing stage. 

For more of Billy's work, click here: http://billymonday.com

Bill will be traveling with Mary Celeste, a highly experienced figure model with an easy-going personality. Mary Celeste is an excellent subject for photographers who are studying studio work. Her classical posing style and her familiarity with the dynamic between model and photographer virtually guarantee success. 

More of Mary's work at http://www.modelmayhem.com/1509848

Location: The Lighthouse Berkeley 1310 9th St. Berkeley, CA 94710 

Date and Time: August 2nd, 2014 11am - 5pm
Snacks and refreshments will be provided. 

Fee: $300
includes 6 hrs of educational, model fees, studio fees and a full release. Bonuses: networking, snacks, hands on training 

Things to Bring: DSLR Cameras and Lenses of your choice, Laptop loaded with Photoshop, Lightroom or comparable software, computer chargers, your creativity and energy for a full day

About The LIGHTHOUSE Berkeley:

The Lighthouse is a photo studio/event space in Berkeley, that runs events, workshops and meet ups for people interested in creating art. The content ranges from fashion shoots to hanging from a Lyra to fine art nudes and filling all the gaps in between. We are affiliated with amazingly talented photographers eager to share their knowledge in lighting; professional models that carefully instruct the female form in providing posing techniques for up and coming talent; and hair, make-up artists and stylists interested in making your ideas come to life. The Lighthouse is available for private bookings hourly, half days or full day rates. We have professional, internationally published models coming through monthly and also widely publicized, amazingly talented photographers on board to teach our groups on various topics. This is intended to be more of a coop of artists of various forms coming together in a common space. We are continually growing and building. You can check out the website atwww.thelighthouseberkeley.com for rates and more info. We invite you to join us!

Want to Teach? The LIGHTHOUSE is always looking for partners that want to give back to the community and help our members grow and learn. If you have exceptional knowledge on any photography related topics, we want you! We are looking to build a community of artists seeking to enhance their skills and master their craft.

Contact Candace at [masked] Thanks!
how_to_find_us: www.facebook.com/thelighthouseberkeley
name: THE DIGITAL NUDE  and Billy Monday featuring Mary Celeste

description:
If you haven't done this one yet, you owe it to yourself!

Spectacular views up top and a perfect lunch spot.  On the way up there we might head over to a waterfall, so plan on a vino/snack break along the trail.

The hike has a gradual elevation gain of 1,600' and the difficulty level is moderate to strenuous.

This is a fun hike that takes in plenty of different scenery and views.  We'll start in the lower lush region of the park that has a beautiful canopy, then head for the higher regions to the top of Barnaby Peak.  The trail we take is fairly gradual, so virtually anyone can make it to the top. Spectacular views up top and a perfect lunch spot.  On the way up there we might head over to a waterfall.  Plan on a vino/snack break along the trail, so be prepared.

Plan on spending the entire day - in other words, no pub crawls that night.   This is an incredibly beautiful park, and we'll see a lot throughout the day.

What To Bring:

Vino! (and cups)

Good Hiking Boots/shoes

Layered clothing, hat, sunscreen, insect repellent

2 liters of cold water (1/2 fill and refrigerate, then top w/ ice in the a.m.)

Vino/Snacks for our pre-lunch break during the hike

Potluck Lunch ~ Food and more food -  (dried fruit/nuts/seeds, chips, dips, salsa, wraps, cut up sandwiches, meats/cheeses/braeds/crackers, deserts - be creative!)

Drinks, drinks, drinks!

If you've been on any of my hikes you know what to expect - so be prepared for fun!

$5 activity fee

Your sense of humour is an absolute must! 

<a>Driving directions</a>:

GPS  38.029805,-122.736678


1. Take 101 North to exit 450B toward San Anselmo

2. Merge onto Sir Francis Drake Blvd.

3. Slight left to stay on Sir Francis Drake 19.2 mi

4. Turn right onto Ca-1 North/Sir Francis Drake Blvd.

Drive approx 1&1/4 miles past the park entry (and just past the road for Devil's Gulch) and park in the small lot on the left side of the road.  Parking is extremely limited, so please park tightly and carpool if possible.

If coming from the North the parking area will be on your right, prior to reaching the park entry.

 

Naturally you'll meet new people, as this is posted to several Meetup grps.
name: View To A Thrill: Samuel P. Taylor 9-10 miles

group.name: Walking in San Francisco for Health and History

description:
Now open for RSVPs. Anyone may quit the walk at the half-way point, Glen Park, and leave on BART. The first half of this walk is easy, the second half is much harder because it goes up Diamond Heights. The only cost is $3 cash for the walk, but never at the starting point. Kids free. We meet in front of a Starbucks with 2 restrooms, about 1 block West of the West Portal Muni Station, cross street is Vicente. One can take the K, L, or M lines to reach the station.

One should bring a sack lunch or buy one at our starting point. At 11:10 AM we will start walking East on Vicente Street towards St. Francis Wood which bends South and becomes Santa Clara Ave. We will continue on Santa Clara Avenue and then turn right on Monterey Boulevard. Then we visit the 2 big fountains. After exploring St. Francis Wood we will walk through Monterey Heights.

We plan to eat our sack lunches at the Sunnyside Recreation Center and then walk to the Sunnyside Conservatory. Then we walk to Glen Park. The walk is easy up to this point, and attendees who want may leave early by the Glen Park BART Station. We will visit the newly improved Glen Park Recreation Center. Then the group walks up Diamond Heights. Then we walk down Noe Valley, and end in the Mission neighborhood. I estimate the distance is 6 miles or less. Estimated arrival time at our end point, the 24th Street BART Station, is 4:15 PM.

We will have plenty of restrooms stops, and will see lots of good things such as mansions, great views, parks and mini-parks. This part of SF has everything except tourists.

If you have any questions about how to get around the Bay Area on public transportation below is a trip planner link:
http://transit.511.or...

I discourage people from driving and parking in SF. If one has to drive to this event one can park for free during the weekends on the street in the nearby St. Francis Wood neighborhood.

Some legal disclaimers: By joining us for any event you hereby RELEASE and DISCHARGE it's organizers, hosts and participants from any and all liability, claims, demands or causes of action that you now have, or may have in the future, for injuries, damages, death and/or economic loss of any kind or nature, arising in whole or in part out of the activities, advice or information contained herein. You further agree that if you or someone under your supervision uses the information on this website you assume all risks of injury, damage, and economic loss, without limitation, and release providers from all liability therefore. It is advisable to consult a doctor before you begin any strenuous physical activity. The organizer is not trained for emergency medical procedures and no doctors, nurses or ambulances are provided on the walks.

description:
If you haven't done this one yet, you owe it to yourself!

Spectacular views up top and a perfect lunch spot.  On the way up there we might head over to a waterfall, so plan on a vino/snack break along the trail.

The hike has a gradual elevation gain of 1,600' and the difficulty level is moderate to strenuous.

This is a fun hike that takes in plenty of different scenery and views.  We'll start in the lower lush region of the park that has a beautiful canopy, then head for the higher regions to the top of Barnaby Peak.  The trail we take is fairly gradual, so virtually anyone can make it to the top. Spectacular views up top and a perfect lunch spot.  On the way up there we might head over to a waterfall.  Plan on a vino/snack break along the trail, so be prepared.

Plan on spending the entire day - in other words, no pub crawls that night.   This is an incredibly beautiful park, and we'll see a lot throughout the day.


What To Bring:

Vino! (and cups)

Good Hiking Boots/shoes

Layered clothing, hat, sunscreen, insect repellent

2 liters of cold water (1/2 fill and refrigerate, then top w/ ice in the a.m.)

Vino/Snacks for our pre-lunch break during the hike

Potluck Lunch ~ Food and more food -  (dried fruit/nuts/seeds, chips, dips, salsa, wraps, cut up sandwiches, meats/ch

eeses/braeds/crackers, deserts - be creative!)

Drinks, drinks, drinks!

If you've been on any of my hikes you know what to expect - so be prepared for fun!

$5 activity fee

Your sense of humour is an absolute must! 

<a>Driving directions</a>:

GPS  38.029805,-122.736678


1. Take 101 North to exit 450B toward San Anselmo

2. Merge onto Sir Francis Drake Blvd.

3. Slight left to stay on Sir Francis Drake 19.2 mi

4. Turn right onto Ca-1 North/Sir Francis Drake Blvd.

Drive approx 1&1/4 miles past the park entry (and just past the road for Devil's Gulch) and park in the small lot on the left side of the road.  Parking is extremely limited, so please park tightly and carpool if possible.

If coming from the North the parking area will be on your right, prior to reaching the park entry.


  Naturally you'll meet new people, as this is posted to several Meetup grps.
name: View To A Thrill:  Barnabe Peak, Samuel P. Taylor

description:
Bonjour, tous le monde !

Our second annual foreign language draft is coming up, and this year I'm hosting a draft of the new core set in French. We'll have wine and cheese and baguettes and learn a little French along the way.

It'll be $15 to draft and keep your cards. Or, you can just show up and play for free! If you decide before the draft you don't want to keep these silly French cards, there will be no charge to just come and draft and snack and hang out.

I'm in Pleasanton, but we're not far from the Dublin/Pleasanton BART Station and will pick up anyone that needs a lift from there.

"But Ben, I don't know French, nor do I want to learn any French!" I'm sorry, but it's too late. Thanks to the Norman conquest, English has a ton of words that come from French. You probably recognize most (if not all) of the following French words that you'll find on the M15 cards.

• Artefact


• Aura


• Contrôle and Contrôleur


• Couleur


• Créature

• Enchantement


• Équipement


• Exil

• Intimidation


• Légendaire


• Mana

• Régénérer

That's just the beginning. Lots of other words are similar to other English words in ways that you'll recognize. You'll play Terrains to cast spells such as Rituels (Sorceries), activate Capacités (abilities), and when your creatures die, they'll enter your Cimetière. Over the next couple of weeks, I'll post a lot of other words that you might find useful, with cards to test your knowledge.

Looking forward to playing! À bientôt !
name: M15 Draft en français!

description:
Calling San Francisco's SMALL rescue dogs for a meetup on the first Saturday of each month at 11:30 am in Pine Lake Dog Park in Stern Grove.

If you have a small rescue dog and want to meet other rescues and their parents, please join us for off-leash play and schmoozing.

Don't worry if your dog is quirky; ours are, too!

RUFF co-organizer Shannon Bolt of The Domestic Animal has worked with shelter and rescue dogs for years. She specializes in special-needs animals and will be on hand for advice and assistance.

This meetup is for SMALL DOGS UP TO 25 POUNDS ONLY (or who should weigh less than 25 pounds!) — the mutt-ier, the better; but we won't discriminate against purebreds — and their adult people (this is NOT the place for children; many small dogs, especially those with issues, are afraid of kids) are welcome. Please remember to give all the dogs their "space" and ask before giving treats. We'll have a great time!

We socialize in one of the grassy areas west of the parking lot for 30–40 minutes (look for the RUFF sign), then we take a group walk around the park, so if you come very late, you'll have to chase us!
name: RUFF (Rescues United For Fun) Small-Dog Meetup

description:
Sanborn County Park in Saratoga is host to Shady Shakespeare Theatre company. This August, they'll be presenting Pride and Prejudice in the park. Let's see the play, then spend the night at the park's campgrounds.

I have reserved 2 camping spots in the park. Each spot can hold a maximum of 2 tents and 6 people- so we'll have to double up. We'll also have to car-pool, as it's two cars per campsite (for a total of 4 tents, 4 cars and 12 people).

THE PARK- Sanborn County Park in Santa Clara County is about an hour from San Francisco. It offers several easy hiking trails, in mostly shaded areas.
THE PLAY-   According to the website, dogs are allowed at this event, but they must be very well-behaved.  We'll try to sit off to the side. General admission tickets to the play can be ordered here http://shadyshakes.org/tickets.php. Please purchase GENERAL ADMISSION  ($15)for SATURDAY AUGUST 2. It's the wonderful story of Mr Darcy and the Miss Bennetts and all so very British. YOU MUST PURCHASE YOUR TICKETS BEFORE YOU SIGN UP FOR THIS EVENT. Email me a copy of your receipt so I know you've purchased it. Failure to pre-purchase will move you to "not attending" status.

THE CAMPGROUND. I have reserved walk-in camp spots # 11 and #12 for us. Near a bathroom, but with a bit of privacy. Each spot has a BBQ pit and a picnic table. DOGS MUST BE ON LEASH, and can not be left unattended in the car or tied up outside.

MEALS- We'll figure out the logistics/menu later, but we can plan on Saturday lunch (picnic), Saturday dinner (early BBQ, plus the theatre has a concession stand with coffee, tea, wine, soft drinks, chips and candy), and Sunday breakfast. We'll stop for supplies in Saratoga and split the cost.

We'll also figure out who is rooming with whom once we get a little closer. Tent-mates will be same gender. If you'd rather not risk having an unknown tent-mate, one option is to reserve an adjoining campsite for yourself. Choose site #13 or #14 and make a note of it in "comments" so we know to add the extra headcount.

When you sign up, please let us know the following
--Do you have a tent? the larger the better, as it will have to hold people and dogs.
--What other camping/storage equipment can you bring?
---We will have to car pool. Is your car large enough to take on passenger (plus dog, plus equipment). If not, please let us know that you will be a passenger and not a driver.

This should be a fun evening, and I think we'll all be dog-tired once we get home
how_to_find_us: We'll meet in San Francisco and drive down together.
name: OVERNIGHT  Theatre and camping trip to Saratoga

Rent or bring your own.


- Plastic Singles: $20 per hour
- Plastic Doubles: $30 per hour
- Composite Singles: $40 per hour
- Composite Doubles: $60 per hour
http://www.calkayak.com/rentals.cfm#4552

If you are a first-timer, they recommend double sea kayaks for added safety and fun! Launching from their special kayak-dock at Jack London Square, we paddle towards the sheltered inner waters of the Estuary.

Please let us know if you plan to get a single or need a partner.
name: Kayak on Oakland Estuary

description:
Annieglass Tour & Wine Tasting – Saturday afternoon – 12:30 p.m.

Let’s visit this well known production studio and store of the local, Smithsonian Artist and entrepreneur, Annie Morhauser or, most people know as, the Annieglass production studio in Watsonville.

I have seen glass blowing artists in Venice, Italy and in Tacoma, Washington – it is great to have this local gem near us.  Why is this local glass so different?


There is something for everyone - men & women. It is Fun for the whole group.


Studio Tours 2:00 pm

See how Annieglass uses a very unusual method of glass making and discover the craftsmanship that goes into every piece, lively and informative tours are approximately 20 minutes long (all walking) not appropriate for very young children. No photography please. Take a tour and receive 10% off your same-day purchase of Annieglass.* No charge for tours.


Wine Tasting


on Saturday, 12:00 pm to 4:30 pm
Pouring Santa Cruz and Monterey County Wines

 Taste 3 wines for $6  or sit and enjoy a glass - Buy a bottle to take home and tasting fee is waived

Optional early supper afterwards - group will choose.
