FUN! Let's meet up for the Taste of Downtown food & wine stroll through downtown Livermore! I attended last year and they had some amazing food booths! 

"Sample from a Bounty of Local Wines & Culinary Treats, Live Music, Horse Drawn Carriage Rides and More as you Shop & Dine in Downtown Livermore!"

I will figure out a good place to meet as this draws closer.

group.name: SF Girlfriends Book Club & Social Group

description:
Let's dine together & discuss Ariana Huffington's new book Thrive: The Third Metric to Redefining Success and Creating a Life of Wellbeing, Wisdom, and Wonder!

This book has been on my list since it came out earlier this year and I think it's a perfect read as we approach the end of the summer and gear up for the remainder of the year ahead.  Come join us to discuss the book and enjoy a yummy meal!
name: Dine & Discuss: Thrive (Saturday Book Talk!)

description:
Hosted by the Shulgin Memorial Team.

All attendees MUST get their free ticket at http://shulginmemorial.eventbrite.com/.

A memorial service to honor the life and work of Dr. Alexander T. "Sasha" Shulgin (1925-2014) at the Berkeley Community Theater. You may be familiar with Sasha's seminal books 

PiHKAL

 and 

TiHKAL

or his groundbreaking research in chemistry. But not as many knew the man himself: his sense of humor and skills as a teacher, his grace and kindness. We will share stories, savor memories, and hold space for a future that is wide open, in no small part because of the prodigious life work of Sasha and Ann Shulgin.


In the manner of many dinners and holiday parties at the Shulgin home, the reception following the service will be a potluck. All are invited to bring dishes made with love. Of course that's optional, especially if you’re coming from afar.  Due to venue policy, no alcohol, other intoxicants, or smoking is allowed.


This is a free event; however, we urge you to RSVP so we can plan accordingly. Please share this event thoughtfully with those who wish to honor Sasha.

Doors open at 1pm:  If you’ve brought something for the potluck, please hand it to a greeter.


Service begins promptly at 2pm: Please enter the theater in silence, well before 2pm. Doors will close. Late arrivals may watch the service on a screen in the lobby.


Reception to follow:  Potluck items. Water and coffee will be provided. Formal tea service in the lobby. Connection and merriment.


Event ends at 6pm.

Please note:  No alcohol, any other intoxicants, or smoking of any kind is permitted in the venue or on the grounds, which are public school facilities.

If you'd like to contribute to the Shulgin legacy, please visit: shulginresearch.org/home/donate

If you'd like to subscribe to the Team Shulgin email list, please visit: shulginresearch.org/home

For those who can’t attend in person, plans are being made to stream a live webcast from the theatre.  When this is finalized, we will add the webcast link to this EventBrite page and to shulginresearch.org/home.
how_to_find_us: Hosted by the Shulgin Memorial Team
name: Shulgin Memorial

description:
Join us for an afternoon of playing Cashflow -- and trying to get out of the Rat Race.

Based on the principles in the #1 seller Rich Dad, Poor Dad, the game is both a lot of fun to play and a great educational tool that helps develop a stronger "investor mindset." And it's a terrific way to meet people who share similar passions about improving their financial education.

The afternoon will start with a short presentation on Cash Flow 101 for beginners and experienced players alike.  I've learned a few tricks to playing this game that add a lot of value I'd like to share with everyone.
name: CashFlow Game!

description:
Startup Finance: Valuation

About: Learn how to value a startup.

Finance is a powerful global force and valuation lies at its core. Valuation makes or breaks a company. It is critical to understand valuation as an investor, entrepreneur, consultant and employee.

There are many circumstances in which valuation is critical:

A. You are looking to raise funding for your company.

B. You are looking to invest in a startup.

C. You are looking to work for a startup and your success is tied to the startup’s success.

D. You are about to get paid in equity.

E. You are interested in selling your business.

This class is focused on startup valuation with entrepreneurial and non-public valuation needs in mind. We cover concepts such as pre-money, post money valuation and valuation equations used for private companies. We will be looking at Startup Valuation from the financial perspective. You can expect to walk away with a few equations and ideas on how to make financial projections.

This class is ideal for entrepreneurs, investors and anyone interested in working for or with a private company. Attendees to this seminar will walk away with a better understanding of the valuation process.  Attendees can expect to walk through a financial example of valuation.

Testimonials:

“This is one of the best finance classes I have ever taken.”

- Andrew

“I took the “Startup Finance Valuation” class; excellent job. This class is a must for all entrepreneurs. MBA classes do not teach how to value a startup, this class does.”

- Danny

“After taking this class I have a clear perspective on valuation. I recommend this class to all entrepreneurs. Thank you for a very informative class.”

- Bonnie

“I have been in banking for over 20 years and this class taught me valuable concepts not covered by all the classes I have taken throughout my career.”

- Yaakov

description:
I'll be providing study materials to get people started.  Bring a pen or a pencil and a notebook if you'd like to take notes.

 

We'll use Gaeilge gan Stró as a general basis (I have both the introductory and intermediate texts) as well as other various resources gathered from the private tutoring and classes that I attend.  We'll also use some conversations from the TEG (Teastas Eorpach na Gaeilge - The European Certificate in Irish).

 

If you own an iPhone, iPod Touch, or iPad that is running iOS 6.0 or later, I can share a my photostream of Irish children's texts that you can use for translation practice.

name: Study Irish

description:
This is a Monarch butterfly...the only insect to migrate about 2500 miles twice yearly from the northern US to parts of Southern California and Mexico in the winter.  The migration begins in late September but can be earlier or later depending on the weather.  In honor of our hard working butterfly friends, we're dedicating THIS Wicked Wire Challenge to our butterflies.

The technique will be using is wire weaving--something that we've working on this summer, so this challenge is open to anyone with the weaving "chops" to make a butterfly.  I will present five (5) ...yes FIVE...different methods to making butterflies (full profile and half) and you can choose one of the five or select one that you'd like to make yourself!! 

This is a great project, so get your wires, pliers and BEADS ready for this.  Here's what you'll need to bring

1 Chain Nose Plier

1 Round Nose Plier

1 Flush Cutter

1 Planishing Hammer (Crowned or Domed)

1 Bench Block

18 Gauge wire

24 Gauge wire (can be colored if you want that)

Beads and Crystals

(If you want to make Butterfly Earrings, you will need 22 gauge and 28 gauge wire)

See you at the Wicked Wire Challenge!!

Prerequisites:  All participants MUST have completed Jewelry 1 and 2, and it's highly recommended that you finish at least TWO (2) wire weaving classes.
how_to_find_us: Across from Stevens Creek Nissan and at the Corner of Stevens Creek & Albany
name: Wicked Wire Challenge - The Butterfly

description:
Potluck dinner, merriment, & frolicking at Twin Lakes State Beach, Santa Cruz.

Party begins at 2:00 pm with potluck dinner at 5:30 pm; bonfire for s’mores at 7:30 pm; party ends when the beach closes at 10:00 pm.

Please bring:

A dinner dish to share
Beach toys and musical instruments
Your friends, kids, and relatives
A flashlight for after dark
Dress in layers because the weather is often cool in the evening.

The Firelight Team provides water and s’mores makings.

This party is a free, special event with no presentations.


Directions: From San Jose, take Highway 17 south to Santa Cruz. Continue past the Highway 1 South exit onto Ocean Street. Follow the signs to the Ocean St. beaches, continuing past several stoplights to the end of Ocean (stop light). Turn left on E. Cliff Drive; the street name changes to Murray and then Eaton after you cross the bridge. Turn right on 7th Avenue (stop light). At the next stop sign, you can see the beach. Turn left at the stop sign, pull over, and drop off people and belongings. Look for the HAI signs and tables on the beach. Parking: Finding parking can be challenging. Check for street parking on both sides of 7th Ave. and nearby. Parking is $8 before 5 pm and free thereafter. Questions: Contact Greg Nelson at [masked] or [masked]
name: Beach Bonfire Potluck Party

description:
Merhaba,

Let's get this Turkish party started right! I'm talking wine, I'm talking cheese, and I'm talking talking Turkish -- we will also have some English practice for our Turkish friends who would like to practice that.

The main thing is to have fun and get to know other Turkish-interested people in the Bay Area.

WHAT: Potluck picnic of fine wines and cheese - bring some for yourself and more to share with others (other tasty snacks and beverages, of course, more than welcome to our soiree!)

WHERE: In Gabrielson Park, a gorgeous park in Sausalito with views of the bay and city. Just hop off the SF ferry and you are right there.

HOW: Take the 1:25 ferry from San Francisco to arrive at 1:55 right next to the park. Full schedule here:  http://www.goldengateferry.org/schedules/Sausalito.php   - or drive, or take a bus, which runs frequently and passes through the city on the way to Sausalito. To find best route type in your address here:  http://tripplanner.transit.511.org/

WHY: Because Turkish people and people who study the Turkish language are simply awesome.

I'll arrange for the first hour to be a Turkish language practice hour - native speaker volunteers please help us! Then after it will be both languages, and an opportunity for those who want to practice there English. All levels of Turkish and English welcome.

Görüşürüz!


Rachel
how_to_find_us: Look for Rachel at one of the two picnic tables at the park
name: Wine & Cheese Picnic in Sausalito

description:
S'more vegan s'mores anyone?  Join us for our annual fun-filled day at Seabright/Castle Beach in Santa Cruz, complete with vegan potluck and nighttime bonfire! Michelle will arrive early in the AM in order to score a fire pit (they're limited). You can arrive anytime after 10am, but the main party will run from 2:00pm to 10:00pm.

For those who may wonder what exactly to bring to a vegan potluck - there are many options, with the following exceptions :-) Please nothing with animal derived products including eggs, dairy, honey, cheese, and fish.  If you're unsure you can ask me and/or read labels because they even sneak dairy into things like some dark chocolates :-( and/or check out this website:  http://www.santacruzanimalrights.org/WhatsVegan.  If you can, please bring your own reusable plate/silverware/cup, though we will have some back-ups.

Some items we will need:  It will be great if someone can bring an umbrella or some type of shade structure, a folding table, some wood to burn, and vegan items for s'mores, including spikes for roasting marshmallow, i.e. wire hangers.  *Note: vegan marshmallows and chocolates are readily available, however, graham crackers without honey are not so easy.  That's where creativity and/or determination come in if anyone's so inclined.  Also, if anyone has a portable vegan barbeque pit...  You may inform others of what you plan to bring in the discussion section below.

Feel free to bring frisbees, kites, guitars or any other beach activities you enjoy. Bring whatever you need for your own comfort: chairs, towels, sunscreen, water, and warm jackets because it can get cold.  

Note that alcohol is prohibited on this beach.  Dogs are allowed as long as they're on leashes.

We'll be at Seabright/Castle beach, across the street from the Museum of Natural History and just west of Seabright Avenue.  See map at http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=&geocode=&q=santa+cruz+museum+of+natural+history&sll=36.964449,-122.007616&sspn=0.006498,0.01929&ie=UTF8&cd=1&hq=santa+cr...

Please let me know if you have any suggestions or questions!

description:
This is a meeting of the Bay Area Humanists. What then is a Humanist, and what is the Philosophy of Humanism? Martin Squibbs will lead a discussion exploring these questions :-


1)  What are universal Humanistic values? Do such values exist and where do they come from?

2)  How do we apply our values? Can our values be resolved into future goals for humanity – ie visions, missions, and objectives for Human Kind?

-  How do we assess the current/immediate versus future costs and benefits of our actions to ourselves and others? (and to what extent should “others” include other sentient beings).

-  How do we measure and judge the emotional costs and benefits versus the material costs and benefits of our actions?

3)  Can Science define what is right or wrong, moral or immoral, and good or bad? (ie Science informs us how to shape reality according to our wishes, but can it tell us what we should wish, and when, and why?).

4)  Can religious people (ie people with spiritual and/or supernatural beliefs) share our values and future goals and/or be Humanists and/or can we work with them to further our common Earthy visions for humanity.

After the discussion we will go to a nearby restaurant for dinner.

Martin was born in the UK, living in Wales and England and gaining a Masters in Business and EE from Imperial College, London. He moved to San Jose, California, in 1994, and has spend the last 19 years living in San Jose and working for Atmel, a semi-conductor company, in engineering, marketing and business development roles. Since the late 90’s he has been involved with the Humanist Community in Silicon Valley, currently holding the position of Vice President of the Board, and aside from Humanism, is interested in Neuroscience and the Mind, our environment, macro-economics and social justice.

If you want to find out more about the Bay Area Humanists check out our website or Facebook page.  If you have questions, e-mail us.

Come join us as we kick off our HOT AUGUST NIGHTS KARAOKE with a special fundraiser to support our Member KJ Vera whose son Angelo Buzz was killed tragically in a motorcycle accident with semi truck in June.  The fundraiser is to help KJ Vera and Angelo's surviving children with funeral and other expenses.

La Playa Bonita (formerly the Creekside) has offered to host the fundraiser.  KJ Vera is organizing it with them and more details will be provided later as we get additional information.  Here is what we know so far:

* There will be a $10.00 cover charge at the door of which we understand 100% will be going to KJ Vera directly.

* This event will run from 4:00pm - 1:00am. This is an adult function with a KJ for karaoke, a DJ for Angelo's favorite music and a live band for your dancing pleasure.

* There will be a HUGE raffle, t-shirt & cd sales throughout the night.

*  Karaoke will be held from 4 pm to 7 p.m. with a KJ/DJ tba.   After 7:00 p.m. there will be live music and dancing. For now, I am scheduling this meetup to start at 4:00 p.m.  I will update as I get new info.

Please come support our Member KJ Vera Contreras and her family during this difficult time.   

Hope you can make it.

description:
THIS EVENT IS FOR CRAFTING QUEENS ONLY. It is a home event.

"The best portion of a good man's life is his little, nameless, unremembered acts of kindness and of love." - William Wordsworth

Use your creativity to support deployed military women and men by crafting Holiday (Christmas, Kwanzaa, Hanukkah, generic holiday) greeting cards they can share with their loved ones at home through Operation Write Home. 

Please bring your own supplies. We'll use the beginning portion (or all) of our time crafting the cards. Whatever remaining time left, you're welcome to work on your own projects. 

You are welcome to bring completed cards with you or create them while we're together. 

Familiarize yourself with the Operation Write Home Guidelines.

1. NO GLITTER! Really!

2. A2 sized cards only, 4.25″ x 5.5″. Envelopes will be available at the event.

3. Line the inside of your cards if your cards are made with dark card stock. If pencil isn't easily visible, then line the inside. I usually use copy paper.

4. Because we're crafting these cards at least 4 weeks before the holiday deadline, we are welcome to make multiples of the same card design.

5. Use quality supplies. Make sure your cards can withstand the rigors of shipping overseas and back again. Please remember that the card you make could be a family’s last contact with their hero. Use good cardstock and adhesive, make sure it will stay together, and produce your best work!

Be cautious of embellishments that might fall off. Avoid "post card" style cards or fancy-fold cards with nowhere to write. No flimsy card bases (copier paper or lightweight patterned paper). 

6. Some dimension is ok, but don't go wild.

7. Card themes.
Remember who’s sending these cards: adults. Please do not send cards with sentiments “to” Daddy or Mommy, no “wish you were here,” or party invitations; and no explicit images or sentiments out of respect for cultures and sensitivities. Halloween cards should be cheerful ones, not scary – lest a card with a skull end up as the final communication by a fallen hero. The best cards for our heroes’ use are actually designs that can be sent at any time of year – they can customize them for any occasion by writing their note inside. NO get well, sympathy, anniversary, or other specific themes are needed, please! See a list of themes here.

No inappropriate themes (new baby announcement, party invite, cards for daddy or mommy, welcome to the neighborhood, etc).

8. Absolutely NO storebought cards.

9. For our event, no photo cards.

10. NO handwritten sentiments.

Christmas stamps will be avaible at the table. But, you are welcome to bring your own.

OWH has a special stamp for us to use on the back of the cards. This stamp will be at the table. We will all be sure to stamp our own cards before turning them in. Sam will collect the cards when you're done.

Just for fun... Come dressed in some holiday cheer (whatever that means to you).

Food & Drinks

We will order out for dinner. Please bring cash (small denominations) to pitch in for food. If you have a craving, suggest it in the comment section.

Water, Coffee, Tea will be provided. If you have any specific drink you prefer, please bring.

Dessert will be provided.

Reminders:

ACT Membership dues, if not payed yet, is $10 (Paid to Juliana. 1 time a year). Cash only. Exact value appreciated.

Please keep your RSVP updated. *If there are no more spots, please join the wait list. As space opens up, you'll be moved into a YES spot. Return tothe event page often to double check your RSVP as I do not believe Meetup sends automated notifications. (If you are moved into a YES spot but didn't realize and don't show up, it will count against you as it's holding a spot someone else could have.)
name: Philanthropic Crafting: Cards for Operation Write Home {HOME}

description:
Carpe Noctem: Seize the Night . . . Spooky San Francisco Ghetto Night Ride

Our signature ride :-)   We’ll be riding the hills, peaks and valleys of everyone's favorite city. We’ll zip through the ghettos, pass the mansions and view the scenery very few people get to see in a week let alone in a single evening.

This ride is generally within posted speed limits, but the route is highly technical, scary, spooky, challenging and -- at the same time – exhilarating, breathtaking and absolutely positively fun.

We'll make a few rest and coffee breaks, but not long enough for a big meal, just what you can find at Starbucks ;~)

|||   Space is limited - RSVP ASAP - Not for newbies or for the faint of heart  |||

• For meal, arrive by 4:30 PM  <click - for your eyes only>  Bring ID to get in.

• For ride only, arrive by 5:30 PM, KSU 5:45 PM

(ride ends around midnight, or whenever we get sleepy.  There are breakaway points for those who need to get home early to relief the babysitter). 

/<a>\/\/\/\</a> No official pre-ride this time.  Let's just meet in SF.  Remember to fill up or have enough gas for 60 miles <a>\/\/\/\</a>/

</a>

Our Last Rides: 

http://youtu.be/IGYMlhW50M0

  

• Tentative Stops:

If you get separated from the group, don’t worry. Just go straight to the next REST STOP.You may get there before us if you take a straight route. Be sure to text me to let me know.

1. Twin Peaks <a href="http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&source=s_d&saddr=37.754769,-122.446532&daddr=&hl=en&geocode=&mra=mift&mrsp=0&sz=18&sll=37.754587,-122.447187&sspn=0.002231,0.00618&ie=UTF8&t=h&z=18" target="_blank">(map) only if not too crowded and if  not foggy

2. Safeway (5290 Diamond Heights Blvd) 30 min - Starbucks & Restrooms inside

3. Golden Gate Park (John F Kenedy Dr. & 36th) restroom break

4. SF Legion of Honor (34th Ave & El Camino Del Mar) 15 min/photo op

5. Starbucks Laurel Hts (California & Spruce - rear parking lot)  30 min for coffee/rest

6. End of Van Ness near wharf (map) 15 min

7. Coit Tower - may be and only if there's parking

8. City Hall - end of the ride (what more do you want )

Tentative Route -

__________________________________________

How Many Bikes - How Many People? To keep the size of the group manageable, we’ll limit the number of bikes.  MeetUp system doesn’t distinguish between # of bikes and # of people.  Therefore, if you have a passenger simply indicate it in the comment section, and show only count of “1” in your RSVP for your bike.  If you wish to invite a riding buddy with own bike, please have them join and RSVP.

Dinner & Ride or Just Ride? In your RSVP, please state if you are joining us for dinner as well, or only the ride.  This way I know how many seats we'll need.

• Pace:  Not too slow.  Not too fast.  Just right.

• Gear: Head to toe.  It may be cold in May, so wear layers.

• Motorcycle: Yes, please bring one with you ;-)


~ Please review Liability Release statement at THIS LINK

~ Proper gear, a working machine and gas in the tank is highly recommended.
~ Ride within your comfort zone and leave room for bad karma.
~ I may pass slower traffic when it's safe. You don't have to. Remember, someone will wait for you at turns, so just relax and have fun.
~ I maintain the Pace according to road conditions with safety of all riders in mind. Be mindful of others in the group. Let faster riders get ahead of you by moving to the right and signaling them to pass you. And if you want to pass the rider(s) who are in front of you, make sure to do so safely and without startling them.
~ If you know the area and would like to sweep for the group please let me know.
~ Good stuff to read before going on group rides (CLICK).
~ Keep an eye for the rider(s) behind you so they won't take a wrong turn. If they get lost, you'll buy their dinner
~ City riding means traffic lights, stop signs and of course other vehicles.  Below is an exaggerated case, but it illustrates that getting separated doesn't mean getting lost. BLUE dots are riders going from A to G points of a route. RED dots are the riders who have stopped and are waiting for the rider behind them.  When stopping at a turn for a rider who is behind you, wait "before" the turn so they see you.  Not "after" or "in" the turn, because by the time they realize you have turned, they have missed the turn, or they may not even see you at all.  If you approach a rider who is waiting for you, but you don't see the rider behind you, please stop at the same stop so the one waiting can go while you wait for the rest to arrive. REMEMBER, WE ALL WAIT .... ALL EXCEPT THE SWEEP SINCE HE IS THE LAST ONE

Frequent Pauses:

As you can see, we'll have a large size group (20+ bikes). So, just like a Caterpillar, the “Head“ section will have to wait for the “Tail” to arrive. Therefore, there will be frequent “pauses” to make sure the chain is not broken and that we have riders who are “marking” the turns for people behind them. We need a few volunteers …. 1 for sweep, of course. Plus 2 more “advanced” riders who will help with a smooth flow. Please email me if you feel comfortable helping out. .

Tight Group:

We need to zip thru traffic lights and stop signs in as many at a time as possible.  Ride staggered, and if we do come to a stop, feel free to fill all lanes that we can take so as soon as light turns green a whole bunch of us can pass before it turns red again.  Picture below shows how to keep a tight group(distance from riders ahead of you) but only on straights and flat sections with good view.   When on crooked streets, uphills or down hills, ride single file 2-3 seconds apart.  Remember, 2-3 seconds means the distance from rider in front or behind you will vary according to the speed at the time.  Please don't tailgate or crowd the rider in front of you.  But if you see you are getting far from the rider in front, and the bikes behind you are on your tail, it means you'll be more comfortable riding closer to the tail end of the group which is normally slower.  When it's safe, move to the right and signal them to pass you.  And if you want to pass a slower rider, make sure to do so safely.

If you feel uncomfortable for any reason make sure to chat with Mehran or the sweep at the next stop so we can figure out how best to assist the situation.

Down Hills:

SF Hills (going down) can be intimidating.  Downshift (2nd gear, or even 1st if you like) and lean back a little.  Cover front brakes.  If you are comfortable with "trail braking", cover the rear brake also, but DON'T lock the rear wheel.  Just a gentle tap on the pedal.  Prepare for sudden stops by the rider ahead of you.  LEAVE 2-3 seconds distance.

Going up hills is the same principal.  Shift weight forward and lean on the tank.

.. and of course the cardinal rule of watching out for the riders behind you.  Everyone must keep an eye for the rider behind them.  The only one who is exempt is the sweep, and that's because he is the last rider

Check out GRF Boutique !!
name: Carpe Noctem:  Spooky SF Ghetto Night Ride, Sat 8/2/14

description:
As most FCF members already know, the Emerald City Supporters and our ECS regional subgroup the Fog City Faithful are Boycotting the Saturday, August 2nd 7:30 pm Quakes game vs. Seattle taking place at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara.


(For background on #AwayRobbery, read more here:  

http://www.sounderatheart.com/2014/3/24/5542138/away-robbery-symbolizes-shift-in-sports-consumption-of-younger-fans

and also here:
https://www.weareecs.com/phpBB/viewtopic.php?f=60&t=24045 )

That DOESN'T mean we won't be supporting the Team that day!  

We cordially invite all FCF Members and Friends to join us in Mountain View at Stephen's Green, 223 Castro St., Mtn. View  (just a block away from Caltrain) for a Gala Celebration of the Sounders as they show the Quakes' Management and Fans what a First Place team looks like up close and in person!

We are encouraging our San Francisco based FCF members to carpool or take Caltrain down to Mountain View for a special Gala Viewing Party!  We'll have some fun, sing some songs, and cheer the team on to another road victory!


First Beer is on us!  We'll be on site from 6:30 pm forward.

We know that passing on the only NorCal visit by the Sounders in 2014 is a hardship, but we want to be sure the Quakes management knows by our Conspicuous Absence of a traveling ECS section (no Capos, no flags, no drums, no two-poles) that we expect and deserve fair and reasonable Ticket Pricing for traveling supporters in 2015 when the Quakes open their new stadium near the San Jose Airport.

We look forward to welcoming ECS back in 2015, and we welcome all FCF members to join us in Mountain View on August 2nd for a very special Viewing Party!

Please wear your Sounders jersey and bring your scarf for a photo!
how_to_find_us: Wearing the Rave Green, of course!
name: Gala Sounders vs. Quakes Viewing Party - Mtn. View

description:
6:30 Singing, 7:45 Meditation 8:00 Potluck

*Please note that doors close at 7:15

            Singing *** Meditation***Potluck 

Kirtan is an ancient participatory music experience. Without the work of mentally quieting the mind, kirtan can carry us effortlessly to a place of quiet, to stillness. One of the oldest sacred music traditions of the world, the kirtan call-and-response chanting genre comes to us from India. Using ancient Sanskrit mantras, the kirtan calls upon sacred energies which serve to quiet the mind, remove obstacles to meditation. Singing traditional Sanskrit mantras has a profound effect on the environment and consciousness, helping to elevate the mind, heal the body, and open the heart. No experience is necessary.

 

"Satsang is the shelter from the changing time and its harsh influence on life" 
Sri Sri Ravi Shankar

 

This event is sponsored by the Art of Living Foundation
name: Kirtan, Meditation & Veggie Potluck

description:
In 2005 an independent worker in California conceived of a different way of working; he envisioned a place where independent workers could come together, collaborate and reap the rewards of community, increased productivity and creativity. That worker was Brad Neuberg and the word he used to describe his vision was coworking, and he was a cofounder of Citizen Space, arguably the worlds first Coworking Space. On August 9th, approximately 5000 coworking spaces around the world will celebrate Neuberg’s vision as part of International Coworking Day.

Join us, and celebrate 9 years of collaboration, and the shared economy!


The week of events hosted at Citizen Space for Coworking Week 2014: 


UX Day- Presented by: Lean UX SF Meet Up & UX Rex- Class from General Assembly: Mobile UX Fundamentals Growth 

Hacker Day- Presented by: @Oreilly - Class from General Assembly: Digital Marketing: Key Concepts and Metrics 

Maker Camp- Presented by: Arrow Electronics -Hands on Arduino Class by SF Wearables- Purchase a kit, or see the list of supplies. 

Colearning Day- Free Classes all day, all over the bay area. Presented by: @General Assembly & Colearn
- An Introduction to UX
- HTML/CSS (Web Dev Let's break it down) 

Pitch Club 5- Presented by @MingleMedia http://www.pitchclubsf.com

Sharing Economy Hackathon- Presented by: @Lockitron

Coworking Unconference- Presented by: @Shareable 

Get 50% off tickets:  https://coworkingweek2014.eventbrite.com/?discount=startupaddicts

If you are interested in participating as a partner, speaker, press, or sponsor, please email us: [masked] or call us M-F from 9AM-6PM at [masked]

Not in SF? Organize and host your own Coworking Week event!
name: Coworking Week 2014

"Usagi Tsukino is a little clumsy and a crybaby, but she's also one spirited eighth grader.

"One day she meets Luna, a black cat with a crescent moon mark on her forehead, and transforms into the pretty guardian of love and justice in a sailor suit, Sailor Moon! As a chosen guardian of justice, Usagi apparently has a mission to protect a princess, and to find her fellow Guardians and the phantom Silver Crystal.

They cause strange events to occur there, all in an effort to acquire the tremendously powerful Silver Crystal...Can Sailor Moon and the other Guardians successfully find the phantom crystal, and protect the princess...!?"

description:
An Ecstatic Dance journey through the elements of
 Air, Fire, Water, Earth and back to our Center.

Every 1st and 3rd Saturdays of the month, from 8pm - 11pm, in Los Gatos.

Dance Elemental offers a unique expression of ecstatic dance culture, inspired by nature-centered traditions. Music is selected to take you on a journey through the four elements that leads you back to your center (Spirit). This sacred container is created for authentic self expression through dance, meditation in motion, deep play, spiritual centering and community.  Allow your True Self to be revealed! 

When?  
Monthly on 1st and 3rd Saturdays
8pm - 11pm 
(Registration opens at 7:30)

Where? 
Los Gatos Acupuncture and Qigong Center 
761 University Ave - Suite A 
Los Gatos, CA 95032

Suggested Donations:


$15 - Individual Adult admit at the door.
$5  - Teens 16 - 19
(Children 15-and-under come FREE.)
*Minors must be accompanied by an Adult*


Pre-register online and save a buck.  
Sign up now for $14

Or sign up early with a friend and get a sweet deal! 
Check out our Dance Duo! Two admitted for $25 (when purchased in advance). 

http://devagnosis.eventbrite.com/


++Volunteer/Trade opportunities available.  Contact the organizers in advance.

Need More info? Cool... keep reading.  

Basic structure: A large and beautiful sacred space for free-form dancing to amazing music in a loving community environment. 

* Be moved by Live DJ with Live Drumming and Improvisational music too! 

* Bring your heart-felt intention and dance it into being. You are welcome to bring a token to represent your intention if you so desire, and place it on the Community Altar as we journey together.

* Areas are set up for meditation, energy/body work, and community networking. Healthy snacks, tea and water are provided. We invite volunteer Reiki healers and other energy/body workers to attend the healing areas.

* Yoga Mats / Back Jacks / Chairs available. Feel free to bring your own yoga mats for stretching or lying down.

* All ages welcome! Young children should be supervised by parents/guardians.

* New-comers welcome and encouraged!
If this is your first Dance with us, we strongly encourage you to arrive by no later than 8:00 p.m. sharp for a helpful and brief orientation.  This really helps to get everyone clear about how we can participate fully and have the best time possible at our dance.


* Important Guidelines and Tips * 

1. We kindly ask for a Talk-Free dance floor.
This allows for people to go deeper into their Dance and connect with their journey through the Elements. (Chat and conversation is welcome in the tea room, outside, or very quietly just off the dance floor in the "Chill out zone".) 

2. Dance however you want. There is no right or wrong way. Listen to your body and move to the way it feels. Express who you are from the inside out. 

3. Respect yourself as well as those around you. Pay attention to your boundaries and the boundaries of others. Communicate through eye contact and body language. Be compassionate and aware. If it becomes necessary to use your words, please feel free to do so in a respectful way.
Many participants find meaningful interactions on the dance floor which both surprise and delight.

4. Bring extra water - Mainly recommended for those who get very thirsty while exercising, or have a cold. 

5. Wear clothes that make you feel good and are comfortable for dancing. Be expressive and colorful if you like, or just show up in your sweats. It's all good! Dancing barefoot or in socks is fine. Shoes are ok, but heavy tread shoes or heals are not allowed. Most dance shoes or slippers are great. 

6. We are a clean and sober venue.  No drugs or alcohol, period.

7. Please, do not bring cameras to the event.  Personal photo/video without express permission (from subjects and the organizers alike) is not allowed.
This guideline is for everyone's assurance of privacy and feeling of safety.

8. ALL ages and genders are welcome. 

9. Be yourself! 


* Even MORE about the Dance *  
~ IF YOU HAVE NEVER ATTENDED BEFORE... Please take a few minutes to read the rest. ~

We welcome all to the Dance.  Open your heart, and dissolve any blocks of judgment and fear.  Come, move your body and soul to a handpicked mix of music: inspirational, uplifting, world beat, tribal, funk, pop, electronica, trance, ambient and much more.  Live improvisational music and inspired guided meditations set to music are often part of the evening to transition us from element to element, focusing intention as we journey together through the experience.

As we dance, we can reintegrate and refuel ourselves through communion with the Elements of Air, Fire, Water, and Earth, naturally leading us back to the center of our being.  Each Element can be treated as an initiation into a spiritual journey, each one having a unique resonance within us. This practice is designed to propel us towards greater integration between our bodies and higher consciousness, as well as our community.
As a community, we recognize that we can learn and grow by witnessing and supporting one another through our shared expressions of each elemental energy.  Let's work those edges together, and return ourselves to a life of deep trusting.
Rediscover and liberate your heart of hearts together through dance!


* What to expect when you arrive * 

Arrive to soft music. Check in first, and then quietly find a place for your things. You may choose to be welcomed with a cleansing/smudge (smoke-free mist). Relax, breathe and stretch as others arrive. 

We will be called together for a welcoming circle, speaking of our names, brief orientation, and grounding meditation. Then the dancing starts. 

There are several "stations" throughout the venue to help you with being present during the Dance. 

1. Drumming: 
There are an assortment of drums/shakers available for you to play. You may borrow available instruments or bring your own. (Remember to remove rings/bracelets.) Please attend children. The goal is to support the dancers by adding to the energy of the music. Sensitivity and awareness is key to holding the energy in the room...
If you are new to drumming, please ask for guidance.  We are happy to provide this as a growth opportunity and chance to try this form of expression in alignment with the Dance.  [DevaGnosis also holds monthly Drum Circles for further exploration.]

2. "Tea" Room: 
Need a refresher? We have a lovely table with healthy snacks to help re-energize and 'ground' you.  A great place to chat as well. 

3. Chill out zone: 
Need to be still for awhile? This is a cozy space set aside for meditation/stillness. 

4. Healing: 
Feeling tapped? Reiki Practitioners and experienced Energy and Body Workers from within our community are often available to offer their care to re-energize and align the participants.  LGAQ has a few private offices set up for our use during the evening.
If you are a practitioner willing to offer service, please contact an organizer for further details.  (What a great way to highlight your personal practice.)

5. Community Altar: 
This is a space for you to focus your energy and intention or to draw inspiration from during the dance. You may bring something to place on or near the altar if you feel called to do so. 

6. Community networking area: 
This surface is set up near the entrance so that we can get to know one another better. Bring your business cards and brochures, event flyers, freebies, etc. 
Please take a moment to look through the materials during the evening and collect anything of interest. Seek and ye shall find. 


* Closing Process* 

At the end of the night, we usually end with a simple Heart Sharing with a few words spoken by those who wish to speak about what they experienced and any gratitudes, etc. There is also time allowed for community announcements before we part.

Remember, you are free to bring flyers for your events/services and put them on the community networking table as well. 


http://devagnosis.eventbrite.com/

"Dance Elemental" TM - DevaGnosis 2008

description:
The Tour de Peninsula is coming up again. August 4th at Coyote Point. Those that have done this ride will know it offers great value for the $45 entry fee ($50 after July 1). A lot of families participate together, some people don't wear lycra and there are almost none of the weekend racer types.

http://supportparks.org/tdp/event.html


Route options include 20 miles, 31 miles, 56 and 63 miles. All routes include the great Sawyer Camp Trail alongside Crystal Springs Reservoir. The start/finish venue is Coyote Point Park, which is a warm, sunny, bayside location shaded by big eucalyptus trees.

Meetup members usually ride at their own pace and then meet for a post-ride lunch and story-sharing at a picnic table in the finish area. Rides begin at 7 a.m. and 8 a.m. depending on the route option.

description:
Join us for a half day climb up Mt. Tamalpais in support of At The Crossroads (ATC), a local non-profit that empowers homeless youth. The full hike is about 8 miles, and will probably take 4 to 5 hours round trip. If you haven't been to Mt. Tam, it's a mellow hike with gorgeous views. It's definitely one of those refreshing places that make you fall in love with life again. Since the hike is a fundraiser for ATC, they request that you register for $20 here (http://atthecrossroads.org/summersunday/index.php). You can also fundraise if you'd like but that's entirely up to you. ATC is offering van pools so we can hitch a ride from their office. Vans leave at 7:45am so please don't be late or you'll seriously be left behind :)

Post up with questions, cheers to working out for a cause!
name: Hike for a Cause at Mt. Tam

description:
If anyone is interested in doing a photowalk on street art, Flickr is hosting a worldwide photowalk event on August 3rd. Let's go out and shoot around the Mission District's famous street art! We had fun the last time around and I know there are members out there who would love to check out the colorful alleys!

Exercise your street photography skills. Capture textures, details and develop your "eye". While shooting solo has it's rewards, a small group walking close together provides safety in numbers, particularly in some parts of the urban landscape. 

We will meet at a predetermined location that I will send to those on the final RSVP list. I will be at the location before 7:30 AM. We will do a quick meet and greet, go over some basics then start our hike. Be ready for an easy walk of about 2 miles on flat grade. This will be done during the early morning to make the most of the light, avoid the heat and we will be winding our way along some alleyways to capture street art. At the end of the walk, we can stop for coffee and pastries.

Things to bring(recommended):

Camera, one lens (fixed or zoom)

Memory cards

extra battery

Pack light and bring some water for hydration

Walking shoes and comfortable clothing

No tripods are needed so you can leave them home.

I will be sending out an email to those attending a few days before the actual event with the final location.

description:
This Hike Starts at 8 :30 am from GPS address 560 Hemme Ave. in Alamo !  The first Half of this hike is on wide open fire trail and the rest is on neighborhood streets and the Iron Horse paved pathway.

          But this hike is no cake walk! Compare this to the upper Rim Trail at the Lafayette Reservoir for difficulty and approx. duration !

      The Route is : Ringtail Cat Trail to the Madrone Trail and on the to neighborhoods of Camille Lane and the Iron Horse trail to finish in a little over 2 hours and 4 Miles round trip.  This Hike is not rated for beginning hikers - please look to our calendar of events for more suitable hikes and for the respect of other hikers please hike within your means . The average speed of our hikes is 2  1/2 mph and the group as whole effort decide the pace . We are a hiking group and strive to keep together so we don't lose anyone !

     NOTES  : The organizers wish to remind all attendees to wear sturdy hiking footwear and bring plenty of drinking water, maybe a trail snack, for the 2 hour hike . Well behaved DOGS ARE WELCOME on this event and must be leashed in the parking areas and surrounding neighborhoods. Off leash on the trails is O K .

     NOTE : Parking is in a neighborhood and will best serve each of us to arrive early for best selection !

description:
I have a free Sunday the first weekend in August so am offering another weekend Gear Knots and Anchors class. If there is more interest in my Trad Follower class I would be willing to teach that class instead.

Please make sure to read all details below. Location of class will be texted to the group once everyone has had a chance to RSVP. • Do you want to climb more often, but don’t know how to build safe climbing anchors yourself?
• Are you interested in joining a climbing group outing, but don’t know who knows how to build safe climbing anchors and who doesn’t?
• Have you ever risked climbing on somebody else’s anchors without knowing whether they are safe or not first?
• Are you lacking the knowledge needed to assess a climbing anchor before trusting it with your life?
• Do you want to gain the knowledge and skills to build safe climbing anchors yourself?

If you answered yes to any of the above questions, then this could be the class for you.

Note: no climbing class will give you the instant ability to build safe climbing anchors. This requires time, careful study, practice and hands on experience preferably under the watchful eye of an experienced and competent anchor builder. This class will not make you an expert anchor builder overnight, but it will teach you the basic skills and knowledge necessary to be able to assess other people’s climbing anchors and give you the skills you need to start becoming proficient in building your own anchors.

Confirmation for class: please send me your cell # through my profile in case something happens last minute or you have trouble finding us the day of the class. I will text you confirmation once I receive your email. My text is your confirmation you are rsvp'd for the class and I will update your confirmation accordingly

Climbing Gear, Knots and Anchors class

Class is taught by an AMGA trained instructor with 10+ years of experience teaching technical skills and systems used for rock climbing.

Learn how to assess a climbing anchor before you climb on it and how to build safe climbing anchors yourself

1) Gear

a) typical gear used in climbing anchors

i) Hard gear i) Bolts and bolt hangers ii) Locking carabiners iii) Non-locking carabiners

ii) Soft gear i) Cordelette ii) Sewn slings iii) Webbing iv) Static cord

b) Proper handling of gear. Learn how to handle gear properly so you never drop anything. This can get costly $$$.

2) Knots – primary knots used in climbing anchors and simple ways to learn them and dress them properly a) Overhand knot (for learning purposes only, not to be used in climbing) b) Double overhand knot – easy way to tie it c) Triple overhand knot d) Overhand on a bight e) Fisherman’s knot (for learning purposes only, not to be used in climbing) f) Double fisherman's knot g) Triple fisherman’s knot h) Figure eight on a bight i) Water knot (the better way)

3) Other frequently used knots: a) Figure eight follow through (the better way) with Yosemite finish b) Clove hitch (how to tie one-handed) c) Girth hitch d) Autoblock hitch e) Prusik hitch

4) Difference between a hitch and a knot

5) Physics, vectors and angular forces

6) SERENE anchors (some may be familiar with acronyms SRENE and EARNEST)

7) Basic anchor scenarios (bolted anchors) a) Two piece anchors at same height b) Two piece anchors at different height c) Three piece anchors

8) Advanced anchor scenarios (as time permits) a) “Trad” anchors using passive and active protection (nuts, hexes, cams)

9) Natural anchors (as time permits) a) Trees b) Blocks c) Horns d) Pinch offs e) Chockstones f) Slots

Recommended personal gear:

No personal gear is required, but if you have gear that you would like to bring and learn how to use then feel free to bring it. Please check your gear with Stan before the start of the class. If you don't have gear yet, but want to get some then this class will help you figure out what gear you need to practice and build your own anchors.


A harness is highly recommended. A notepad for writing down notes is a good idea. There will be a lot of information to learn so notes will be a good idea for when you practice your knots and anchors at home.

A folding lawn chair is welcome during the lecture portion of the class.

All other gear will be provided.

Classes are usually taught in a park in Alameda. Other locations can be negotiated by request for groups.


Class size: minimum 4, maximum 8 (more possible by request and at instructor's discretion)

Time for class: this is an all-day class that usually runs 6+ hours depending on the overall learning ability of the group. Because this is a fairly long class you should bring some water and food to snack on.

Cost: $40

Rain cancels class.

Confirmation for class: please send me your cell # and email address through my profile in case something happens and I need to contact you or vice versa . I will text you confirmation once I receive your email. My text is your confirmation you are rsvp'd for the class and I will update your confirmation accordingly

Note: prior students who have already taken my class in the past are welcome to take it again at no charge. If the class is full new students have priority, but should not be a problem accommodating you if notified in advance.
name: Gear Knots and Anchors class

description:
Enjoy fresh air and the view of rolling hills in Foothill Park. Description in English and Mandarin is below (以下先用英文再用中文解说）


We meet at the center of the park, a slightly raised area (about 100 steps from park entrance, see picture below).

In case it's raining or very windy, we'll meet at the patio (from the center of the park, turn left, cross basketball court, you'll see the blue colored patio).

We start with basic postures and will incorporate advanced techniques gradually.

The fun exercise consists of the following sections:

• Wild Goose Postures

• Dragon Postures (front/back, left/right, turn one section, combination 1, combination 2)

• Healing Qigong (also called Inhale, Inhale, Exhale Breathing Exercise)

• Wellness Exercise which includes:

1) Standing Posture;

2) Breathing in Good Energy (breathe six times into each of the six locations: middle of eyebrow, adam's apple, breast, belly button, below belly button, bottom of upper body);

3) Shaking Off Bad Energy;

4) Massage Exercise (shoulder, arms, front/side/back body, legs, knees, ankles);

5) Ending Exercise (massage face, head, ears, bottom of neck, turn head, deep breathing).

Yoga Exercise

All experience levels are welcome. Practice qigong and yoga to start a great day!

description:
Weekend Itsy Bitsy Yoga Class: This will be a mixed age yoga class and we shall offer it the first (Non Holiday) Sunday of each month.

Calling all newborns to crawlers, Itsy Bitsy Yoga has been shown to help with a baby’s circulation, sleep, muscle & brain development and is a great bonding time! Drop in Class: $10.00; 3 class package for $25.00; OHM members get an additional FREE Class!

WHAT: Baby Itsy Bitsy Yoga classes contain dozens of unique yoga postures designed to support baby’s development. Each class is filled with calming, nurturing ways to enhance bonding and improve baby’s sleep.

During a Baby Itsy Bitsy Yoga class, babies enjoy yoga while on their backs, tummies, or held in loving arms. For parents, this class is a special opportunity to meet other moms, get support, and learn about baby's emerging personality. Most of the yoga we do in Itsy Bitsy Yoga is for baby, but you will also learn breathing and relaxation techniques as you practice a bit of yoga yourself. No yoga is experience required

FIRST SUNDAY of each month at 9:30 am-10:15 am in the Sports Basement LOFT

description:
El primer domingo de cada mes a las 10 am nos reunimos en el Tennessee Valley Trailhead de Mill Valley. Es un paseo tranquilo de 3,4 millas de ida y vuelta a la playa. Regresamos al mediodía. Si quieres, trae un bocadillo o algún vino para compartir en la playa. Si el clima no estuviera bien, les enviaré el día anterior el nombre de un restaurante en que podremos reunirnos. ¡Hasta pronto!

Todos los niveles son bienvenidos. Si no conoces este lugar, las direcciones en google está bien -- pero toma en cuenta que necesitas conducir . . . seguir y seguir conduciendo y finalmente vas a llegar al termino de la calle y al principio del sendero. No para cuando encuentres el aviso que dice Tennessee Valley sino que continúa al termino de la calle. Habrá un aviso de cartón, hecho a mano, encima de una de las mesas que dice Caminamos y Hablamos en Español.

Si llegaras tarde, podrías encontrarnos en la playa. El sendero correcto es el sendero que parece la continuación de la calle.

Lo siento pero se prohiben los perros.

The first Sunday of every month at 10 am we meet at the Tennessee Valley Trailhead in Mill Valley. It’s a 3.4 mile relaxing stroll out to the beach and back. You will be back by noon. Bring a snack or wine to share on the beach, if you like. If the weather is not good I will send a note the day before with the name of a local cafe where we can meet.

All levels welcome. If you are unfamiliar with the trailhead, google directions work well -- but know that you just keep driving and driving and driving and then finally you will find the end of the road and the beginning of the trail. Be sure to go all the way to the end of the road, not stop at the sign that says Tennessee Valley. There will be a handmade cardboard sign on top of the table that says Caminamos y Hablamos en Español.

If you arrive late, you can find us on the beach. The correct trail is the one that is the continuation of the road.

Sorry, but dogs are not allowed.
name: "Caminamos y Hablamos en Español"

group.name: Singles near Palo Alto Hiking/Running and Outdoor Meetup

description:
We'll cycle rolling hills with spectacular views of Upper Crystal Springs Reservoir and the Santa Cruz Mts. on scenic Canada Rd.  that is closed to vehicles  for Bicycle Sunday  9-3.  . Our route is an 8 mile out and back with  the option of repeating it for a longer ride of 16. 

We'll briefly stop at mysterious Pulgas Water Temple where you'll learn about the source of its sacred water and how you can help save water during the drought. You'll take home a FREE 5 minute shower timer and low flow showerhead or hose sprayer just for finishing the ride!  (Courtesy of Santa Clara Valley Water District)

Legal Disclaimer and Liability Information:

1. Singles Near Palo Alto Hiking/Running and Outdoor Meetup  is a private group.  Attending events is voluntary by you as a member.  Participation in any activity with this group is at your own risk.

2. Cycling events can be dangerous and pose a risk to other group members and guests.  By participating voluntarily in the group you understand that you are responsible for your own safety.

3. By joining this event with Singles Near Palo Alto Hiking/Running and Outdoor Meetup  you agree to indemnify and hold harmless this group, its organizers, coorganizers, assistant organizers, event hosts, and other members from all claims or liability of every type (including court costs and legal fees) for injury or death to any person or for damage to property, loss of personal property or any other wrongful act arising out of or relating to your participation as a member.  This agreement applies to you and to other persons (as your guests) who may accompany you in these endeavors.

4.You also agree to hold the organizers as well as other group members harmless.  By participating voluntarily in the group, you expressly waive any and all such claims against each and every other member in the group, including without limitation any and all claims against the group organizer, coorganizers, assistant organizers, and event hosts.


 Thank you!  Rayne
name: Cycle for Water  ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~ ~  16 mile social ride

description:
Shooting Victoria: Madness, Mayhem and the Rebirth of the British Monarchy by Paul Thomas Murphy, 512 pages (2012)

This is what happens when none of the other really interesting suggestions on our poll makes a solid third place showing. Shooting Victoria, the organizer's wildcard selection, is on the calendar for August. (Note: Date has been moved from 8/31 to 8/3.)

"Paul Thomas Murphy used to teach “a variety of disciplines” at the University of Colorado, Boulder. I would like to have been taught by him. He’s the most free-spirited of scholars. “Shooting Victoria” rambles uninhibitedly and learnedly through 19th-century history into literature, penology, constitutional theory and even ballistics, stimulating highly topical thoughts along the way."--John Sutherland, The New York Times

http://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/29/books/review/shooting-victoria-by-paul-thomas-murphy.html?pagewanted=1

"Written with as much verve and spirit as the youthful queen herself, this fascinating investigation into the attempted assassinations is a superb exploration into 19th-century construction of monarchy, police procedure and perceptions of madness. Murphy’s infectious energy is a fit tribute to the inexhaustible monarch he paints with such detail and affection." —BBC History Magazine

"Gripping… Shooting Victoria is a teeming discursive pleasure. Murphy’s book is a feat of historical sympathy, shining light on the larger picture of the 19th century and its indestructible queen." —Observer

"Fascinating…Murphy’s impressive work pulls together many strands of legal, social and political history. It is a testament to his talent that these 500 pages left me wanting more "—The Daily Express

"Murphy presents his tale with a superb sense of place, gleaned from many hours poring over maps and census records…in a book for true lovers of the minutiae of the Victorian period "—Sunday Telegraph

And for fun, check out this "Shooting Victoria Tour" on the author's website: http://shootingvictoria.com/

how_to_find_us: Look for us at the back of the cafe. Say thanks to Borderlands for the quiet place to meet by purchasing something from the cafe. No outside food, please.
name: Shooting Victoria: Madness, Mayhem...British Monarchy (Book Discussion)

description: This moderately strenuous 6 mile loop starts and ends at the Stinson Beach fire station. We'll go up the Matt Davis trail to the Coastal trail; these two miles are extremely steep and include many steps. The intersection of the Coastal trail and Willow Camp fire road is a great place for lunch with stunning views of the ocean and Bolinas (fog permitting). From here it's about two miles downhill to Stinson Beach.

Also we try to put people on courts based on level so if you are a beginner thats ok we will try to match you up. We play DOUBLES and to facilitate even play you may get moved to another court.

description:
Let's play bocce and enjoy a potluck brunch at the Marin Bocce Federation in San Rafael! This place is wonderful...you will feel like you stepped into a little corner of Italy...sunshine, Frank Sinatra on the loudspeaker, a little bubbly, and bocce...ahhh!


I have reserved a court from 10am- 1pm. The staff will teach us the rules of the game when we first get started. Please wear soft-soled shoes. We can rotate teams (4 people per team) so folks can play as much or as little as they want.

Please bring a brunch food item to share and whatever you would like to drink (other than champagne and juice). I will provide the champagne, juice, paper plates, napkins, cutlery, and cups.

Cost: $15 includes 3 hours of court rental, champagne, juice, paper products, and tons of fun! Sorry, no refunds.


See you there!

Andrea
how_to_find_us: I'll be waiting at the bocce court
name: Mimosas, Pot Luck Brunch, and Bocce in San Rafael

description:
This is a Monarch butterfly...the only insect to migrate about 2500 miles twice yearly from the northern US to parts of Southern California and Mexico in the winter.  The migration begins in late September but can be earlier or later depending on the weather.  In honor of our hard working butterfly friends, we're making a woven wire butterfly this morning.

The technique we'll be using is wire weaving--techniques that have been honed through courses this summer, so this is the perfect time to elevate your skills to include wired insects!  For this course, designed for the beginning to intermediate jeweler, we'll be making TWO butterflies (one full and one profile).


This is a great project, so get your wires, pliers and BEADS ready for this.  Here's what you'll need to bring

1 Chain Nose Plier

1 Round Nose Plier

1 Flush Cutter

1 Planishing Hammer (Crowned or Domed)

1 Bench Block

18 Gauge wire

24 Gauge wire (can be colored if you want that)

Beads and Crystals

Prerequisites:  All participants MUST have completed Jewelry 1 and 2, and it's highly recommended that you finish at least TWO (2) wire weaving classes in order to take this course.
how_to_find_us: Across from Stevens Creek Nissan and at the Corner of Stevens Creek & Albany
name: Woven Wire - The Butterfly (Class 4)

description:
TO ENTER YOUR DACHSHUND(S) IN THIS RACE, EMAIL DEAN SMITH, [masked] AND PROVIDE NAME, DACHSHUND(S) NAME, AND HE'LL SIGN YOU UP!

Us Cheerleaders will be cheering your dog(s) on!

The highly anticipated 11th Annual Dachshund Derby, The Highway Wiener Nationals, is planned for this year on Sunday, August 3rd, starting at 11:00am (be there by 10:30am).

DACHSHUNDS ONLY will take to the lawn at Palo Alto High School to showcase their speed and race for the title. Our Nathan and Roo have participated in this race, and it was a lot of fun. Nathan has won a heat, but unfortunately at the next race he got so excited he just jumped in the air and twirled! Roo saw something he liked better and ran sideways! Neither one came close to the finish line, but it was very cute to watch. All participants are very gentle with their pups...

If you don't want to enter your Dachshund in this fun, stress-free Dachshund race, bring your Dachshund(s) to watch the races - it's a real hoot.

This FREE, Dachshund ONLY, 10th annual race will have 1st, 2nd, and 3rd prizes! Bring a little money to purchase an Event T-Shirt! Last year all Event participants got a free T-Shirt - hope that's true for this year too!
name: Annual Dachshund Derby in Palo Alto!

description:
These pics are very typical of what you'll see on this ride.

Naturally there will be some vino stops.

This will be a beautiful ride through three of the premier wine growing regions of Sonoma County.  There's really no time here when the scenery is not gorgeous!

 

The Plan: 

We'll ride over Chalk Hill Rd into Alexander Valley, where we'll stop for a snack and do some tasting at one of the wineries.

Then we'll ride over to Dry Creek Valley, making a stop at one of my favourite wineries (no, I'm not telling) where we'll have lunch on their beautiful grounds (bring your own - lunch that is).

From there we'll ride through the Dry Creek region, crossing into the Russian River Region and over the Russian River (great photo op), and then back to Windsor.

This will be a full day of fun, and at times challenging riding, with a chance to see some amazing Sonoma County vineyards and country scenery!

PLEASE NOTE:  Because of the length and nature of this ride I will need an email from you when you RSVP telling me your experience and riding level (current riding, how often, distance, terrain, pace) ~ Thx!

What To Bring:

Snacks, water, a lunch, and your camera (there will be some great country shots on this ride).

Wear: Sunscreen, layered clothing, your helmet.

I pack a few fruit bars and at least one sandwich for lunch.  We'll be passing a deli, so if anyone wants to stop and pick up a sandwich to bring w/ them - no problem.

$5 activity fee 

Preparation:

Fill your tires the day/eve before.

Have your bike tuned and in good shape.

Getting out for a couple nice rides before this one (on your own if necessary) would help.

A repair kit (optional, though always suggested - at least a spare tube is highly recommended). I'll have a pump. 

As always, your sense of humour is required!

This ride is posted on other Meetup sites and will be a good chance to meet other riders.
name: 42 Mile Ride Through Beautiful Wine Country

description:
Join the ACSJ for a family friendly atheist afternoon in the park. This year's venue will be Vasona Park in Los Gatos - and we'll be doing it potluck style, so it should be lots of fun!

Our spot is Gateway Pavilion Group Area. It's the first picnic area on the right after you enter the park. (lower right corner) See map. The site includes shaded picnic tables and a large BBQ grill.

As it will be a potluck style picnic, please state in the comments what you plan on bringing, and it will be added to the main list below. This list will be updated often to reflect additions and changes. Also please bring serving utensils for your own dish. If your item needs to stay cool or hot, please plan to bring items to manage that, such as a cooler with ice. Plates, cups, eating utensils, and napkins will be provided.

Also of note, there is a $6 entrance fee per vehicle to the park, so carpool if you can!

For more details about Vasona Park, see here.

We look forward to spending the afternoon with you and your family!

~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~*~

Entrées & Side Dishes

• Spanish Rice (with Meat) - Larry Gott

• Zucchini Casserole/Veggies – Larry Gott

• Deviled Eggs - Kevin Harms

• Potato Salad(?) - Mike

• Kale Chips or Mini Frittas - Emily

• Corn on the Cob - Chuck Barritt

• Hummus & Chips - Kennita


Desserts

• Devil's Food Cake – Rick

• Saint-Andre Cheese & Fresh Fruit - Kurtis Rader

• Pie – Jim Laffer

• Gluten-Free Chocolate Chip Cookies - Gina Lunde

• Watermelon - Chuck Barritt

• Pie or Cookies - Noreen


Beverages

• Beer & Hard Cider - Lyn C

• Bloody Mary's - Kevin Harms

• Wine & Soda - Kim

• Fruit & Veggie Juice (?) - Kennita

• Maker's Mark Bourbon Whiskey - Kranthi Kavuri
name: First Annual ACSJ Picnic!

description:
This is a FREE introductory session for you to learn Android Programming for Wearables. Google has come out recently with the Android Wear SDK.  Attend this session to see if you want to learn Android Wearable programming in-depth.

- Get a headstart in learning Android programming for wearables. First class is Free.

- Classes are in Mountain View, CA : 11am - 1pm on the following days : Aug 3, Aug 9, Aug 10, Aug 16, Aug 17, Aug 23

- You will learn everything about Android, Android Wear, including Google Glass. Full Syllabus  : 

https://drive.google.com/?usp=folder&authuser=0#folders/0B4Aj-DszvT81SkZWWGVROW9rNWs
- Some programming experience is helpful, if complete newbie, please be prepared to work hard during the week.

- At the end of this bootcamp, you will be able to write Android basic apps for phones, watches, wearables and google glass.

- You don't need an android tablet, watch or wearable to learn to program for it. You will program with the Android emulator.
name: Android Wearables & iOS Bootcamp : Free session

What's included:

- $29 for a round of golf for one with cart and basket of range balls (reg. $75)

- $55 for a round of golf for two with cart and two baskets of range balls (reg. $150)

- $99 for a round of golf for four with cart and four baskets of range balls (reg. $300)

- 10% off food and beverages on the day of your visit

http://www.travelzoo.com/local-deals/East-Bay/Other/122395/Deer-Ridge-and-Shadow-Lakes-golf-clubs?utm_source=localdeal_us&utm_medium=email&utm_content=1785916&utm_campaign=1785916_html_san-francisco_deal%3a122395

- Just like the last time, book 3 tee times through our NCGC club and 3 times through BABGMG; or

- Book 3 tee times at Deer Ridge and 3 same tee times at Shadow Lakes 

We'll decide closer to the date of the meetup.

description:
3 Mi, 500' We’ll hike along wooded trails behind Villa Montalvo, an historic landmark. Enjoy a snack at Lookout Point, with a panoramic view of South Bay. Picnic lunch afterwards in a shady spot on expansive lawn in front of majestic mansion. There are Restrooms here. You have an option to explore arboretum in the afternoon. Directions #1: from Hwy 85: exit W on Saratoga Ave., head SW on Saratoga Ave for 1.8mi. At town of Saratoga L on Hwy 9/Los Gatos Saratoga Rd, 0.4 mi to R onto Montalvo Rd, Directions #2: From Hwy 17/880 take first Los Gatos exit at Hwy 9: Go NW on Hwy 9 3.2 miles to L onto Montalvo Rd. 0.6 mi to Villa Montalvo entrance. Continue past villa to Parking Lot 4, where we’ll meet. Carpool: Los Gatos 11:00  Cupertino 11:00 Leaders: Dieter and Suzanne Fellenz GPS: 15400 Montalvo Rd, Saratoga, 37.243798, -122.031086

Please click on "Pages" for additional Information.
name: 1A Hike, Villa Montalvo

description:
Hallo Alle. We will have another Fest to meet up and enjoy! I will make sure that we have a table again to meet (with sign) near the outdoor bar (like last time at Maifest). I hope as many of you can make it. If anyone would like to co-host with me...please feel free. Remember that one can enter the fest as early as 12PM (as many of us as possible) so that we can reserve additional adjacent tables. Below is the advertisement from the Naturefriends Oakland.


Welcome Again to Die Naturfreunde Oakland! (aka THE TOURIST CLUB)

Come celebrate Biergarten Fest and get your POLKA on with the Internationals Band (Band plays from 1PM to 5PM)

Experience our Berg Frei tradition with the DIRNDL- and LEDERHOSEN-laden Schuhplattler dancers. ALWAYS SASSY!

Authentic German Food: Many types of Bratwurst, Schnitzels, etc. plus various traditional sides, desserts and beverages are available for purchase. Try our wurst...it's the best!

Please join us at our home in the mountains above Oakland and take in the spectacular SAN FRANCISCO BAY VIEWS. We have a PLAYGROUND for juniors and a HORSESHOE court for you ringers. Or catch a tan in our alpine-style SUN CHAIRS. With dancing, beer, food and good company...there is something here for everyone!

description:
Come and join BAGH and welcome Janice Magill aka "Abby Normal" and Eileen Cervantes (both members of BAGH) on Sunday, August 3rd, as they talk about their experiences of living in a very active haunted house and the strange directions it has taken their lives.

I (Laura J) have investigated their house 3 times in the past and will be doing a follow-up investigation in the next few weeks along with an overnight stay, so I will be sharing some of my experiences also.

This will be a dutch treat lunch.

Some History:

For most of Janice's adult life, she had chosen to believe that when you died that was the end. But one night she found out differently when a ghostly woman standing next to her bed awoke her and wanted her to deliver a message to a mutual friend. That event changed Janice's life forever.


Janice has discovered that she has some paranormal abilities and is learning to cope with them – and the spirits who know she has them, too. In looking for more insight she has interviewed some famous mediums and paranormal investigators including Amy Allen (Dead Files), Kim Russo (The Haunting Of...), Laura Lee (Spirit Salon), Jackie Barrett (The Haunting of the Gemini, America's Psychic Challenge), The Zodiac Girls and the cast of Ghost Adventures.

In 2008, Eileen was a quasi-non-believer, wavering somewhere between "ghost stories are cool" and "it couldn't happen to me." While out house hunting, she found a house that was perfect on paper, except in person, it had a seriously negative feeling to it. Worried that Janice– an unwilling sensitive – would be uncomfortable in it, she walked away from it. That house became the basis for Eileen's novel, House of Homicide. Instead of buying the house that she thought might be haunted, she bought one that she fell in love with the moment she saw the listing - which turned out to be far more haunted than the first one. Destiny? Karma? 

For several years she ignored the strange happenings, but in 2013, an incident occurred that changed her life and her beliefs forever. 

Please welcome these guest speakers and enjoy lunch in this well known haunted location.

name: Meet & Greet with Janice Magill & Eileen Cervantes at Old Spaghetti Factory

Another blow job... um, I mean... blow out!  In honor of Pride weekend, we went all out with Team Glitter Ballz of Fury and Team Flaming Gallant Tiger Cajones battling for beer and pride!  Sadly, the Glitter Ballz went on top in the first, leaving the Flaming Cajones on the bottom and in the dust throughout the whole game.  But a good time was still had by all!  Final score:  Glitter Ballz 61, Flaming Cajones 34. 

Do you want to spend time meeting some new people? Does the idea of running around like a little kid appeal to you? Or maybe you want to let your inner trash-talker out? Does the potential of being in a group named "Team Midnight Buffet" or "Team Butt Cookies" excite you? If you've answered "yes" to any of these questions, you need to be a part of our games!

Ball-kicking, base-running, (friendly) trash-talking, laughing, smiling, and f-u-n: that's what we and our games are all about. 'Nuff said.


If you want to see more about how we roll, check out our PICS and REVIEWS!!!

description:
POSTPONED due to double-booking. This is now on August 3rd.

Directions/meeting point:(the meetup.com directions linked above are not always reliable, use these details to find the start of the hike) the meeting point will in Huddart County Park, in the main parking lot on Huddart Park Road.   I will be driving my Silver Subaru Impreza WRX, license plate ending in 468.   I'll be wearing this black Sanzaru Games hoodie (if it's not too hot). I'll send out my cell to RSVPs (but as always there is no guarantee of reception).

This week's hike is on the peninsula, starting at Huddart County Park, and ending up in Purisma Creek, before returning via Phleger Estate.  Exact route to be confirmed, but I expect it to be around 8 miles, with reasonable elevation gain..

Dress in layers, bring lots of water and snacks.  Hopefully the weather will be good, but be prepared for rain and mud. Also be sure to avoid Poison Oak, which can be found on most bay area trails.  We should be back well before sunset, but bring a flashlight just in case.  No dogs are allowed in these parks, unfortunately.


Carpooling recommended, as there is not a ton of parking at the trailhead.  I will be travelling from San Francisco and will have two spaces (email me via meetup if you are interested). There is a $6 parking fee at the park.


As with all my hikes everyone signs up at their own risk, and you assume all liability associated with the hike and carpooling to it (by RSVPing you agree to our conditions of membership).

If anyone fancies a post-hike beer and a snack, we'll be heading over to the <a>Freewheel Brewing</a> in Redwood City after the hike.
