description:
http://photos4.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/3/f/5/c/event_676220.jpegRaines says: This regular monthly community tour and open house of the East Bay's biggest and most "suburban" cohousing neighborhood, Pleasant Hill cohousing, the only "new-build" classic cohousing community in the region, the largest in the East Bay, and a lovely community.

Note that this is not an official MeetUp run by EBCOHO, but we will pass along RSVPs that come in here, and you can use this event listing to coordinate carpooling, bike riding, and the like.

Visit Pleasant Hill Cohousing's page on the EBCOHO MeetUp for more info, links, and current openings.

If you need to cancel your reservation, or decide not to go, please let Pleasant Hill's volunteer tour guide know as soon as possible!

 

Individual Homes

There are 32 units, grouped in various configurations ranging from 2-6 homes per building. The buildings were constructed with wood framing, stucco outer walls, and corrogated metal roofing. The smallest units are 675 sq ft one-bedrooms; the largest are 1707 sq ft four-bedrooms.

Each home has its own kitchen. The homes are owned individually as condominiums.

Common Areas

Our 3,835 sq ft Common House contains a kitchen, dining room ("great room"), sitting room, laundry, kids room, teens/older kids room, crafts room, guest rooms, bathrooms, and fireplace.

The Common House is the only building in the project that has air conditioning. However to minimize the use of air conditioning, the building also has a cooling tower with large fans that can be used in the evening to pull cooler air into the building and push hot air out.

http://photos1.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/8/e/3/c/event_93696412.jpegOther common facilities include swimming pool, hot tub, large sandbox/play area, workshop, bike shed, organic garden, and granite boulders from original site - both decorative and used by children for climbing.

Location

We're conveniently located near Highway 680 and public transportation, with easy access to Walnut Creek, shopping, and recreation.

Pleasant Hill, population 32,000, is located 30 miles east of San Francisco, 4 miles north of the I-680/Hwy 24 interchange. Mostly a residential community with scattered retail/commercial areas, it is bounded by the cities of Walnut Creek, Lafayette, Concord, and Martinez. Pleasant Hill has recently (2000) redeveloped its downtown to create a contemporary shopping district just blocks from the site. In addition, an abundance of good restaurants and shops are within easy driving distance. The city has good recreation programs for all ages and regional walking/biking trails traverse it.

 

Iron Horse Trail

A walking and biking trail - the Iron Horse Trail (so named because it's on the old Southern Pacific Railroad right-of-way) - runs alongside the site and connects to the Pleasant Hill BART (Bay Area Rapid Transit) station (~1 mile) and downtown Walnut Creek (~4 miles). The 24-mile trail goes north-south from Concord to Dublin and connects to several other trails that traverse the county making for great biking opportunities.

A neighborhood park is located just the other side of Fair Oaks Elementary School adjacent to the site. Briones Regional Park and Mt. Diablo State Park are located nearby providing numerous opportunities for hiking and recreation. There are several health clubs in Pleasant Hill including the YMCA and Bally's (walking distance).

Diablo Valley Community College and JFK University are located in Pleasant Hill, and there are several city and county adult education programs in the area.

There are multiple venues nearby for movies, theater, music and other performing arts including a CineArts movie theater (art and independent films), the Dean Lesher Center for the Arts in Walnut Creek, the Willows Theater Company in Concord, and the Concord Pavillion.

There are farmers markets in Pleasant Hill (May-Nov) and Walnut Creek (year-round). Several community members participate in a CSA farm, Terra Firma Farms, with a weekly delivery of locally grown organic fruits and vegies made even more convenient because we are the drop site.
how_to_find_us: Come to the Common House front door.  Please arrive promptly - note new start time vs previous tours.  If you're late, walk around to the back and look for us there. Optional community meeting follows at 3. Let your tour guide know if you cancel.
why: It is well worth the journey to go "East of the Hills" and see this community. Whether you're thinking about living there, seeking more examples of cohousing, or looking for inspiration for your own new neighborhood. If the weather is good, bike it!
name: Pleasant Hill Cohousing monthly tour

description:
WHAT’S IT ALL ABOUT?
Shoppers (aka “swappers”) bring in GOOD quality women’s, men’s, and children’s clothing and swap for other items brought by other swappers. Please remember that donated items are no longer yours.

WHAT HAPPENS ONCE I ARRIVE?
If you have clothes to drop-off:
• Clothing drop-off time is from 2:00pm – 4:00pm. • You’ll have fun checking out the items and finding treasures to take home.

If you do not have clothes to drop-off:
• Arrive at the Clothing Swap from 4:30pm-5:30pm to find goodies.

WHAT IF I DON’T FIND MY SIZE/STYLE?
Since we are dependent on the clothes brought in by others, we cannot guarantee you will find exactly what you are looking for (size and style) as the selection is based solely on what others bring in. Also, since this is not a “trade” event, we cannot guarantee the amount of clothes you take will be equal to what you brought in.

IT DOESN’T REALLY MATTER BECAUSE WE ARE STILL GOING TO PARTY!!!

WHAT SHOULD I BRING?
Please bring at clean and gently-used clothing such as dresses, play clothes, pants, jackets, swimwear, shirts, hats, costumes and accesories. Bring shoes tied together.

Please be mindful of other swappers and only bring clothes that you would want to bring home (i.e., no stains, holes, rips, or missing pieces). If you want to do a good deed and donate more clothes than you want in return, please bring do so! Other swappers will have more choices and your closets will be cleaner!

There is no time limit for how long you can stay during the event hours, but we ask you to please take only what you need. Select only what you can use so everyone can have an enjoyable shopping experience too. We want this to be fun and satisfying opportunity for all our swappers!

If two or more of you want the same item, the host will flip a coin, draw or rock/paper/scissors for the winner.
We'll have music, food and drinks so be prepared to have fun.
name: Let's Sip and Swap Fashion!

description:
Expanding technology and social organization have enabled more people to live together in smaller spaces with fewer resources, but with better living conditions. However, this greater good for greater numbers can be punctuated by catastrophic famines, wars, and exterminations. What if this trend continued with an ever greater density of prosperous experience with cataclysmic nightmares? Live one such future through the eyes of a child whose misfortune gives him the skepticism to see the flaws and risks of his era. Could this one individual make the difference against a collapse of historic proportions?

Please RSVP by June 30 and I'll send out the novel July 1st.
name: Novel Reading: Density by Carlos Cortes

description:
From Goodreads:

"Anzaldua, a Chicana native of Texas, explores in prose and poetry the murky, precarious existence of those living on the frontier between cultures and languages. Writing in a lyrical mixture of Spanish and English that is her unique heritage, she meditates on the condition of Chicanos in Anglo culture, women in Hispanic culture, and lesbians in the straight world. Her essays and poems range over broad territory, moving from the plight of undocumented migrant workers to memories of her grandmother, from Aztec religion to the agony of writing. Anzaldua is a rebellious and willful talent who recognizes that life on the border, "life in the shadows," is vital territory for both literature and civilization. Venting her anger on all oppressors of people who are culturally or sexually different, the author has produced a powerful document that belongs in all collections with emphasis on Hispanic American or feminist issues."
name: First Book Discussion: Borderlands/ La Frontera by Gloria E. Anzaldúa

description:
Learn to play ancient & vintage board games played by Pharaohs of Egypt, Emperors of China, Knights Templar, and people from around the world for hundreds -and in some cases thousands- of years.  Play for knowledge, fun, & prizes!

This cafe will have live jazz and blues music upstairs on Sunday afternoon and offers a cafe menu with an expresso bar and selection of wine & beer.  It has a great outdoor terrace and huge room for us too!  You can check out their website at: Blue Rock Shoot.  There is a ton of free parking in the back parking lot - accessed around the corner by the park (see map below).

To add an element of challenge, we are going to offer a 1st, 2nd, & 3rd place prize for the most wins (weighted by games).  At our AiH Bday Party in September, we will raffle off some games - so everyone who comes gets one raffle ticket for the September drawing.

1st Place:  $5 gift-certificate to the cafe & 5 raffle entries

2nd Place: $3 gift-certificate to the cafe & 3 raffle entries

3rd Place: Game event fee of $3 waived for your next time & 2 raffle entries

Everyone who comes will get 1 raffle entry

Cost:  $3 (please bring to the event).  This is to cover prizes and purchases of new historical games for us to play. 

Game List (may be added to):  

*All Game Rules will be available at event*

Senet: One of the oldest known board games. It has been found in Predynastic and First Dynasty burials of Egypt, c. 3500 BC and 3100 BC respectively. It was one of the most popular games of Egypt. By the time of the New Kingdom in Egypt (1550–1077 BC), it had become a kind of talisman for the journey of the dead.

Playing time: 10–45 minutes. Players: 2.  Medium amount of random chance (dice rolling).  Skills required: Strategy, tactics, counting, probability.


Mancala is a family of board games played around the world, sometimes called "sowing" games, or "count-and-capture" games, which describes the gameplay.  Among the earliest evidence of the game are fragments of a pottery board and several rock cuts found in Aksumite areas in Matara (in Eritrea) and Yeha (in Ethiopia), which are dated by archaeologists to between the 6th and 7th century AD.

Playing time: 10-20 minutes.  Players: 2.  Chance: Light amount (no dice).   Skills required:  Strategy, tactics, counting, probability.

Go is a board game for two players that originated in China more than 2,500 years ago. The game is rich in strategy despite its relatively simple rules.  Go originated in ancient China. Archaeological evidence shows that the early game was played on a board with a 17×17 grid, but by the time the game had spread to Korea andJapan, in about the 5th and 7th centuries AD respectively, boards with a 19×19 grid had become standard.   The earliest written reference to the game is generally recognized as the historical annal Zuo Zhuan (c. 4th century BC), referring to a historical event of 548 BC. It is also mentioned in Book XVII of the Analects of Confucius and in two books written by Mencius (c. 3rd century BC).

Playing time (Casual): 20–90 minutes.  Random chance: None.  Skills required: Strategy, tactics, observation.


Knights Templar Playing Chess, 1283

Chess is believed to have originated in Eastern India during (c. 280 – 550 CE) in the Gupta Empire, where its early form in the 6th century was known as chaturaṅga, literally four divisions [of the military] – infantry, cavalry, elephants, and chariotry, represented by the pieces that would evolve into the modern pawn, knight, bishop, and rook, respectively.


Around 1200, the rules of shatranj started to be modified in southern Europe, and around 1475, several major changes made the game essentially as it is known today.  These modern rules for the basic moves had been adopted in Italy and Spain. Pawns gained the option of advancing two squares on their first move, while bishops and queens acquired their modern abilities. The queen replaced the earlier vizier chess piece towards the end of the 10th century and by the 15th century had become the most powerful piece.


Players: 2.  Playing time: 15 to 60 minutes. Random chance: None. Skills required:  Strategy, tactics


Mahjong:  One of the myths of the origin of mahjong suggests that Confucius, the Chinese philosopher, developed the game in about 500 BC. The three dragon (cardinal) tiles also agree with the three cardinal virtues bequeathed by Confucius:  benevolence, sincerity, and filial piety.  Many historians believe it was based on a Chinese card game called Mǎdiào (馬吊) (also known as Ma Tiae, hanging horse; or Yèzí [葉子], leaf) in the early Ming dynasty.


This game was banned by the government of People's Republic of China when it took power in 1949. The new Communist government forbade any gambling activities, which were regarded as symbols of capitalist corruption. After the Cultural Revolution, the game was revived, without gambling elements, and the prohibition was revoked in 1985.


The game was imported to the United States in the 1920s. The first mahjong sets sold in the U.S. were sold by Abercrombie & Fitch starting in 1920.  It became a success in Washington, D.C., and the co-owner of the company, Ezra Fitch, sent emissaries to Chinese villages to buy every mahjong set they could find.


Players: 2-4.  Playing time: 1-3 hours.  Random Chance: Light - shuffling. Skills required:  Strategy, tactics, memory.

The Royal Game of Ur, also known as the Game of Twenty Squares, refers to an ancient game represented by two game boards found in the Royal Tombs of Ur in Iraq by Sir Leonard Woolley in the 1920s. The two boards date from the First Dynasty of Ur, before 2600 BC, thus making the Royal Game of Ur one of the oldest examples of board gaming equipment found, although Senetboards found in Egyptian graves predate it as much as 900 years. The Ur-style Twenty Squares gameboard was also known in Egypt as Asseb, and has been found in Pharaoh Tutankhamen's tomb, among other places. Discovery of a tablet partially describing the gameplay has allowed the game to be played again after over 2000 years, although reconstructions of the detailed rules have differed widely.


Players: 2.  Playing time: 20-50 minutes.  Random Chance: Medium (dice).  Skills required:  Strategy, tactics.

*****************

I will be bringing all of these games to the event, and hopefully will be able to add more in the future!  Below is a pic of the front of the cafe and a map of the general location.  Plentiful parking is around the corner in the back (you can access the cafe from there - the building with the terraced patios).  

There has been interest in making this a reoccurring event, so please check back if you are unable to go this time.

description:
This event is perfect for some of you who want to get into paddling on a kayak or SUP board but never have done it, or tried a few time but want to practice a little more in a safe calm surface at Vasona before you hit the waves or the open Bay/ocean. We start later in the day to avoid the traffic and harmful UV rays. Rental rates are:
Kayaks
$15 hr.
$10- 1/2-hr.
(2-persons or 1-person) Stand Up Paddle Board
$15 hr.
$10 - 1/2-hr.
$25- includes 1/2 Hours Lesson and 1/2 Board Rental
(1 Person per Board) *** You will sign a waiver at the boat rental. In order to join this event, you should be able to swim and be strong enough to pull yourself up on the board or kayak in case you fall in the water.


Wear the quick-dry clothing (like swim suits, rash guard, board shorts, but no cotton), aqua shoes or socks, marine gloves, and bring a towel and the change of clothes, water-proof pouch to put your car-keys and valuables. There is no shower, but you can change in the restrooms. Bring a hat, sun screen, sun glasses w/a croaky, a bottle of water to drink. We’ll meet at the boat rental location at Vasona Lake inside of Vasona Park, Los Gatos. For more info, visit Los Gatos Recreation Class & Programs page at http://www.lgsrecreation.org/Pages/vasona.html. I will be wearing a Meetup badge.
name: SUP or Kayak at Vasona, Los Gatos, SUN Aug 3, 3:30 – 5 PM

description:
Join us in the JoAnn classroom!

ATC theme: Fabric - use fabric or felt in your cards, sew or no-sew!

Make 5-8 cards in advance with your take on the theme and bring them to swap. If this is your first maker day or you've never made ATCs before, no worries! Join us for the demo and we'll fill you in... then you can swap next month!

Demo: Kumihimo (Japanese braiding)

Supplies for you to bring: 
- Round Kumihimo disk tool
- Sturdy string, twine or cord - any size, multiple colors are nice
- small weight with a hook or loop (I use a 1.5" crystal ball from a suncatcher) 

Click here to see a few ways I used a plain round Kumihimo braid in crafts...it's not so much related to ATCs but it's fun and easy to do, with beautiful results.

Feel free to bring your own project to work on if this demo isn't so interesting to you, we'd still love to swap ATCs and have some good chat time with you!
name: ATC Maker Day - August

description:
It's like a math equation! "My Heart Belongs to Daddy" + Free Ice Cream Social + Free Concert + Broadway Singers = One Wonderful Time!

This is the last of the San Jose Symphony's free Summer Pops Concerts on the lawn at San Jose State University.  These are terrific events to picnic, socialize and listen to great music! 


Tonight is The Cole Porter Songbook for a lyrical trip back to the 1930s and 1940s. A gifted composer and lyricist with a scandalous secret life, Porter handled both music and lyrics with ease, and conquered both Broadway and Hollywood with his witty songs.   His work includes "Night and Day," "Anything Goes," "I've Got You Under My Skin," "True Love," and of course "My Heart Belongs to Daddy."


SJSU has plastic chairs if you want to sit on those or you can bring your own or sit on the grass. You will want to get there a bit early to get the best space.

PICNIC: 4:30 Bring food/snacks to share, wine, etc...

PERFORMANCE: Begins at 5:30

NOTE if you cannot locate the BAIC group please call my cell at [masked].
name: Revisit the 1930s & 40s:  Cole Porter Songbook, FREE concert on the lawn at SJSU

name: 3D Printer Meetup

description:
This meetup is for intermediate/advanced players, rated 3.5 to 4.0. Players aspiring to 3.5 and wanting a challenge and learn are also welcome.

In this meetup we play sets and try to improve match skills and competitiveness. Feedback to each other is welcome. We try to match players' skills.

It's geared mostly for singles play, though we may play doubles if there aren't enough courts available.

A fresh can of balls will be appreciated to play.

You are encouraged to arrive early because these courts are very popular.


Waitlist: What do you do if you are in the waitlist? You should definitely plan to attend the event, but 45 to 60 minutes from the start. At that time, things start to ease and spots open up. We ask that you always wait outside, at the entrance, until the next re-shuffle of partners or a court opens up. In the rare event that there are a lot of people waiting due to lack of courts, confirmed RSVPs have priority, but even then we will try to shuffle everyone in.

Please avoid no-shows at all costs. If you find you cannot attend, change your RSVP as early as possible to free one spot so that others can plan their day. No-shows will lead to not being allowed to participate in future events.

Be prepared to have fun and being challenged playing!
how_to_find_us: Ask a couple of people if they are with the meetup group.
name: Sunday Sunnyvale 3.5+ Tennis

description:
It's Music, Dancing, & Picnic time.  Music in the Park is wonderful!  Lets all get together.  Food & Alcohol are allowed so maybe bring a appetizer & a drink to share.  Please bring a blanket &/OR your own chair.  THIS PLACE GETS CROWED SO THE CLOSER TO 5 YOU GET THERE THE BETTER. MUSIC STARTS AT 6."

MUSTACHE HARBOR 

This Band is

GREAT!!   EVERYBODY knows these songs.

Check out there video.......

BAND VIDEO: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3j5kZ4JwzmQ 

Mustache Harbor is a group of dedicated and talented musicians brought together by their  love for vintage soft rock and sweet stashes.

Formed in Northern California, M.H. is comprised of Steven Moon on Keys, (who’s spiritual experience as a limo driver for Michael McDonald fueled his desire to play soft rock.) Pat Vornado on Bass…..yes, THAT Pat Vornado. Russ ” solid” Gold… out of Biscayne Bay, on drums. “Pretty” Rick Dallas on Guitar, and Dan ” the man” Kingsford on vocals, acoustic guitar and overall frontman-ness. If we are not at the Dojo, perfecting our kick-ass moves, you will find us in, on, or near the water, producing sweet sounds as smooth as the summer sea.

Our mission, our destiny, is simple, to build a mustache army capable of creating a Soft Rock Explosion the likes of which has not been seen since the days when Christopher Cross, Steely Dan, Ace, Kenny Loggins and The Little River Band, to name but a few, created A.M. Gold.

 ﻿Event is from 5:30-7:30 pm but COME EARLY to grab a spot with the group.  This is a well attended event & open to the public.

So Be Sure to Bring your lawn chair, beverages & appetizers.  This is an OUTDOOR concert & is free to attend.

﻿ ﻿
name: Outdoor Free Concert w/the "Mustache Harbor" Band

description:
What's a great way to improve your Mandarin or English?

Join our innovative sessions to advance both, learning communication and language skills at the same time.

The first hour is one-to-one mutual coaching, and the second hour is a special event - singing workshop by Bilingual Champion Vincent.

Singing is the best way to develop vocal variety. Vincent has won "people's choice award" for his singing. He is the first bilingual speech champion in Toastmasters' 90-year history and President of San Jose Mandarin English Toastmasters. 


Bring your questions and a journal.

English and Mandarin speakers of all levels are welcome!

description:
So, mother nature seems to be hatin' on the Transplants (raining on our hikes, beating down 100 degrees on our book club) but, we are undaunted! The last book was well-received, the meeting was fairly attended (especially considering the weather) and we are marching onward with another book selection! http://smile.amazon.com/Theory-Opposites-Allison-Winn-Scotch-ebook/dp/B00GGQ8YEQ/ref=sr_1_1?s=digital-text&ie=UTF8&qid=1402337234&sr=1-1&keywords=The+Theory+of+Opposites

Let's put a "Meet Up" time at about 5 weeks out. And, let's plan on meeting up at Heather Farms (in the spirit of exploration of our various 'hoods in conjunction with the reading / socializing). Also bumped it waaaaay back in time to help combat some of the summer heat. 6:45pm should give us plenty of light and I hope it doesn't affect people's decision to attend because of Monday AM work obligations. We will meet at the "Grassland" area of Heather Park (map link below), which is just "south" (in the image, not necessarily as a real-world directional) of the larger lake, by one of the parking facilities. Bring a blanket, a beverage of choice and a snack to share.
name: Summer Book Club - Light(er) Reading - Book # TWO

group.name: Parents of Bay Area Young Writers

description:
Dear Parents,


Due to recent requests, we are offering a new morning camp in the Cupertino area for the week of August 4-8, 2014. Please see below for details!


Imagine-Nation Course for Young Writers, Ages 8-12

Taught by Writing Coaches Shu-Hsien Ho & Royd Hatta

 
This year, we’re inviting students to create stories about memorable, wacky Heroes and Villains. As always, we'll have 2 writing teachers and a maximum of 12 students per workshop.

Cupertino/San Jose area (near Miller Ave & Bollinger Rd)

Generously Hosted by Parent Michelle VanWiggeren

AUG 4-8: 9:30am-12:30pm - STORY WRITING, Ages 7-12

Students will

* practice the entire writing process

* focus in-depth on one or two stories

* learn highly interactive, playful and hands-on writing games & exercises

* learn story structure based on the Hero’s Journey by Joseph Campbell

* have an opportunity to do a reading of their work on Friday

Our story writing students will travel through all the creative writing steps:

* Brainstorming

* Choosing a topic

* Organizing ideas

* Writing rough drafts

* Revising content

* Editing (grammar, spelling, punctuation)

* Publishing

Feedback for our Workshops:

"My daughter had the pleasure of taking a week-long creative writing workshop from Shu-Hsien and Royd. Though my daughter is an advanced reader, I have had previous challenges creating an environment where she would get into writing. Shu-Hsien and Royd were able to get the group of kids to enthusiastically write. Students shared their works at the end of the week with oral readings. The teachers are excellent about using various strategies to tap into what works for the individual student and use interactive group work to start the thinking process moving for the young writers....My daughter came home from the workshop so happy and content, the way she can be after a long stretch of time engrossed in an activity."
  ~ Julie, Parent of 8-year-old writer

Writing Coaches Shu-Hsien Ho and Royd Hatta are passionate about teaching youth and teens how to organize their thoughts and write with power, clarity and ease. Since 1996, their students have learned to write essays, research reports, poems, short stories, and even their first novels. After working with Ms. Ho, one teen writer independently published her 400-page fantasy novel. Their students have gotten accepted into top colleges and universities, such as UC San Diego, Carnegie Mellon, Caltech, MIT, NYU, and Brown University. Ms. Ho has a B.A. from Pomona College and an M.A. from Lesley University. Mr. Hatta has a B.A. from the California State University at Long Beach, with specialties in history, art, theater, and philosophy. Ms. Ho and Mr. Hatta currently teach small group workshops for homeschooling groups and at the Chinese American International School in San Francisco. They run two thriving writers clubs with over 420 families: Bay Area Young Writers and Bay Area Teen Writers. In the last two years, Ms. Ho and Mr. Hatta published four anthologies of their students’ fiction: Strokes of Lightning, Real Heroes Wear Sneakers, Bones of Mystery, and Encroaching Ink. They are currently compiling and editing stories for the 2014 anthologies.

Regular Tuition:
$410 per student

Special Offer if we receive a $150 Deposit by APRIL 12:
$310 per student


RSVP online Today: http://www.meetup.com/Parents-of-Bay-Area-Young-Writers/events/173914732/

For more information, please contact Writing Coach Shu-Hsien Ho:

[masked] or <a>[masked]</a>

To register and reserve a seat, please write deposit checks to

“Beyond the Box Learning” and mail to:

Shu-Hsien Ho

Beyond the Box Learning

c/o UPS Store

530 Showers Drive #7-256

Mountain View, CA 94040

Thank you! We look forward to working with your children.
name: Cupertino Story Writing Camp: August 4-8, 2014

group.name: New Yorker Magazine Lovers in SF

description:
All, please join us for our next New Yorker Magazine Meet Up. Conversations are not limited to the New Yorker Magazine at all, but rather it is a gathering of like-minded people who enjoy the New Yorker Magazine to enjoy cocktails and socialize. We will talk about life, world events and anything else worthy of conversation over happy hour drinks.

We try to pick a few articles each month for people to read. Here are this month's articles: 

A Very Rare Book
The mystery surrounding a copy of Galileo’s pivotal treatise.
http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2013/12/16/131216fa_fact_schmidle


Auto-Correct
Has the self-driving car at last arrived?http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2013/11/25/131125fa_fact_bilger

ROCKET MAN
How an unemployed blogger confirmed that Syria had used chemical weapons.
http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2013/11/25/131125fa_fact_keefe

By popular demand, here is a FAQ for this Meet Up.

Q: Is reading of the articles mandatory. 

A: No, No, and No. Please come even if you haven't. 

Q: I only look at the cartoons and never really read the articles. May I still attend?

A: Yes.

Q: I used to read the New Yorker but I haven't recently. May I still attend?

A: Yes. We are about like-minded people getting together and socializing. There will be no test on recent issues.
name: Talk about the New Yorker over cocktails.

description:
Enjoy meatless Sri Lankan cuisine! Pearl of the Ocean offers organic food, many dishes with exotic ingredients that you can try! The owner is trained in Ayurvedic medicine and even has clients who come to her restaurant for healing food. Chef Ayoma Wilen is also the winner of the Best Chef America 2013 award!

http://www.pearloftheocean.net/


http://m.mainstreethub.com/pearloftheocean


http://www.facebook.com/PearlOfTheOceanCA

There will be one check per table, so please bring cash if you can.


Help the Environment

Eating with friends is fun, and even more fun if you're helping the environment at the same time. Reducing animal product consumption helps to reduce your personal contribution to greenhouse gas emissions and climate forcers, including carbon dioxide, methane, black carbon (soot), nitrous oxide, and tropospheric ozone. Plus, eating more veggies is good for you!

RSVPs

We'll make a reservation, so please RSVP and show up if you plan to go. To make sure our events are a success, if you're a no-show three times you won't be able to RSVP for the dinners anymore (it's nothing personal). Emergencies or illness aside, when you cancel at the last minute, that can mean some people who wanted to go couldn't, so that might be marked as well.


Be sure to check in with me so we can mark you as present on the RSVP list. That way I won't accidentally mark you as a no-show. Things get a little crazy as people arrive so I could easily make a mistake.


Hope to see you there! Multiple meetup groups are attending. If you'd like to meet more people than you're sitting next to, feel free to walk around and mingle with other tables. There will be people with a variety of eating styles at the event; all we ask is that everyone be respectful and kind to each other, and order a meatless dish to help the environment.

More Information About Meatless Monday

Our normal Meatless Monday dinners are the first Monday of the month at 6:30pm. We might have other special dinners on other Mondays of the month.

Here's more info about the international Meatless Monday campaign:
http://www.meatlessmonday.com/about-us/why-meatless/

Here's the goal of the international Meatless Monday campaign, from their website:

"Meatless Monday is a non-profit initiative of The Monday Campaigns, in association with the Johns Hopkins’ Bloomberg School of Public Health. We provide the information and recipes you need to start each week with healthy, environmentally friendly meat-free alternatives. Our goal is to help you reduce your meat consumption by 15% in order to improve your personal health and the health of the planet."

Here's a proclamation that the Santa Cruz County supervisors put together in support of Meatless Monday:
http://files.meetup.com/161345/MeatlessMondayProclamationSignedSCCsupervisors.pdf

Here is the Meatless Monday Santa Cruz County Facebook page:

http://www.facebook.com/SCruzMM

What Is Meat?

This is a question I have been asked. For clarity, it is the flesh of animals (kingdom Animalia) as used for food. Feel free to look up this kingdom if you like; for example, it does include fish and various sea creatures.

You come under your own liability to this event.
how_to_find_us: Ask for the Meatless Monday group.
name: Meatless Monday Dinner: Eat Sri Lankan Food to Help the Environment

What Is Meat?

This is a question I have been asked. For clarity, it is the flesh of animals (kingdom Animalia) as used for food. Feel free to look up this kingdom if you like; for example, it does include fish and various sea creatures.

You come under your own liability to this event.

group.name: Loma Prieta Chapter of the Sierra Club

description:
Join us on Monday, August 4th in Redwood City for a special showing of Annie Leonard's latest film, The Story of Solutions, and an introduction to the Loma Prieta Chapter! 

If you have ever wondered how our chapter welcomes and empowers our members, new and old, come and feel welcomed into our chapter. 

All are welcome. Dessert and beverages. After the film, we'll have short introductions to some of the groups and activities that the Loma Prieta Chapter sponsors. We'll learn about the many hiking and outing groups, efforts to stop fracking for oil in California, the battle against clear cutting of forests, and current Water and Conservation issues. 

You'll have a chance to share your thoughts and concerns, and find out how you can make a difference by becoming more involved - at whatever level works for you! We'll enjoy some dessert and drinks (note: no dinner this meeting) and make some new connections and friends during our discussion portion of the evening. Don't miss it! 

Not yet a Member of the Sierra Club? Join today for as little as $15 and receive a special gift:  http://lomaprieta.sierraclub.org/join
name: Event for Sierra Club Members: Controversial Film & Activities Discussion

description:
If others ask you, "what do you do", how do you craft a pitch about yourself, or your company?

Join our interactive workshop hosted by multiple speech champions. You'll learn simple techniques and coach each other for a compelling talk.
name: Craft a Compelling Talk through Mutual Coaching

description:
Welcome to the new and improved community crafting event!  This free meetup returns to Santa Clara. 

 

Since so many of our extremely talented members have many and various types of crafts to do, including the paper arts, drawing, stamping, card making, scrap booking, quilting, embroidery, knitting, and jewelry making, we've decided to rename these free nights of crafting as "Community Crafting" nights, rather than knitting, needles or jewelry.

 

So, we now welcome ALL crafters to the community room on the first and third Mondays of the month to share your craft, your art, and your projects with all of us!!  Show us your stuff, and bring your great crafts to the meetup!

 

Although this is a FREE meetup, we do ask that everyone please keep their RSVP's updated at all times.  There is limited space in this meetup and its not fair for anyone to RSVP and never show up.  Please know that if you can with less than 5 days notice to the host, you will be given an attendance violation for the year.  Repeated offenses can result in removal from the group.  Please remember the rules and keep your RSVPs updated at all times.  thanks!
how_to_find_us: Across from Stevens Creek Nissan
name: Free Community Crafting Meetups - Santa Clara/San Jose

description:
Counter Culture Labs and our sister lab BioCurious in Sunnyvale are putting together a team for iGEM - the 10th international Genetically Engineered Machine competition. iGEM has been the premier breeding ground for synthetic biologists, and this is the first year they will also be accepting Community / DIYbio labs.

The topic we've chosen for our project is Vegan Cheese, expressing casein proteins in yeast - check out our wiki!

Feel free to come check us out, whether you are already part of the iGEM team or not. We're hoping to actually get work done in these meetings, so we will likely not give an extensive introduction to any newbies, but you're more than welcome to sit in and absorb some biohacking-in-action.  This is your opportunity to join a working iGEM team.  

For now, we will be meeting every first Monday of the month at BioCurious, and the other Mondays in Oakland.

Join from a PC, Mac, iPad, iPhone or Android device: 

Please click this URL to start or join. https://zoom.us/j/820128495    Or, go to https://zoom.us/join and enter meeting ID: 820 128 495  

Join from dial-in phone line: 

Dial: +1 [masked] or +1 [masked]    Meeting ID: 820 128 495
name: Synthetic Biology, Biohacking and Vegan Cheese - iGEM team meeting

group.name: East Bay Women Relaxing Into Relationship

description: We will share our challenges with and desires for relaxing into relationship and move into playful exercises to get out of our heads and into our bodies. I will guide you in deep relaxation and guided visualization so you can move toward your relationships while staying centered within yourself. I will teach you Emotional Freedom Technique as a powerful tool to navigate anxiety and challenging emotions in dating, relationships, and life. We will have the opportunity to practice EFT together in a way that is potent and and beneficial to all participating.
name: EFT and Deep Relaxation for Dating and Relationships

description:
For the Mountain View folks who can't make it to San Jose, and for everyone else too, Mondays at Peet's on Castro seem pretty nice!

All levels welcome—come knitters, come crocheters, or just come by and say hello. If you've never knit (or crocheted) before, just bring a set of needles (or a hook or a loom) and some yarn, we can get you started.

This venue has a parking lot next door (it's on the not-so-busy part of Castro Street). It does close at 9 but they're friendly about asking us to leave. We'll do introductions & show-and-tell around 8 o'clock, so bring along any finished objects you like and we'll ooh and aah over them.

** The meetup is free as always, but it's nice to buy a drink or snack at Peet's since they're so nice about letting us use the space. **
how_to_find_us: Look for the people playing with yarn.
name: First Monday Knitting Meetup

description:
Join the San Francisco Travel Book Club on Monday, August 4th when we will discuss The Great Railway Bazaar, by Paul Theroux

Description from Amazon.com
First published more than thirty years ago, Paul Theroux's strange, unique, and hugely entertaining railway odyssey has become a modern classic of travel literature. Here Theroux recounts his early adventures on an unusual grand continental tour. Asia's fabled trains -- the Orient Express, the Khyber Pass Local, the Frontier Mail, the Golden Arrow to Kuala Lumpur, the Mandalay Express, the Trans-Siberian Express -- are the stars of a journey that takes him on a loop eastbound from London's Victoria Station to Tokyo Central, then back from Japan on the Trans-Siberian. Brimming with Theroux's signature humor and wry observations, this engrossing chronicle is essential reading for both the ardent adventurer and the armchair traveler
name: The Great Railway Bazaar, by Paul Theroux: SF Travel Book Club August Meeting

description:

There will be a 30-something male group there so we can be there to meet them as well. :-) 
They will be there 8:30-10:30pm.
Feel free to come earlier to meet the other group or submit a song earlier.

You don't have to sound like a superstar to sing and have fun...you'll be in good supportive company...

Guests can come to two meeting before making a decision to join and the cost per meeting is $10.00 and that includes a great breakfast. Bring 50+ business cards and be prepared to give a couple commercials on yourself to tell us how we can help grow your business.

group.name: PMI San Francisco Bay Area Chapter

description:
This group has been set up to provide project managers in the PMI-SFBAC region with support while they are looking for new career opportunities.  

It will be held twice a month (every 1st and 3rd Tuesday, from 7:30am-9:00am) in San Francisco - for location details see above.  

The meeting will be open to currently unemployed project management professionals as well as those in search of a new position while still being employed.  

If there is interest from either side, representatives from recruiting and contracting agencies can be invited to give an overview of the current market situation, special skills that are in high demand, and potential trends.

During the events participants will:

• Share information on useful websites, job search opportunities, social media

• Discuss current project management as well as recruiting trends

• Initiate peer reviews on their own CV and/or online presence (e.g. website, LinkedIn)

The ‘PMI-SFBAC – Job Search Group’ will provide the attendees with much needed face-to-face support while they are trying to accomplish one of the most difficult tasks in their work life:  finding a new position where they can apply and develop their project management skills.


Note for Recuiters:

Please note that this meeting is for project managers who are looking for new job opportunity and who want to discuss the way to get there!

As much as we are happy to connect with you, it does not make sense for you to spend 90 minutes in this meeting - and to take up a seat from somebody who potentially would like to join and now has been put on the waiting list.  We are more than happy to have us join for the last 15 minutes of any future meeting, but we would like to coordinate that.

Please contact the meeting host upfront through this website - by clicking on the name and then 'Send email'.  We will get back to you asap and arrange an appropriate time and date.

Thank You!
how_to_find_us: https://liquidspace.com/Venues/capital-one-360-san-francisco
name: PMI-SFBAC Job Search Meeting

description:
Join us for free at one of our highly-innovative business-networking meetings - in your city! View our full calendar of business-networking meetings. We welcome anyone to attend a GoRampUp! meeting, once, for free as our guest, so you can learn what the innovative GoRampUp! business-networking experience is all about. Note, we are not able to give you a free meeting at more than one of our many locations.

YOU MUST obtain a free-access GoRampUp! Golden ticket by registering for a specific meeting athttp://GoRampUp.com/calendar/. This ticket must be presented at your complimentary meeting for you to gain admittance. Without this ticket you will, unfortunately, be declined access to our innovative and exclusive business-networking meeting. WITH a GoRampUp! Golden Ticket, you will be welcomed with open arms!

It can be too difficult to attract new clients. We help you fix that! We're a business-impact community. We're informal and fun, yet, by design, we're extremely effective!

We help people who work for a living to get a much greater payoff from working. We do this in three specific ways under our three CoreSuccess Platforms: 1) We help you move toward mastery with business-networking, 2) We help you move toward mastery with business performance, and, 3) We help you move toward mastery with personal development.

How do we deliver on this promise to our community members? Each month we conduct dozens of business-networking meetings in more than a dozen cities in the SF Bay Area. A member may attend all of our "OpenConnect" business-networking meetings. And our members are welcome and encouraged to attend any and all of these meetings and locations.

Each month we introduce and emphasize a learning and development subject under each of our three CoreSuccess Platforms. For each of the three learning and development subjects that we introduce and emphasize each month, we give you four different ways to learn it: We produce written learning guides, video learning guides, audio learning guide, and we cover the subjects as 15-to-20-minute mini-workshops inside of our 60-minute business-networking meetings. There's no registration or initiation fee to join. Membership in GoRampUp! is month to month. You enroll when you like, even mid-month, and you depart when you like.

Be sure to see our website to learn about our generous enrollment incentives

Also, be sure to learn about our 100-Satisfaction Money-Back Guarantee

Would you care to come to this meeting, at no cost, to see if there’s business-value for you?

• Free-Meeting Guest-RSVP and Golden Ticket Request

• View complete meeting details

• Invite a Buddy to join you

One last thing: You REALLY should check out actual testimonial videos by our members: See them here

This page was created to produce awareness of our event. However, OUR PAGES ON THIS SITE CAN BECOME OUTDATED. The authoritative source for our meeting dates/times is http://www.GoRampUp.com/calendar. Be sure to check it prior to traveling to a meeting.

description:
Our topic/presenter changes from month to month.

 ************************************************************

Mastery for Women is an international organization that recognizes the beauty, power and capabilities of all women.  Our mission is to enrich lives, awaken greatness and provide a community of support to ensure all women have the opportunity to reach their infinite potential.

At no time during the 1½ to 2 hours that you are there will business be discussed.  Our chapters are designed to foster a sense of community where women can grow from wherever they are in their lives today. With us, you will experience soul-to-soul connections with other like-minded women like never before. We are all beautiful, intelligent, and all have something to contribute.  We serve one another best by leaving our hang-ups at the door, listening to one another, and supporting one another. We come to our meetings with authentically, transparency, and without judgment.  

MFW is a safe place where women can support one another to reach the goals and desires that tug at our hearts and souls. It is a sisterhood of empowered women.  

Join us: http://www.masteryforwomen.com


Here are some of the opportunities that Mastery for Women provides:  

• o Bi-weekly local meetings – a monthly luncheon and a dinner, so we can reach as many women as possible  

• o Speakers at each meeting who address women’s issues, concerns, and education  

• o Book-of-the-Month Club  

• o Weekly Saturday Morning Coffee Calls -  https://www.facebook.com/events/507866415959885/  

• o Interactive Workshops  

• o Field Trips  

• o Regional and National Conferences  

• ...and there will always be lots of fun! 

To join us or for more information on starting a MFW Chapter in your local area, please visit our website:

http://www.masteryforwomen.com

or contact
Donna Bellacera
President & CEO of Mastery for Women
VP of Relations Successful Thinkers Network™, Inc
[masked].

description:
This is the second of a two part class on website development. In this class you will learn how to use the Bootstrap Framework to make a good looking website. Bootstrap is the most popular frontend framework and will save you time in developing a site. This class assumes you either attended the earlier class on HTML and CSS, or are otherwise already familiar with HTML and CSS. You need to bring a laptop computer with a text editor installed. If you don't already have a text editor, please download and install either Notepad++ for PC or Text Wrangler for Mac before attending the class. Both are free and work very well.
This class is taught as a hands on workshop. You will actually be creating a website on your computer during this class. You will access the code from the internet.
name: Free Crash Course - Learn Website Development - Bootstrap Framework

description:
Ready for more white-boarding, technical puzzlers and mock interviews? The folks at UrbanSitter are kindly hosting and will provide pizza. So come join us for whatever technical interview tasks you want to work on. 

The format is as usual:

We start with a quick meet & greet before breaking in to pairs.

Each pair will take turns as interviewer and interviewee. The interviewer will spend a few minutes asking the interviewee about their resume, experience and what they are looking for in a role. Then they spend 20 minutes or so posing a technical coding question, and reviewing the solution. Then, the pair switch roles. Pairs are, of course, welcome to change it up to suit their own needs.

After each round, we can change partners and we aim to get through 2 to 3 rounds in the evening.

Please come prepared with:

* A friendly and inquisitive attitude!

* A copy of your resume for the 'interviewer' to review and discuss

* Some 'puzzler' type questions that are typical in tech interviews; Ideally questions you know the answers to! We will provide some too.

Feel free to bring business/contact cards too. Networking is your best tool to find that next role!

Doors open at 5:45 and we start at 6:00. Looking forward to seeing you all there!

Shaun

PS Our hosts at UrbanSitter are hiring! Feel free to check their jobs section. An engineer will be available on site should you have any questions.
name: Coding Interview Practice #11

It should be a great night to learn more about whats going on in our community, how to be involved with the movers and shakers in the Tri-valley, and understanding healthcare for the startup world.  We look forward to seeing everybody there.

description:
RAFT's mission is to help educators transform the learning experience through hands-on education that inspires the joy and discovery of learning. Hands-on education translates abstract and complex subjects into activities that young learners, literally, can grasp, and nurtures their natural inquisitive and interactive traits. RAFT develops innovative hands-on project idea sheets and pre-packaged activity kits created around important concepts in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) as well as reading and art.

Volunteering at RAFT is a fun, easy and convenient way to support local teachers. RAFT's products, services and low-cost teaching supplies enrich and improve the education of over 825,000 young people each year. Volunteers help keep the cost of RAFT products affordable for educators by sorting the different raw materials that are donated and packaging RAFT hands-on learning activity kits.


When: 6:00pm-8:00pm. Please arrive on time and plan to stay for the entire shift.

All volunteers must be at least 18 years old.

If you would like to bring a guest/friend with you, please have them sign up with their own account through Meetup.

Casual Dress and close toed shoes are recommended. Onsite parking is available in the front, rear, and along the left-hand side of the building.

What we will be doing:

Building RAFT Hands-On Educational Kits - Assembling hands-on learning kits for science, math and art.

Sorting donated materials - sort and prepare a variety of donated materials for distribution to educator-members of RAFT. 

 

NOTE: By RSVP’ing to this event, you are agreeing to Silicon Valley Volunteers’ waiver policy. Please go to your profile page and say “YES” to the waiver policy after going through it, if you have not done so already. Click on “My Profile” at the top right-hand corner to go to your profile, and then click “Edit Profile” to agree to the waiver.

description:
Please come and play board games at Panera Bread (in the Concord Willows Shopping Center). Theme- the 70's: peace signs, tie dye, bandannas, Burkenstock's, flowy skirts/shirts, smiley faces and/or flower power. The theme is optional.

I will bring between 8-15 party/social/strategy/two person games to shared. Please bring a game or two to share.  I will supply name tags (this time, lol), pens, pencils and tons of scratch paper.  This group tends to eat prior to game play. If you decide not to eat, look for others that are "ready for game time".

Also, Panera Bread has a PaneraCard.  Just go to the counter, ask for a card, register it at home and your next visit you will have a free pastry.  Of course the more money you spend the more offers you will be receiving.  Plus, each full meal you purchase, you have the option to purchase a pastry for 99 cents.  Finally, Costco offers gift certificates (2) $25 for only $39.00 which you can utilize at any Panera Bread. The Costco in Concord definitely has Panera Bread gift cards. 

Just look for me or the East Bay Board Gamers "table tent".

I hope to see you all soon.

Jennifer (host)

description:
Hi all! This will be a Q&A session and BYOB happy hour with Rich Woulfe, a dive travel planning professional. We did a very similar event with Rich last year that was really interesting and informative. He can address questions about specific destinations of interest, general dive travel planning considerations, or anything in between. More info and Rich's bio is below.

We are going to be gathering in the social lounge of the Paramount (special thanks to Kate for arranging this!) which will be a better venue to have a group discussion. This is just a few minute walk from the Montgomery BART station, and above the Grove.


Please feel free to bring your favorite drink and/or snacks to share so we'll make it our own private happy hour. Hope to see you there!

"Ask the Dive Travel Expert"
Presented By Richard Woulfe

This is your opportunity to ask any dive travel or general travel question. Come join Rich Woulfe of RichTravels as he answers interesting questions about numerous travel topics. Dive travel planning is an exciting and dynamic process. With the right strategies and tools, the planning and travel itself can be enjoyable and result in hundreds of dollars in savings.

Richard has over 32 years of dive travel experience. In 2012 he was on the road over 300 days in over 20 countries and stayed in over 100 hotels/resorts. Rich has dived in over 100 destinations around the world. This includes over 20 trips to Thailand, 14 trips to the Maldives, 10 trips to Fiji, the Philippines, Papua New Guinea, Australia, New Zealand, Cocos Island, the Galapagos, Indonesia(Komodo, Raja Ampat,Bali), Sipadan/Mabul, Palau, Japan, Colombia and numerous Caribbean destinations.

Richard is an expert on marketing and selling adventure trips to remote dive and water adventure locations.  You may contact him at [masked]
how_to_find_us: We'll be in the social lounge of the building. Look for the dive flag!
name: Dive Travel Q&A and BYOB happy hour

http://techtalkhectoryee.eventbrite.com

Hector Yee of LiftIgniter is a technical leader in the fields of machine learning, personalized recommendations and detailed user modelling.

His paper, "Label Partitioning for Sublinear Ranking", was co-authored with Jason Weston and Ameesh Makadia while at Google. 

Thank you to our generous sponsor and host for the evening, Yelp.


About Hector Yee
Hector is a researcher / engineer in the field of personalized recommendations. He wrote a large chunk of the Emmy award winning personalized video recommendation engine at Youtube and the recommended for you (similar users) part of the Google Play store. These recommendations are generated for many hundreds of millions of users and over millions of items and have increased watch time on YouTube and revenue on the Google Play store by a large percentage.
name: Google Play Tech Talk: Label Partitioner for Sublinear Ranking

description:
Details:

By enabling better automation of processes and management, Cisco Unified Computing System (UCS) allows data center managers to achieve greater agility and scale in their server operations while reducing complexity and risk. Join us as we discuss UCS PowerTool, the PowerShell library for UCS, and demonstrate how Cisco UCS PowerTool interfaces with the Cisco UCS XML API (which provides an interface for Cisco UCS hardware inventory, monitoring, alerting, and automation of Cisco UCS using PowerShell). Real world examples detailing programmatic bare metal deployment and ongoing systems monitoring and management of Cisco UCS using Cisco UCS PowerTool will be demonstrated.

Speaker Bio:

Jason Shaw is a UCS (Unified Computing Systems) Technical Marketing Engineer with Cisco Systems who focuses on systems management, automation, and partner integration.  Jason’s responsibilities include educating customers, partners, and field staff on the management benefits of using the Cisco UCS platform in the datacenter.  Jason works closely with UCS Product Management Teams to drive product direction and roadmap.
name: Jason Shaw - Cisco UCS PowerTool

description:
Thirty years after women became 50 percent of the college graduates in the United States, men still hold the vast majority of leadership positions in government and industry. This means that women’s voices are still not heard equally in the decisions that most affect our lives. In Lean In, Sheryl Sandberg examines why women’s progress in achieving leadership roles has stalled, explains the root causes, and offers compelling, commonsense solutions that can empower women to achieve their full potential. 


Sandberg is the chief operating officer of Facebook and is ranked onFortune’s list of the 50 Most Powerful Women in Business and as one ofTime’s 100 Most Influential People in the World. In 2010, she gave an electrifying TEDTalk in which she described how women unintentionally hold themselves back in their careers. Her talk, which became a phenomenon and has been viewed more than two million times, encouraged women to “sit at the table,” seek challenges, take risks, and pursue their goals with gusto.


In Lean In, Sandberg digs deeper into these issues, combining personal anecdotes, hard data, and compelling research to cut through the layers of ambiguity and bias surrounding the lives and choices of working women. She recounts her own decisions, mistakes, and daily struggles to make the right choices for herself, her career, and her family. She provides practical advice on negotiation techniques, mentorship, and building a satisfying career, urging women to set boundaries and to abandon the myth of “having it all.”  She describes specific steps women can take to combine professional achievement with personal fulfillment and demonstrates how men can benefit by supporting women in the workplace and at home. 


Written with both humor and wisdom, Sandberg’s book is an inspiring call to action and a blueprint for individual growth. Lean In is destined to change the conversation from what women can’t do to what they can.
name: August Book Club - Lean In: Women, Work, and the Will to Lead by Sheryl Sandberg

description:
Imagine a street (in this case a cul-de-sac) blocked off to traffic and reserved for a block party type of event - anchored by a drum circle..... our drum circle. Residents of the neighborhood will be invited to attend to meet their neighbors, have a snack, and listen to the music that we produce in our drum circle ..... and they will be welcome to join in.

It's all part of "National Night Out" and the following text is from their press release at http://www.natw.org/resources/press-release/

The National Association of Town Watch (NATW) has announced that the “29th Annual National Night Out (NNO) program will culminate on Tuesday, August 6, 2013.

National Night Out, a year-long community building campaign, is designed to: (1) Heighten crime prevention awareness; (2) Generate support for, and participation in, local anticrime programs; (3) Strengthen neighborhood spirit and police-community partnerships; and (4) Send a message to criminals letting them know that neighborhoods are organized and fighting back.

Along with the traditional outside lights and front porch vigils, most cities and towns celebrate National Night Out with a variety of special citywide and neighborhood events such as block parties, cookouts, parades, festivals, visits from local officials and law enforcement, safety fairs, and youth events.

The city of Santa Clara is supporting NNO and there is no cost. I have the permit for the street closure. I'll ask residents to bring a dessert or beverage to share. Our drum circle group will supply the instruments to play.


So, if an evening of drumming on a well lit street as part of a neighborhood block party sounds interesting, please RSVP so we will have a good strong group. 20 or more would be fantastic.


Handicap access is easy. Dogs allowed. Restrooms available in my house. Extra drums and percussion instruments are usually available but not guaranteed.
name: Drumming in the Street - National Night Out (#2)

Dr. and Master Zhi Gang Sha is a soul leader, an extraordinary healer, and a divine servant. Trained as an MD in China and a doctor of traditional Chinese medicine in China and Canada, he created Power Healing and Soul Mind Body Medicine to combine the essence of Western medicine and traditional Chinese medicine with ancient energy and spiritual healing secrets from China.

The founder of the Institute of Soul Healing and Enlightenment, Dr. Sha is a grandmaster of many ancient disciplines, including tai chi, qi gong, feng shui, and the I Ching. He was named Qigong Master of the Year at the Fifth World Congress on Qigong. An inspired guide in his Soul Power Series of best-selling books, TV programs, and other teachings and services, Dr. Sha says, “Heal and transform the soul first; then healing and transformation of every aspect of life will follow”. In 2006, Dr. Sha was granted the Martin Luther King, Jr. Commemorative Commission Award for his humanitarian efforts.

I consider Master Sha’s healing path to be a universal spiritual practice, a journey into genuine transformation.

Founder, Agape International Spiritual Center

description:
Livermore Civic Library ~ ~ Community Room A ~ ~ 1188 South Livermore Avenue, Livermore

Enter the Main Entrance, turn RIGHT - The Community Room A is on the right, across from the restrooms. ~~If you go to the main part of the library, or the Information Desk, you've gone too far.~~ It's just inside the Main Entrance doors, to the right.

Directions to Civic Center, 1188 South Livermore Avenue, from I-580: Take the N. Livermore Avenue Exit, head South toward the center of Livermore. Civic Center Library is 2.5 miles from the N. Livermore exit on the left hand side of the street. College Avenue is the nearest cross street. City Hall & the Police Station are on the left immediately before the Library.

[masked] Kim's phone

Enhance Your Own Power By Integrating Your Intuitive Skills

7:00 - 7:20 a free one-question mini-reading **

7.20 - 8.00 - Channeling / Lecture

8.00 - 8.30 - Intuitive Interactive and/or Q&A

8.30 - 8.50 - Guided (often channeled)

Meditation Cash/Check at the door or PayPal before the meeting. Bring your receipt, please.

**(in order of arrival; due to meeting time, there is a small possibility there won't be enough time for all people to be read, depending on the number of people in attendance.)

Class teacher & channeler is me, Kim Kristiansson. I've been teaching since the 1980's. I am a professional psychic & medium. I was 15 before I found out everyone didn't use their intuition! My only reaction was, "Why not??!!"

Intrigued by this, I started my (ongoing) investigation & study of metaphysics, philosophy, & humankind's Quest for spiritual connection. I come from a family who took psychic happenings in stride (I am a 7th generation clairsentient on my mother's side) & a Catholic going to Catholic school. The Universe had me live in high-energy environments (i.e. over a former POW camp in Guam & in a Berlin barracks -site of a bloody coup attempt between different factions of Nazis). I often spontaneously channeled at some length - details that couldn't be found any other apparent way. Neither of these things were explained or encouraged by Church doctrine -So I kept investigating - & practicing. My studies took me more than half-way around the world, to many disciplines & several renowned & wise teachers, including one of Sylvia Browne's mentors, & being "adopted" by a hereditary Kahuna while still in grade-school. I am grateful to Charlie, Kevin Reyerson, S. Bartlett, Hans King & Nick Nocerino for their guidance & encouragement. I also studied with the Spiritual Science Church. Every night since I was three, my mother would practice telepathy with me, using a deck of playing cards at the kitchen table. Since all the neighborhood kids' moms played Bridge, I thought everyone played the "telepathy game" after dinner. Boy, was I surprised! I was in my 40's when I found out there was a trick to a magic trick which was popular in my childhood; until then, I thought you picked the correct card by intuition & psychometry. After doing Palmistry, I moved to doing Psychometry (reading energy off of objects -from car keys to Stonehenge stones), & now do what are called "Cold Readings" (reading the energy of the person or events without the aid of anything else, such as Tarot, crystal balls, etc.)

I have used my psychic & remote viewing capabilities for police, the National Security Agency, Military Intelligence, and other Agencies.

I feel strongly that intuition is a powerful tool in daily but most of us have not been guided to develop it or taught how to trust our own abilities.

For more info: www.WhispersInTheWinds.com. Our purpose is a focused gathering to share in spiritual awareness and most importantly, the awareness of your own connectedness. A safe place for practice & validation of your own innate psychic & metaphysical abilities. Intuition is a powerful tool in daily life & as magical & ordinary as any of our senses, but most of us have not been guided to develop it or taught how to trust our own abilities. In this new century, it is becoming essential for us all to live the most balanced and integrated lives possible. In Authentic and compassionate living, it is necessary to synthesize wisdom, logic & feeling, as well as deepening understanding.

For more info: www.WhispersInTheWinds.com

description:
The group meets at the Palo Alto Art Center, http://www.paacf.org/, which is located at 1313 Newell Road, Palo Alto.

The models come from the Palo Alto Models Guild.  Unfortunately they don't have a web site but do have a facebook page, but they are a long standing source of artists' models for the San Francisco Bay Area.  They range in age and body type making for an interesting and different experience everytime you go.

Model time is 7:15 pm and ends at 9:45.  We begin with five 2 minute poses and two 5 minute poses, then we go to two 10 minutes poses.  After these, each pose last 20 minutes untill the end of the night.  There is a short break every 20 minutes and tipping the model is very much encouraged.

Dry and water based mediums are most appreciated, as these are the easiest to clean up.  This being an interim facility an appreciation and respect of these borrowed facilities is needed so we do not lose the use of this space.  We all pitch in at the end of the session in order to put the facility back into its previous or better condition.

All that being said, please come and enjoy yourself, while stretching your figure drawing legs.
how_to_find_us: If having problems don't hesitate to contact me through my profile or give me a call at 1-650-773-2057.  I can usually be found at the nearby Peets at least an hour before model time.
why: A traditional single nude model drawing session run by volunteers that has been going on for decades.  Populated by artists of varying abilities and ages, some still in high school.  The group is fun and supportive and the cost is just $8.
name: Palo Alto Life Drawing

description:
This adventure follows up directly outside the Cairn of the Winter King.

Old characters are with the party to start.  New characters will be quickly introduced.

The following characters will not be coming on this adventure:  Kirra, Amaris, Samhayne.


Here are the guidelines:

• Characters should be Level 6.


• Characters that start with the Ritual Caster feat should have the rituals they start with in Level 1.  Additional rituals may be purchased with the 1000 gold available (see below).


• Upload updated (Level 6) character sheet pdf's here (probably replace the old versions).  I'll use the info to customize some of the story, encounters and loot.

• New characters should use the following guidelines:

        Level 10 Weapon
        Level 6 Armor
        Level 5 Slot Item
        1000 gold for purchases (changed from 840g)
        1 additional Level 6 Item

Mundane equipment valued at less than 50g can be had for free; purchase equipment valued at 50g or more.


• Returning characters can purchase items using gold they had before the start of Cairn of the Winter King.  They can add items they hadn't added according to initial Level 5 guidelines.  Unless anyone has strong objections, returning characters can tweak themselves as they wish outside the normal leveling limits now that the players have some experience with how their characters play.

• Wishlists - those who don't have enough gold to buy everything they'd like or those who want a particular item or ritual for their character can send me a wishlist and I'll try to work it into loot for the adventure.


For any new players:


Please check Resources for links to a free character builder and a pdf of the Player's Handbook.


What to bring:

• Your printed character sheets, we want to keep this analog.

• A pencil w/ an eraser and some extra paper.

• A set of 7 die dice!  You can get these online or somewhere like Gamestop.

• Player Handbooks and miniatures if you have them. 

Lastly

We have some really great people with a lot of experience in this group.  Please feel free to ask questions on this thread or in the Discussion area.  You will only get great advice. 

Hope to see you soon!
name: The Howling

From Goodreads.com:

There is a clarity, elegance, and beauty to Conway's Road From Coorain that places it firmly at the apogee of autobiography along with such masterpieces as West With the Night by Beryl Markham, or An American Childhood , by Annie Dillard.

From the first sentence, you will be drawn inexorably into the story of her childhood in New South Wales, Australia, and her gradual discovery of—and by—the larger world: the clarity of Conway's language satisfies like cold clear water after a day in the desert: the rhythm of her sentences has a timelessness and expansiveness akin to the Australian landscape itself. This is very likely a book you will remember the rest of your life. 


From Publishers Weekly:

At age 11, Conway left the arduous life on her family's sheep farm in the Australian outback for school in war-time Sydney, burdened by an emotionally dependent, recently widowed mother. A lively curiosity and penetrating intellect illuminate this unusually objective account of the author's progress from a solitary childhood--the most appealing part of the narrative--to public achievement as president of Smith College and now professor at MIT. Gifted with an ability to adapt to a wide range of cultures and people and despite ingrained Australian prejudice against intellectuals, Conway devoted herself to the study of history and literature, spurred on by excellent British-style schooling.
how_to_find_us: We'll all be holding the book!
name: Let's Discuss: The Road From Coorain by Jill Ker Conway

description:
Speaker: Juval Löwy

Abstract: The sad reality is that Agile in the wild is often abused as a cynical way of avoiding the right things. Other times teams just go through the motions, having no idea what they mean. More than a decade after the Agile Manifesto, as an industry, we are no better off. Many have never seen a good Agile project that meet its commitments or promises, and bad Agile lets people assume that because they can't do it then it can't be done. Without knowing the true cost and schedule of the project, companies cannot make educated decisions and are literally playing poker without looking at the cards. Furthermore, poor Agile lets practitioners skirt the issue of not knowing how to do system and project design, pretend design is not needed or is even bad. In this candid, somber, and entertaining session Juval will reflect on what is wrong with the common way of doing Agile, identify the fallacies and misconceptions, the consequences of bad Agile, explain why people fail to do it right, the patterns the fall into, and what you can and must do about it, to prosper and BE agile. Juval will show how combining Agile with architecture and project design yields an excellent construction process delivering on schedule and on budget every time. 


Note: Upon arrival at Intel, park on the 2nd level of parking garage D behind building SC12. Follow the connecting bridge from the garage to the security desk for guest check in. Guest check in requires identification and an Intel employee (Robert Zych).
name: Agile: The bad, the ugly and the good

description:
TurnON: [turn{on}]  


verb (something that happens in the body)

To raise the body heat, leaving the individual feeling as though they may perspire

To feel tingles in random parts of the body, letting the individual know those parts are awake

To encounter cheeks getting flushed, often leaving the individual feel seen

To ignite, as to feel more alive and alert

TurnON occurs from many different things. Maybe you saw someone you thought was cute. Maybe you had an inappropriate thought cross your mind.

Maybe you saw something that inspired or even pissed you off. Many things/people/conversations leave us with this ignited feeling in our body. (yes, deep down we all like the feeling of TurnON!) You know it's TurnON because it ignites -- as though your body is giving you a cue, shouting out "I'm ALIVE in here"!

TurnON leaves you feeling more alert, ignited and happy.

At OneTaste, we believe TurnON is the ignition that leads to a more of what we really want in life. We believe it is the first step to knowing what is possible.

So, we started an evening event designed specifically to give people the opportunity to feel TurnON in themselves. (p.s., it's totally PG-13) It's an evening where, through only talking, we begin to experience these exhilarating, normal, often ignored feelings -- referred to as TurnON. A room of people (cool, fun people) engage in honest, humorous, playful conversation around topics we mostly only consider having in our head.

TurnOn leads to authenticity and authenticity leads to the kind of connection we hope for around the globe.

The evening leaves you invigorated, happy and inspired. We are meant to live TurnedON.


Details:
Singles & Couples Welcome
This event is $10
how_to_find_us: On the corner of N Pacific Ave and River St, downtown Santa Cruz
name: TurnON Santa Cruz
Beer.js SF

description:
American Me Comedy presents Ben Gleib from Chelsea Lately!

RSVP AT [masked] FOR CONFIRMATION.


THIS IS BEN GLEIB'S ONLY SAN FRANCISCO APPEARANCE THIS YEAR!

LAST SHOW WAS SOLD OUT!


Ben Gleib: An actor, stand up comedian, satirist, and writer, Gleib was called by Esquire one of "the six comedians who could be comedy's next big things" and part of a "a bumper crop of brilliant new-alt comics".


Gleib was the voice of Sid the Sloth’s younger brother Marshall in ”Ice Age: Continental Drift,” which is now the #1 animated movie of all-time internationally! He is a regular round table guest on the E! late night talk show Chelsea Lately, and has been appearing on the show since January 2008.  He is a frequent guest on KPCC (Southern California's NPR affiliate) on the Patt Morrison Program, bringing his comedic spin to political issues. He also reported for KPCC live from the 2008 Republican National Convention in St. Paul, Minnesota. He starred in the NBC series The Real Wedding Crashers, a prime time comedy that aired on the network Mondays at 10pm, with the show Heroes as a lead-in. The show also aired on BRAVO and STYLE Network. In 2009 he performed his standup on NBC's Last Call with Carson Daly, and in 2008, Gleib was featured on the NBC competition show Last Comic Standing. He is known for covering a wide range of topics in his act, including political and social commentary, but is also known for his improvisational skills, often making up large sections of his performance based on interactions with the crowd. A recent review of his stand up said "His persona has evolved to a satirical high...his act is laden with material that pays every time.“ In 2006, he sold a pilot called The Gleib Show to Fox, produced by Saturday Night Live creator Lorne Michaels, Broadway Video, and NBC/Universal. This show was based on a TV show that Gleib directed, wrote, and starred in for three seasons on the National Lampoon Network from 2003–2005, which aired to college campuses across the country, and was consistently the network's number one show. It was also written and produced by Scot Richardson. The show was based on a show of the same title that Gleib did for four years during his time as an undergrad at the University of California, San Diego. At UCSD he studied Communications and Theater, and graduated in the Honors Thesis Program. He was a commencement speaker at his graduation. Ben Gleib appears in a supporting role in the feature film Bar Starz, which had a limited theatrical release. The film also featured Charlie Murphy, Daniel Franceze, Derek Waters, John Bernthal, and Nikki Griffin. In addition, Gleib has performed on The Late Late Show on CBS, at the Vancouver Comedy Festival, the Laughing Matters Festival in the Netherlands, hosted several pods for Current TV, and in 2002 wrote the "Radio Music Awards" for ABC.

If you haven't seen an "American Me Comedy Show" then you're definitely missing out! Very funny line-up of comics will be performing including myself! We've had comics that have been on Comedy Central, HBO, Showtime, The Late Show With David Letterman, The Tonight Show, Conan, The Late, Late, Show With Craig Ferguson, America's Got Talent, and regulars on Chelsea Lately so make sure to catch this show because you never know who might pop in!!!

American Me Comedy will be an evening of the best stand up comedy featuring today's hottest working comics from all walks of life - race, color, religion, sexual orientation - sharing their unique and hilarious perspectives on life experiences.
