description:
Solve the most important problem -- in new and different ways!

This week you will develop, write and present entirely new and exciting stories and scenarios to solve your customer's problems.


Thinking on the fly / Being spontaneous

* Use what happened to you today.
* Using someone else’s story
* Relate to actual audience scenarios
* And many more custom story ideas you can use right away.


If you're ready to take your presentation to the most effective point ever, don't miss this week's very special SPEAKER JAM on Thursday, August 7th.  You'll learn the best ways to get the attention of your audience and deliver your message with clarity, purpose and enthusiasm.


The world's most effective speakers, communicators and change agents overcome their fear of speaking, target their ideal audience, and then follow-up. If you want to achieve your greatest success ever, you'll definitely benefit from our special "Develop More Stories" Speaker Jam on Thursday, August 7th.


Come on now, you deserve comfort, clarity and ease in front of any audience. My Speaker Jam participants tell their personal story in a way that connects them to their audience with IMPACT! They're becoming experts in delivering their message authentically and passionately.

Speaker Jam speakers are HAPPY SPEAKERS!

You can do this. You can actually enjoy yourself in front of an audience and motivate them with enthusiasm and brilliance and clarity. You ARE a great speaker. Remember, I want this for you. I care about you. Come join me and find out for yourself how easy public speaking can be. Speaker Jams are also perfect training for:

                     * Speaker presentations             * Personal relationships
                             * One-on-one                                  * Elevator speech
                                     * Meeting someone for the first time

And don't forget, if this is your first time, you receive a Free Flash Drive with a video recording of your presentation (to be really effective, you must watch yourself). And for returning Jammers, be sure to bring your flash drive with you. It's an incredibly powerful tool.      

                                  THURSDAY, August 7th, 7:00 - 9:00 p.m
                                       91 Lafayette Circle, Lafayette

            **BONUS - BRING A FIRST-TIME GUEST FOR JUST $20

Mark your calendar . . . 

Wouldn't you like a discount? Well, here's great news. You can sign up for a 7 session package for the price of 6 -- save $70.00. Go to:

Speaking Fearlessly Speaker Jam Package.

Sign up now, don't miss any more opportunities. Blast through those speaker myths that are holding you back and share your story with the world. It's time to shine!


Pam Whitman

description:
These meetups are community based and focused. The Beginner track is for someone with little to no experience with OpenStack. You can be just interested in expanding your devOps horizons or someone that just wants to learn more about this cloud thing. The Intermediate/Hackathon track is for a experienced devOps, some python experience, and an understanding of OpenStack core. Some advanced OpenStack devOps will join the hackathon from time to time. The Advanced track is for seasoned OpenStack devOps to discuss blueprints and code. Each Advanced devOps meetup will focus on a different OpenStack core project.

Beginner track in the Pioneer room. Mirantis will be leading the discussion. Video and audio access via WebEx at https://yahoomeetings.webex.com/yahoomeetings/j.php?ED=160663867&UID=492396097&RT=MiM0 Intermediate/Hackathon track in the Point Dexter room on different days generally than the beginner meetups. We may have advanced OpenStack devOps on hand for designing, coding, or advice. Go to the Intermediate/Hackathon meetup page for more information. Advanced/Topic specific track will be held in San Francisco out of the Seagate/EVault offices on a generally monthly basis. You will find topic specific events here. Drink, food, whiteboards and wifi provided by Yahoo!

Updates will be published via the meetup email list, OpenStack community blog, and twitter via @sarob
how_to_find_us: right at the stop sign. right at the guard shack. pull around back to the garage. park on the 3rd floor. Walk through the door and turn right to the pioneer room.

description:
Discover The Secrets of Success Behind Property Procurement

You have finally decided to get into real estate game, or maybe you decided to step up your game and make things happen; at this month’s SJREI meeting discover the secrets behind successful property procurement and what the pro’s at Prodesse Properties know for sure,  specifically President Michael Pierce, prominent leader of one of  the most successful property management companies (& investor himself) in the Bay Area

At this meeting you will learn:

- Evaluating properties for purchase - what really matters?

- Due Diligence through the eyes of a pro

- How to strategically minimize expenses - a key success principle when investing

- Who should your ally’s be in the process (strategic alliances)

- Physical inspection - how to do these through the eyes of a pro

- What numbers are relevant to your purchase decision and how you dissect those for accuracy?

- Finally negotiation and execution  and specific examples to illustrate all of the above?

Note from Ger, founder of SJREI:

"I don’t know anybody who can articulate so clearly and completely on this topic as Michael, he has shared so much relevant timely information with us in the past not a simple property management presentation - his information is content rich and powerful. No Power Point just straight up solid info and data.”


Michael Pierce is the co-founder and President of Prodesse Property Group. Michael has over 30 years experience managing property in California and Washington. He has been active in the management, operation, acquisition, renovation and construction of apartments since 1979. Prior to founding Prodesse Property Group, Michael was a member of the management team at Essex Property Trust in Palo Alto, California.

Michael served as the 2009 President of the California Apartment Association(CAA) and has been active on the CAA Board of Directors for over 18 years. He also has been a member of the Board of Directors of the CAA Tri-County Division since 1991 and served as its President in 1997. Michael also serves on the Board of Directors of the St. Francis Center and the San Mateo County Colleges Educational Housing Corporation.

SJREI's August Meeting is Information-Packed

Thursday, August 7th, 2014. The Domain Hotel: Sunnyvale, 7PM.

Come join us for a night of fun, education, networking and connections. Learn from the best in the business and grow as a landlord, investor and financial whiz!

See you soon, friends!

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

YOUR MEETING DETAILS

Online pre-registration is now REQUIRED for all members and guests to ensure that we have enough seating and can safely accommodate all our attendees.

 All SJREI Members, Register By Clicking Here.

All non-members can register by clicking here.

MEETING DATE/TIME: August 7th, @ 7:00pm

MEETING LOCATION: The Domain Hotel, Sunnyvale  // 1085 E El Camino Real

CHECK-IN: opens at 6:30pm

MEETING: begins promptly at 7:00pm

Please direct all inquiries to Hannah: [masked]

group.name: Classic Literature and Cafes Book Club

description:
"Geoffrey Firmin, a former British consul, has come to Quauhnahuac, Mexico. His debilitating malaise is drinking, an activity that has overshadowed his life. On the most fateful day of the consul's life, his wife Yvonne arrives in Quauhnahuac, inspired by a vision of life together away from Mexico and the circumstances that have driven their relationship to the brink of collapse. She is determined to rescue Firmin and their failing marriage, but her mission is further complicated by the presence of Hugh, the consul's half brother, and Jacques, a childhood friend. The events of this one significant day unfold against an unforgettable backdrop of a Mexico at once magical and diabolical.

Under the Volcano remains one of literature's most powerful and lyrical statements on the human condition, and a brilliant portrayal of one man's constant struggle against the elemental forces that threaten to destroy him."
name: Malcolm Lowry's "Under the Volcano"

Now monthly at Balancoire, we continue to be your one-stop shop for Retro Futurism. Musically, we feature the best of Steampunk and Boom Swing, socially we're a weekly costume party, dance night and affinity group meetup all rolled into one.

The Electric SwingSet is an alternative dance floor from a past that never existed. We play traditional music, non-traditionally and we dance to have fun! It's the dance party of "all times" where the swing goes BOOM and "Steam" fills the room!

We provide the opportunity to dress up, socialize, dance and play. The only thing it's missing is you!!!

About the Class:

Come to this class and learn how to make a mobile application. This class teaches the process of making cross platform mobile apps. It is simpler than you think; no prior programming experience necessary. 

Attendees to this class will get equipped with the tools necessary for Mobile Application Development. 

Learn to make applications for:

Android

iOS (iPhone and iPad)

mobile web

Don’t miss out on this awesome opportunity!

75 % of all Smart Phones in the World are Android Devices

15 % of all Smart Phones in the World are iOS Devices

Please remember to bring your laptop

Please follow the directions on the confirmation page

Before Class 

Please follow the directions on the confirmation page

~~~~

Who is this class for?

This class is for everyone; no prior programming knowledge or experience required.

~~~~

Why should you take this class?

You should take this class because technology is a very important part of every business and knowing technology will give you an edge. Regardless of if you plan on making mobile apps yourself or you plan on working with someone to make a mobile app. This class will empower you with useful tools that are required for success in the app world.

~~~~

What will you learn?

The objective of this class is to set you in the right direction for Mobile Application Development.

1. We will set you up with the tools necessary for mobile app development

2. You will learn about the interface of the software development kit

3. You will get an overview of the various options available for app development

4. You will learn about app planning; how to put it all together

5. You will do exercises and make applications in class

6. You will learn about the mobile industry 

~~~~

About the instructors:    This class is taught by the combined effort of 2-3 instructors depending on the class size; all instructors work in the technology industry.

~~~~

~~~

Please bring your laptop!

~~~

description:
Join us for free at one of our highly-innovative business-networking meetings - in your city! View our full calendar of business-networking meetings. We welcome anyone to attend a GoRampUp! meeting, once, for free as our guest, so you can learn what the innovative GoRampUp! business-networking experience is all about. Note, we are not able to give you a free meeting at more than one of our many locations.

YOU MUST obtain a free-access GoRampUp! Golden ticket by registering for a specific meeting athttp://GoRampUp.com/calendar/. This ticket must be presented at your complimentary meeting for you to gain admittance. Without this ticket you will, unfortunately, be declined access to our innovative and exclusive business-networking meeting. WITH a GoRampUp! Golden Ticket, you will be welcomed with open arms!

It can be too difficult to attract new clients. We help you fix that! We're a business-impact community. We're informal and fun, yet, by design, we're extremely effective!

We help people who work for a living to get a much greater payoff from working. We do this in three specific ways under our three CoreSuccess Platforms: 1) We help you move toward mastery with business-networking, 2) We help you move toward mastery with business performance, and, 3) We help you move toward mastery with personal development.

How do we deliver on this promise to our community members? Each month we conduct dozens of business-networking meetings in more than a dozen cities in the SF Bay Area. A member may attend all of our "OpenConnect" business-networking meetings. And our members are welcome and encouraged to attend any and all of these meetings and locations.

Each month we introduce and emphasize a learning and development subject under each of our three CoreSuccess Platforms. For each of the three learning and development subjects that we introduce and emphasize each month, we give you four different ways to learn it: We produce written learning guides, video learning guides, audio learning guide, and we cover the subjects as 15-to-20-minute mini-workshops inside of our 60-minute business-networking meetings. There's no registration or initiation fee to join. Membership in GoRampUp! is month to month. You enroll when you like, even mid-month, and you depart when you like.

Be sure to see our website to learn about our generous enrollment incentives

Also, be sure to learn about our 100-Satisfaction Money-Back Guarantee

Would you care to come to this meeting, at no cost, to see if there’s business-value for you?

• Free-Meeting Guest-RSVP and Golden Ticket Request

• View complete meeting details

• Invite a Buddy to join you

One last thing: You REALLY should check out actual testimonial videos by our members: See them here

This page was created to produce awareness of our event. However, OUR PAGES ON THIS SITE CAN BECOME OUTDATED. The authoritative source for our meeting dates/times is http://www.GoRampUp.com/calendar. Be sure to check it prior to traveling to a meeting.

description:
Women Wine and Wisdom about relationship building, helping, building alliances, learning. It’s about growing and masterminding in a casual fun way.

 

Here is what one member said about this event: "I love the unconventional networking Ann inspires! It's more like a matchmaking session! Always educational and sassy!"

This opportunity allows women to come together, get REAL, and RAW. To learn and grow. To step into their unlimited space and potential.

Currently I hold these in my home, we believe we attract the right women to participate! I live in the North East bay, off I80 Hilltop area, easy to get to from San Rafael, Vallejo, Walnut Creek and El Cerrito (address will be given to those that are registered, if you have been before, you know where!). We have a beautiful 9000 square foot urban garden, and a comfy home we love. The address and driving directions will be sent to registered guests the THURSDAY morning prior to the event.


Agenda:

3:30-4:30 arrive, grab a glass, informal networking, nosh, help set up, wander in the garden, avoid traffic (YAY!)

4:30-6:30 Warrior Women and Wisdom Networking Round, get ready, get real, get laughter, get love--get connecting!Networking, relationship building with smart intention, fun, laughter maybe even a tear or two! What makes this special is it isn't just "pass your cards and flyers"!

6:30-7 free to leave at 7...often we dig deeper as my hubby comes home and learn from a male perspective...or we just after party)

$25 to attend. Includes visibility for YOUR business, relationship building, community, wine and snacks. Bring your business cards, wear something casual (no spiked high heels on the hardwood please)

Do you have to drink wine to attend? Of course not, there will be non-alcoholic choices. We encourage everyone be responsible. Please note, I do not offer refunds or transfers. I cost of food and wine is spent based on your RSVP and cannot be saved for the next event.

 Please note that the address and directions are emailed the THURSDAY beofre the event.
name: Women, Wine and Wisdom!

description:
Levi's Stadium -- the new home of the San Francisco 49ers -- opens for tours on August 8, so join us for this private group tour and be one of the first to see the completed stadium. We'll start the event with a visit to the onsite 49ers museum where we will see the five Super Bowl trophies!


Schedule
4pm: Meet at Levi's Stadium outside the 49ers museum entrance
4:15pm: Enter 49ers museum
5:10pm: Regroup at Intel Gate A (located at the northwest corner of the stadium)
5:30pm: Guided stadium tour begins
7pm: Guided stadium tour ends

I had to prepay for this 20-person group tour. Your $35/person payment includes the discounted museum entry + stadium tour (normally $42.25/person for non-group individuals with included Ticketmaster fees) and reservation costs.

Items to bring: comfortable walking shoes, camera (of course!)

Official Tour Description
Levi’s® Stadium public tour destinations include the Main Concourse (300 level), Champion’s Club, NRG Solar Terrace, locker room, Gold Rush Cheerleaders’ locker room, BNY Mellon Club, and Michael Mina’s Bourbon Steak & Pub restauraunt.

The home of the 49ers will be the stage for the team’s next generation of tradition and glory. Now is the time to get an insider’s look at the state-of-the-art venue. Learn how the stadium created the ultimate fan experience through innovation and technology. From the playing field to the rooftop, understand how the building is the smartest and greenest in all of the NFL and be surprised as you walk the interiors viewing the amazing custom art collection featured throughout the building. Levi’s® Stadium is not your typical sports venue.

Parking is free in the Northeast corner of the Great America Lot and the Parking Structure off of Tasman. Parking availability is first come first served and subject to change.

Official Museum Description
The 49ers Museum Presented By Sony features 11 unique gallery and exhibit spaces. Your journey will begin in the main lobby at the Trending gallery, where you will learn what’s new with the team and our space. From there you’ll move to the Morabito Theater to watch the 49ers signature film and then into the Edward J. DeBartolo, Sr. 49ers Hall of Fame where you’ll walk amongst the 49ers greats. Our Heritage Gallery innovatively illuminates the history of the team through artifacts and multimedia exhibits and leads perfectly into the active In the Game gallery on the lower level. Your visit will end reliving the memories of our five Super Bowl Championships in front of the Lombardi trophies.

Levi's Stadium site

Levi's Stadium tour article


----- 
Please be considerate of your fellow members and the host managing the event and/or reservation: If you RSVP "Yes" but are unable to attend, change your RSVP to "No" before the stated RSVP closing date. If you don't, you will be marked as a no show. Members are allowed two no shows: after that, you will be wait listed for future events or dropped from the group.
how_to_find_us: Meet in front of the 49ers Museum
name: Levi's Stadium: Private Tour of the 49ers' New Home

description:
Sign-ups close: Monday, 7/14. 


Rugged mountains with gorgeous trails through dense, cool forest.  All levels and non-cycling friends and family welcome. 

Camping on Friday and Saturday nights.  Guided ride on Saturday.  Non guided ride on Sunday. 

PLEASE DO NOT RSVP UNTIL YOU HAVE PAID FOR YOUR RESERVATION


PLEASE READ EVERYTHING HERE BEFORE ASKING QUESTIONS


(But ask away if needed - I'm happy to answer)


Campsite: The guide has set up a special arrangement with State Parks just for us - the parks are trying out allowing mtbers stay at an under-used horse camp.  We'll have the entire camp just for ourselves!   It's accessible to an awesome network of trails so we can have a car-free weekend and ride to our rides.  Mostly in the shade.  Once you make a reservation, I'll add you to the RSVP list and the location of campsite will be sent to you .

• No drinking water or showers.  Non potable water available.  Pit toilets.  No fires allowed.  Dogs allowed in camp but not on trails (bummer).  Must be on leash.


Details: Everyone must make and pay for a reservation through links below.  Choices of reservations include:  1) advanced ride + 2 nights camping  2) intermediate ride + 2 nights camping  3) 2 nights camping only. 


The two guided rides are for Saturday only.  If you want a guided ride at a level not offered here feel free to contact the guide service and make your own arrangements. Same thing if you want a guided ride on Sunday. We figured, once we get one guided ride, then we'll be able to plan our own ride for the next day. 

Guided rides descriptions: Optional.  You do not have to go on a guided or any ride to camp with us.  Both on Saturday.   Bring LOTS of water and food on the rides.  (Please don't show up at a ride start unprepared and then become a burden to your ride companions.  It can ruin a ride.  Been there; done that.) Required: Helmet, tools, tube.


• Advanced: 4 hours, 20-25 miles, fast pace (8 mph avg), short regroups.  Should have the skills to ride over some tricky bits but nothing death defying. 


• Intermediate: 4 hours, 15-20 miles, moderate pace (6 mph avg.), short regroups, time allowed to walk over obstacles. 


Reservations for rides + camping or camping only: Choose one of the "Hubbard Party" links. https://squareup.com/market/mendocino-bike-sprite-llc

Schedule: Can arrive anytime on Friday starting at 5:00 p.m.  Alex and I will arrive around 8:00 p.m.  Saturday:  morning: guided rides leave by 9:00 a.m.  Anyone not going on a guided ride can do whatever they want.  Enjoy!  Afternoon/evening: nothing planned but sloth.  We'll be hanging out at camp, snoozing, drinking beer and eating.  Please join us.  Sunday: non guided intermediate ride will leave by 9:00 a.m. You're welcome to organize a ride of a different level or do your own thing.  We'll be heading home sometime 3:00 - 5:00.  You can stay as long as you want.  Leave too early and you hit Marin County traffic. 

Trails description: Have ridden on only a few of the trails in this area but here's what I saw: twisty, mostly smooth dirt, some slick areas covered in pine needles, not a lot of rock/gravel or technical stuff.  Some logs.  A little bit of mud.  Heavily forested, lots of brush.  Some poison oak, prickly berry vines and stinging nettles.  I wear knee socks.

Esprit de corps:  we're quiet, early to bed/early to rise kinda folks.  If you're not, you may not want to hang with us.  We respect the natural environment and leave nothing but tire prints/take nothing but memories.  We don't use soap in or near streams/ponds.

State Parks is taking a chance on us, let's show'm mountain bikers are desirable tourists.


See you there!  Winona
name: Mendocino campout with optional guided rides

description:
This event will start at 5:30 p.m. and end at 7:30 p.m.

"A Genuine Networking Association Event!"

Please join our organization's facebook group page where we mastermind in between meetings at:

http://www.facebook.com/groups/genuinenetworkingassociation

Please also join our organization's facebook fan page at:

http://www.facebook.com/gnanetwork

Come to Interactive Fridays @ The Beverly Heritage Hotel Every Second Friday of the month, and meet your next power partners or possible clients!

THIS IS A FREE NETWORKING OPPORTUNITY!!!

Looking for a simple way to connect with people? At Interactive Fridays, you can mix and mingle with great people at your own pace and with no pressure. You will not be forced to give an introduction or presentation.

Many business professionals have done some of their best business over a glass of wine, beer, and some great food, and Interactive Fridays provides this fantastic atmosphere!

At this event, we have several "fireside chats" happening as well. A fireside chat is when there are more than two people engaged in a discussion. Another way to describe a fireside chat is like a one on one meeting on steroids! What a great way to manage your time by getting to "DEEPLY" know several great professionals at once!!!

Please join us every second Friday of the month to expand your resources, allow us to help further your power partnerships, and even possibly help you find your next clients!

Food and drinks will be available for purchase.

For your convenience, The Beverly Heritage Hotel will provide a no host bar and a special food menu. Click the link below to access the menu.

http://161.58.50.222/linked/Interactive_Fridays_Bar_Menu.pdf

Happy Hour Special $4.50 Margarita Fiesta (House Well Only)

Blue Plate Special: Nachos / Grande Beef Supreme $12.95/plate(Includes 1 Glass of House Wine or Draft Beer)

Come join us for some good old fashioned networking at The Beverly Heritage Hotel!

We are here to primarily help San Francisco Bay Area Business Professionals meet their next power partners or clients at no cost or obligation. We also welcome any wonderful and like-minded business professionals from anywhere in Northern California. We are willing to help these people outside of our immediate area in the same way as if you were here in our local San Francisco Bay Area communities. What makes us truly genuine is that we have no hidden agendas. We are here to sincerely help you from the heart!

The Genuine Networking Association was created to provide San Francisco Bay Area Business Professionals with an affordable alternative to meeting other like-minded business professionals. FREE NETWORKING!!! :-) We understand during these trying times that not everyone can afford to spend a lot of money on networking. Also, while we are not discouraging other groups, we feel that you don't need to spend a lot of money or waste your time at other events, that are not going to be the most productive use of your time and financial investment.

Genuine Networking Association website link:

http://www.genuinenetworkingassociation.com
name: Interactive Fridays @ The Beverly Heritage Hotel - Milpitas

description:
Have you ever felt imprisoned in your desire for someone to love you? Do you find yourself wanting something different or something more?  It can be so painful when you're looking for your happiness within a romantic relationship and it's not delivering.


If you want to finally find some peace with that loved-one you've always struggled with, whether you're with them or not, this workshop is for you!  Join us and spend the weekend in a warm atmosphere doing The Work with Susan Vielguth, certified facilitator, and Amelia Chenoweth, certification candidate, bringing our most stressful thoughts about relationships to inquiry.    Through a series of powerful exercises you will leave with an in-depth understanding on how to do The Work on your own.

Schedule:

August 8, Friday 7:00pm - 9:00pm

August 9, Saturday 9:00am - 6:00pm

August 10, Sunday 9:30am - 5:00pm

179 Ridgeway Avenue


Fairfax, CA, 94930

-Byron Katie

description:
Souk Savanh is one of the authentic Lao restaurants that lie within the "Little Saigon" area of Oakland (with International Blvd x East 12th St as its epicenter). Little Laos bleeds a little more into Fruitvale.

Souk has greater scale than Sticky Rice Cafe, is more polished than Vien Tian Cafe with its earthier flavors, and is not to be confused with the fusion offerings of the more popular Champa Garden. You won't find "Laos Tacos" here. Instead, you'll find the most extensive menu of purely Laotian offerings, in an airy comfortable setting.

Dinner will be banquet style, with a fixed menu. 

If you are interested in carpooling (as opposed to car pooling), make a comment.

Diners should cancel 48 hours in advance to allow vacancies to be filled.

This event is cross-posted to another dining group, for a total of 10 diners. This may affect precedence of RSVP.


Thank you,

Stephen Yeh / Lebeauviolet

description:

Hot Italian Summer DOUBLE FEATURE

presentation

The Decameron

1971 / 112min / colores


"An adaptation of nine stories from Bocaccio's "Decameron": A young man from Perugia is swindled twice in Naples, but ends up rich; a man poses as a deaf-mute in a convent of curious nuns; a woman must hide her lover when her husband comes home early; a scoundrel fools a priest on his deathbed; three brothers take revenge on their sister's lover; a young girl sleeps on the roof to meet her boyfriend at night; a group of painters wait for inspiration; a crafty priest attempts to seduce his friend's wife; and two friends make a pact to find out what happen= s after death. Pasolini is up to his old tricks satirizing the Church, and throwing in liberal doses of life and love."  IMDB

and

Baba Yaga

1973 / 91min / colores


"Strange things have been happening to Valentina, a young and beautiful professional photographer, ever since she made the acquaintance of Baba Yaga, a mysterious older woman who gave her a lift home late one night. For one thing, Valentina has been having weird, kinky nightmares. For another, one of Valentina's cameras seems to have acquired a deadly curse. And then there was that visit to Baba Yaga's house, where Valentina discovered bizarre relics, including a dominatrix doll, and a bottomless pit in the living room. Valentina comes to realize that Baba Yaga is a witch who is out to possess her - body and soul."  IMDB.

Please bring any finger foods, drinks or any other social accoutrements, sans nicotine.

description:
Paranormal Investigation for members only (no guests allowed and no one under the age of 18)

Cost - $55.00 per person (payable at time of RSVP)

This location has never been investigated before. We will have 6 hours to investigate 2 floors, a basement and attic. The house was built in 1876 and is approximately 7,000 Sq. ft. including the attic and basement.  

We will be separated into 2 groups of 6. Please do not wear any perfume, cologne or scented lotions - as it makes it hard to determine phantom smells. Please feel free to bring any equipment except for Ouija boards and headlamp style flashlights. You can bring food and drinks that can be left in the back room, which will be our setup area. There is a refrigerator and microwave available.

Some History:

This is the very first location where I got an awesome picture of a giant orb during a daytime tour. It was back in May 2011. The photo is posted under that event, so check it out if you have time.

There have been several deaths in the house. Most of them just because people back in that time period died at home. There was one tragic death at the house, a young girl (I believe a niece of the family) who was not allowed to attend a party given in the garden. She went up to the attic and was leaning out of the window watching the party and fell to her death. Another family member drowned, at the age of 82, while taking his daily swim in the nearby creek.

All of the family members that were buried on the property were relocated due to the creek flooding. They were moved to Mountain View cemetery in Oakland.

The following are just two places where you can find some history and information.

http://nileshomesweethome.blogspot.com/2010/05/niles-shinn-nurseries.html

http://www.berkeleydailyplanet.com/issue/2010-07-13/article/35838
name: Investigation at Shinn House in Fremont

description:
The ecstatic experience of expression through drumming and vocalization is magnified when we learn how to harmonize with others.  We'll explore a practical methodology for learning the archetypes of rhythm and how they can be used in combination with other players-of-music to help strengthen and heal not only our own energy, but those that are in vicinity of its influence.  

Bring a drum if you have one; bring two if you have one to share.  Bells are also highly recommended because they're much easier to use than a drum.

The time-tested polyrhythmic aesthetic and approach to music is cross-cultural, and along with your devotion and correct practice attracts wellness and augments any practice of stillness.   This session will not be a 'thunder-drum jam,' but more a guided lesson.

I encourage you to bring a recorder to help learn.

description:
Okay everybody, we can totally do this! The route of the Livermore Half Marathon winds 13 miles from Downtown Livermore, through Sycamore Grove and into the beautiful vineyard covered hills of Livermore.

We'll be starting early to beat the heat and doing just under 13 miles total. We are not starting at the official half marathon starting point, instead, we'll meet at the corner of 6th and South K.

We'll break it up with breakfast at the Wente Grille ... which is delicious btw! 

Be sure to bring LOTS of water (we can refill at the halfway point/Wente) and bring cash for your breakfast at the Wente Grille (they won't split the check). 

Note: Don't let the word Marathon scare you ... there is no running or speed-walking allowed on our leisurely half-marathon walk. :)

Check out the basic route below. This is from the official runliv site, so ignore the notations of water stations ... those won't be there. 

Please join us! The more the merrier :)

The map is a little hard to read at this size, so here’s the basic route:

Start at 6th and South K

South on So. L St/Arroyo Rd.

West on Concannon Blvd.

South on Holmes

Brief turn onto Wetmore and then into Sycamore Grove to Wente Grille

BREAKFAST :)

North on Arroyo and then into Holdener’s Park

Turn on Marina Ave and then connect with the Arroyo bike trail that runs beside the Arroyo Mocho Creek.

Back to 6th & South K
name: Let's Walk the Half Marathon Route with Breakfast at Wente Grille

description:
8 am START TIME for this hike   ---  This hike is our 2nd in the series of EBMUD Permit hikes that we are rolling out for the Discovery Hikers to enjoy. My Hope is that each hiker would consider getting one of these permits so the group can continue to explore new uncharted trails in and around the East Bay Hills .  A one year trail Hiking Permit costs just 10 dollars for a year. And wait till you see the trails that we have discovered so far !

                            For EBMUD Trail permit application info

           The proposed route is an 8 mile out and back along a MODERATE rated Difficulty single track and wide open fire trail . Bear Creek Staging - 4 miles out to Overlook Staging Area and 4 miles back to the start. The trail is not especially tough in Steep or Slippery Dirt surfaces , however is a Long Distance of 4 miles out and return on the same trail 4 miles back . Round trip time 3 hours , with a rest break in the middle of the hike . 

      NOTE  : this route Dose NOT allow Dogs on this section of trail , Sorry !

       The Organizers wish to remind each hiker to remember to bring Plenty of drinking Water and wear comfortable shoes made for hiking on loose dirt surfaces. Hiking poles if you use them. Maybe a snack for the halfway rest break. A RESTROOM is available at the halfway break area . Your going to want to bring your camera on this one !

          Please sign up and get your EBMUD hiking Permit so we can get out and check out these Awesome trails along a Beautiful Lake in a lesser traveled trails and share the passion for these weekend hikes !

description:
Details TBA

Trail Running 101


You got questions, we got answers.

Trail Running Shoes- there is a BIG difference between road running sneakers and trail running sneakers. Trail running shoes have much more traction, a close knit upper to keep dirt and water out, and often have a rock plate to protect your foot from the trail. The ease of running trails is increased dramatically by having this type of shoe in your closet. You can get by on most trails with road shoes, but if you think you will be spending a lot of time on the trails it may be worth it to invest in something that will give you some more control over the ground.

Time- Run a 9:00/mile on the road? Be ready to add 1-2 minutes per mile more than your road running when you get on the trails. There are hills, obstacles, and terrain to deal with out there. Don't worry about walking up big hills and running down the other side, that's what the best trail runners do! A good rule of thumb is, if you can't see the top of it, maybe you should walk it. Of course we aren't talking about a leisurely walk here, a power hike can do wonders to get you up that hill without too much fatigue on the legs. When you get to the top, don't completely open up and tear down the hill either. Chances are there is going to be another giant hill you are going to have to climb up and you don't want to kill your legs.

Maps- It's easy to run to run on the bike path without getting into too much trouble, but trails are a bit trickier. Often there are maps provided at the park you may be going to, but it is also a good idea to print out a map ahead of time. In regards to our Trail Meetup, there is ALWAYS a map linked in the Meetup description. Do yourself the favor to take some time to look at the route and what trails you might get confused at. Print it out and bring it with you, along with the turn by turns. If you have any questions about the directions, email Meghan! The second piece of maps is the ELEVATION map. Check this out! See where the hills are, how big the hills are, and where you think you might struggle. Not all trail runs have the elevation maps attached, mainly because the trails aren't routed on Google maps yet. The ones that are, definitely take a look!

Water and Food- Hand in hand with the Time and Maps category, is nutrition. PLEASE bring along at LEAST 8 ounces of water to each trail run. Remember you might be out there for 2 hours for an 8 miler. Make sure you are aware of that and prepare accordingly. Bring your water, bring your food. Always overprepare. It might happen that you take a wrong turn and that 5 mile loop you were running has suddenly turned into 12 miles. This has happened to the best of us, and we don't want you to be unprepared for that situation.

Scenery- The places we are going to be running are beautiful, no question about it. However. Keep your eyes on the ground! You may totally see that gigantic root and graciously leap over it with no problem, but the next step there is going to be a tiny little rock you totally over looked, and then you will be meeting the dirt. Be vigilant, keep an eye out where you are going.

Weather- It may be 65 and sunny in San Jose, but in the mountains it is significantly colder, especially under tree cover, bring extra layers. If you get to the park and realize it isn't that cold, you can always leave the layers in the car, but it's always better to be safe than sorry. I've seen frost on some local trails when it's been 70 in San Jose. Jackets, gloves, ear warmers, long sleeve shirts.

RESPECT- Finally, and most importantly, RESPECT the park you are in. Whatever you bring in, bring out. Don't litter, don't destroy plants, don't go off the marked trail, and don't cut across switch backs. That mountain has been there way before any of us, and let's make sure it will be there after we are gone. With respecting your environment, remember you are in NATURE! This means things like poison oak, animals, etc. If you see deer, don't chase them or yell at them. If you see any baby animal, give it a wide berth. Mama is close by and you don't want to make her angry. Most importantly (and I have to cover this), mountain lions and bobcats. Chances are, you are NOT going to see one of these animals. However, if you do, make yourself appear as large as possible. Raise your arms, open your jacket, be tall. Second, make noise. yell, shout, bang a stick against a tree. DO NOT make a sound that could be confused as the sound of prey. Speak loudly, firmly, and slowly. Third, act like a predator yourself. Maintain eye contact. Never run past or away from a mountain lion. Don't bend down or crouch. Never turn away. Finally, slowly create distance. Back slowly to a spot that gives the mountain lion a path to get away.

Finally, you are going to see other people enjoying the park, just like you. Be courteous and respectful. If you want to pass someone, yell ON YOUR LEFT with enough time to allow the person to react and move.

group.name: The Joomla Bay Area Users Group

description:
Register for this workshop on Eventbrite.


Migration time!

Joomla 2.5 is scheduled for end-of-life on December 31, 2014. This means we need to migrate Joomla 2.5 sites to Joomla 3 by then (or at least that's the perfect world scenario).

In this workshop, we will work with our site at joomlabayarea.com as an example site to migrate from Joomla 2.5 to Joomla 3. We want to go over many more migration examples as well. Attendees can have a development copy of one of their 2.5 sites set up and we can help guide through those migrations too. We won't have time to do super huge sites - so pick a reasonable site with a few third-party extensions and an off-the-shelf template. This is not a prerequisite and you don't have to have a site to migrate for participation in this workshop.

Lunch will be provided along with drinks. All of this is included with the cost. We will not have food in the morning, only coffee and water, so grab something before you arrive. Or there is a cafe in the Museum where you can grab a bite.

Tentative Schedule for this workshop:

9:00-9:30 Registration and Setup

9:30-10:00 Arrive, coffee, get settled

10:30-11:00 Announcements, Joomla Roadmap discussion:
This segment will be announcements, discussion about the points of the Joomla Roadmap as it pertains to migrations and the technical specifications for Joomla 3 to lead into the next segment.

11:00-11:30 Planning and Migration Process Outline:
Planning can easily take more than a half hour. In this segment we will go over questions to ask yourself as you plan for migration and what the two processes to migrate from 2.5 to 3 are. This includes technical specifications for Joomla 3, hosting, content and how it relates to responsive design, how to prep the 2.5 site, redesigns, clean-up, goals, and more.

11:30-12:00 Templates:
This segment will address templates and how to handle them for migration from 2.5 to 3. We will only be discussing off-the-shelf third-party templates. We will not be discussing custom templates at this workshop. Learn the things to look for when changing templates and setting the expectation with the client.

12:00-1:30 Lunch
We will have a catered lunch and then explore the incredible Computer History Museum. The museum is a fun, informative and inspiring place to be! You will have time to see the things that interest you most, or just stroll through and see the exhibits at your own pace.

1:30-2:15 Third-party extensions:
Third-party extensions have numerous ways they need to be migrated. Learn the three main processes that most third-party extensions fall into for migration and how to handle them. We will be looking at several extensions to see what to do about them during this segment (for joomlabayarea.com and for the attendee sites).

15 minute break

2:30-4:30 Migrations and troubleshooting:
This is the segment that we do the migrations. No matter how many white screens we get, we will go through it and work with it. If time permits, we'll get to some system clean up after the migrations.

We will be meeting in the Boole Room at the Computer History Museum.

Parking is easy and free in the Computer History Museum Parking lot. We will send attendees more info about parking prior to the event. Do you or someone you know need financial help to attend this workshop? We will have some scholarships available. Email our support staff to request a scholarship and why you want to attend the workshop and a few details about your situation. Wanna bring a client? Talk to us about having them attend too.

Includes a ticket to check out the Computer History Museum day of!!

Migration is just part of life in Joomla. Come to this workshop to have a better life. lol!

This workshop costs $50. It is bundled with the Template Workshop in September. You may attend one or attend both. Attend both and save $20 by buying the Bundled ticket. If you want to attend both, pick either date from the ticket area and we will have you covered. No need to bring a paper ticket to either event.

Directory Members receive an additional 10% off. Promo code sent separately.

Register at Eventbrite.
how_to_find_us: Register for the workshop on Eventbrite
name: Workshop: Joomla Migration - Joomla 2.5 to Joomla 3

description:
Come to  the training sessions for the Alcatraz swim.   Check out the beautiful SF Bay, build your strength and swim stamina and meet others that will be Taking the Rock in September.

Meet our Swim Coaches, Kirk McKinney  and Patti Bauernfeind. They will give you an overview of what to expect during the training, tips on how to swim in open water, and then we'll practice. After practice we'll review the experience and discuss ways to work on areas we want to improve. Come Early!! See you at the bleachers!

description:
Technically, this is not a part of the Bay Trail but it is a really fun tour. As some of you know, I used to work at Alcatraz. I've got lots of good stories. They also offer great walking tours by really knowledgeable people to help you get the most out of your tour and possible behind the scenes access.  Tickets are booking 90 days out so we need some lead time to plan.  Ticket sales are not yet available this far in advance.  I will send out reminders around May 1st to purchase tickets or earlier if they become available.

Make sure to sign up for the 10:00 a.m. departure.  The boat leaves promptly at 10:00 a.m. so be sure to find us in the boarding area as early as possible.

There is a cafe next to the Pier that has drinks and deli foods.  It opens at 8 a.m.    I recommend bringing a lunch as lines can be long and the food is expensive.   Coffee or tea can be purchased on the island. 

Visitors can take any boat back to the Pier.  We will probably be on the island for about 3 hours at least, including lunch.

This is an expensive trip - tickets to get to Alcatraz are $38 and parking will probably cost $15 but the good news is that the Pier where the boat departs for the island is easily accessible by Public Transportation.

http://www.alcatrazislandtickets.com/Alcatraz-Tickets/
how_to_find_us: In the boarding area for the boat.  I will hold a sign or stick with a red bandana.
name: Tour Alcatraz Island!

group.name: Bicycle Trails Council of the East Bay

description:
http://photos3.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/3/0/3/c/event_18372348.jpegThe Bicycle Trails Council of the East Bay invites you to our monthly Gala Ride. We meet on the 2nd Saturday of every month for a casually paced social group ride at one of the many great parks in the area. This is a 'no-drop' group ride (we won't leave you behind or let you get lost).

Rides generally last 2 to 3 hours and are great opportunities to meet other East Bay mountain bikers at your skill level and to discover the best trails without having to do it on your own.

Rides are free and open to the public and led by experienced local mountain bikers familiar with the trails.

Groups for ALL skill levels!

Skill Building Beginner Group (C): The group starts off slow, and tapers back from there!
Relaxed Intermediate Group (B): We stop to regroup and enjoy the view once in a while.
Fast Paced/Advanced Group (A): You'll get a chance to catch your breath, every now and then.

We start gathering at 9:00am and hit the trails promptly at 9:30am. Join us for refreshments and snacks after the ride.

Please note: As we are currently in the winter riding season, inclement weather can result in the Gala being postponed. As such, BTCEB will confirm via email the status of the ride by 5pm Friday before the Gala.
name: BTCEB Gala Ride

description: Start in Benicia (briefing at 9:45, on the water at 10 a.m.); paddle to the mothball fleet; lunch on the water; and return. 12 miles total.
name: Benicia to the mothball fleet

description:
Many of you missed this one in May, and others said, "Let's do it again", so we're heading back to Angel Island for more merriment, food, fun and sun.

PLEASE NOTE:  Either meet at the Tiburon ferry at 9:45 or on the island at the picnic area to the right of the dock, past the open field w/ the museum.  The hike starts at approx 10:45

The Plan:

We'll hike around the perimeter of the island (about 5 miles) almost entirely flat other than the initial rise to the perimeter trail.  Not a rough hike by any means, and of course the rating is contingent upon your condition. There are great views of the bay and bridges, so bring your cameras!  This is typically the most popular event of the year, so book your room now!

We'll leave the coolers/food at the picnic area and only hike w/ some snacks and vino.

The hike is optional, so if you want to come chill while we hike and then eat, drink, and be merry w/ the rest of us after the hike - do it!

It would be nice to have a few people stay w/ the coolers/food while we hike.

We'll leave the food and most of the vino at the picnic area, then hike around the island, bringing just snacks and some vino to enjoy on our vino/snack break along the trail.  There's a cool spot on the backside of the island w/ picnic tables and a great view of the Bay and the City, where we'll stop for refreshment(s).

What to bring:

Vino (and cups)

Snacks and vino for the hike.

Your appetite!

A cooler w/ ice and plenty of food

Food to BBQ (someone please bring a small gas stove - Thx Ed for bring one in May)

Sandwiches, wraps, bbq, paella, chicken, meats/cheeses/breads, salads, deserts, the works!  As always I'm hoping for plenty of ethnic food.  Not just boring hamburgers and hot dogs.  We're talking variety here, and lots of spicy food!

Plenty of Vino - we had some really nice bottles last time

Beer, water, soda, juice, whatever you want to whet your whistle

Chips, dips, snacks, and plenty to share

Layered clothing, sunscreen & hat

Hiking boots, or decent hiking shoes

$5 activity fee

Of course your sense of humour and desire for fun is an absolute must!

The hike is optional, so if you want to come chill while we hike and then eat, drink, and be merry w/ the rest of us after the hike - do it! 

It's always nice to have a few people stay w/ the coolers/food while we hike.  And yes, you get some vino while we're away!

Directions to ferry:

From US 101 heading Northbound Take the Tiburon Blvd exit, turn right, and follow Tiburon Blvd 4 miles into downtown Tiburon. Turn right on Main St. The ferry is located on the left at 21 Main St.

From US 101 heading Southbound Same exit as above, except take a left over the overpass. Instructions from overpass are the same as above.

Map and Parking Information: Park at any of the banks which will be closed and walk a few blocks to the ferry terminal.

The ferry costs $13.50 (Round trip).  NO CREDIT CARDS  - Bring cash.

Meet at the ferry dock at 9:45am -

Ferry leaves at 10:00am sharp - they won't wait.

GPS  37.873193,-122.455809

Return ferry runs 20 past ea hour. I.E. ferry leaves island at 3:20pm, 4:20pm, last ferry is at 5:20pm.

Typically several of us ride the last ferry then go to Guaymas for drinks, chips & salsa, and snacks, at the end of the day.  A great way to cap off the day.

This is the largest event of the year, and is posted to several Meetup sites, so plan on a full day of sun, fun, and meeting some cool people.
name: Day On Angel Island:  Perimeter Trail Hike, BBQ/Picnic, Party - Lots of Fun!

description:
Objective : 

Given a problem, analyze and solve the problem. Implement the solution using TDD.


Prerequisite :

You must have already installed Ruby 2.0 or later, Rspec 2.1 or later and a text editor.

You have to watch videos that will walk you through how to solve each type of problem. There will be no presentation during the bootcamp. You will pair up with another developer and practice each sub-skill to master them. The topics that will be covered are:

Problem Domain Analysis

• Given a problem description, analyze to understand the problem.

Solution Domain Analysis

• The deliverables from the previous phase will be used to create the solution document. This could be implementation details added to the previous document, table, pseudo code etc.

Designing Test Cases

• The deliverables from problem domain analysis will be used to practice this skill.

Writing tests using RSpec

• The test cases will be converted to specs.

Structure for Each Sub-Skill

Exercise 1    :    10 mins

Reflect         :      5 mins

Exercise 2   :     10 mins

Reflect         :      5 mins

Exercise 3   :     15 mins

Reflect        :        5 mins

BREAK        :      10 mins
name: TDD for Beginners

description:
Class open ONLY to those who are currently enrolled in or who have completed Jewelry Sawing. 

Well, we've learned how to saw, how to pierce, how to cut shapes out of metal, and now it's time to get started in "piecing" our work together.  For this class, we're going to again, use our material fees to "equip" you with all of the items that you need for soldering and brazing.  Due to the subject matter and the cost of the equipment,  this is going to be the most expensive class that we offer in the metal smithing series.  So here we go...

In this class, each member will be required to complete some "homework" (sawing a few pieces of metal out from a provided template), then we'll be soldering those pieces together to make a sweat soldered pendant, a bail and some additional items on your piece.

In the course of the two hours, we'll discuss the "mechanics" of brazing, some common problems when soldering, as well as common mistakes many of us make when soldering items together.  We'll also discuss the hazards of mixed metals in soldered materials.  For everyone's safety, this class will be limited to no more than 6 students.  Thanks!!

 

The material fees will cover the following items:

1 Max Flame Butane Torch

1 Kiln Brick

1 Container of Handy Flux

1 NonContaminating Flux Brush

1 Package Easy Solder Wire

1 Package Medium Solder Wire

1 Package Hard Solder Wire

1 Set of Soldering Picks

2 Fiber Handled Tweezers

Pieces of Wire to Solder

Pieces of Metal to Solder

Use of Classroom Pickle/Penny Brite

Use of Classroom Paste Solders

Use of Classroom Texturing Hammers

Each Meetup member should bring:

1 Apron

1 Jewelry Saw with 2/0 and 3/0 blades

1 Jelly Roll Pan with Sides

1 Quenching Bowl (a small metal bowl)

Your Brass or Copper Sheet Prepared Pieces (Homework)

Pin Files and Larger File

Sand Paper in various grits (320, 600, 800, 1000)

Ring Mandrel

Hammer and Bench Block

1 Safety Glasses

1 Painters Face Mask

1 Can of Butane (Available from Cigar Shops, Walmart and Target)

So let's make some cool stuff with solder and metal!!  If you have any or all of the above items covered in the material costs, please email me and we'll figure out what you're missing and what you need to get our revised fee.  Thanks!!
how_to_find_us: Across from Stevens Creek Nissan and at the Corner of Stevens Creek & Albany
name: Soldering Basics - Brazing and Sweat Soldering

description:
Hike - Picnic & Meet the Friends of Mt.Tam, State Park Volunteers


We'll hike in the Rock Spring area of Mt.Tam State Park. This will be a four mile hike; over rocky uneven trails. With exceptionally scenic views at elev 2000'; three miles from the ocean.

This hike ending at 12:30pm, is planned for those hikers who would like to know more about being a State Park volunteer at Mt.Tam State Park. 

At the Park volunteer opportunities exist for; Hike Leading, Docent at the Visitor Center or RR Barn Museum, Mtn.Play, Astronomy Night, Trail Work, FMT Board Member, Special Events and Special Park Projects are available.

Attending the Annual Friends of Mt.Tam Volunteer's Picnic will give you the opportunity to meet many of the volunteers and learn in more detail what is being done in their volunteer work. 

The Picnic will begin at 1:00pm; within a very short walk from the Rock Spring Parking Lot. It will end at 4:00pm. If you plan to attend the picnic only; let me know for directions to the picnic grove.

If you plan to attend the Picnic please bring a salad, desert or vegetarian entree; for the potluck. Drinks and barbecue will be provided by FMT Volunteers. The MTSP Rangers; who you will also have an opportunity to meet; will do all the barbecuing..

Come to the Hike and/or the Picnic and learn more about the Park and what is going on in one of Mt.Tam's local communities of volunteers.

Click for FMT Standard Hiking Generic Details


State Park Volunteer Hike Leader, Jordan Herrmann, will lead today's Hike. As usual the hike will leave on time. Don't be late and miss the hike.

Remember if you plan to attend the picnic only; let me know for directions to the picnic grove. [masked], [masked]
name: Hike - Picnic & Meet the Friend's of Mt.Tam - State Park Volunteers

description:
You know how to play Jericho, now see if you can beat a team of people who had an hour to prepare!

The Chronos Missions is a semi-persistent, team-based Jericho game that lasts one day for 5.5 hours.


Your team will know several days ahead of time when your missions are scheduled, but you won't know details about what & where (other than somewhere in SF) until the hour before.


You will be on call for two missions on the day you registered for.  Each of the one hour missions will be run as early as 10am or as late as 3:30pm. All briefings will be made via email to each team one hour before Mission Start.

You can assemble a team ( 4 agents, including you!) or be assigned to one. Simply put down how many guests you want to bring.


You will need a smart phone, Nerf gun, bandanna, and Ninja-like infiltration & evasion skills!

Space is limited to 4 teams , so grab 3 friends &  come on out!

Lots more details to follow after RSVP.

"As always, should you or any of your I.M. Force be caught or killed..."

---The Chief

PS---The only reason this was cancelled back in April was that we didn't get email addresses & photos of all the players. If that sounds too difficult for you, you should probably skip this one.
name: Jericho: The Chronos Missions

description:
Join Shelley and Milo for a day on the ranch.

Meet 10:00am KSU at 10:30am 

The meetup location is the new Starbucks in the Walgreen's parking lot, 14180 Blossom Hill Road, Los Gatos, CA 95032.

We will stop in Santa Cruz for food to go.

Shelley will lead a smooth ride on Route 9.

Milo will lead a back road bump fest.

Wilder Ranch State Park invites you to experience old-time activities from its rancho, dairy farm, and cowboy rodeo days. Hands-on activities and living history presentations vary each month and may include butter churning, ice cream making, branding, cooking, roping skills, wagon rides and demonstrations in the ranch buildings.

Come for a picnic on the lawn and follow it up with a game of tug-o-war, sack races, hoops, stilts, and Wilder Ranch's famous old-fashioned bubbles! The event is held on the grounds of the Wilder Ranch Cultural Preserve. The park is located 2 miles north of Santa Cruz on the coast side of Highway 1 at 1401 Coast Road, Santa Cruz, CA 95060. Day-use parking fee is $10. This event is appropriate for all ages.

description:
HTML 5 Application Development Training

1 Day - All levels

What: This is a 1 day HTML5  application development training.

Description: Get the insight into HTML5 Application Development with this 1 day it training course. 

The class begins with an introduction to HTML5, Document Object Model and an overview of JavaScript. Following this, Event Handling mechanism is explained. Following this Forms, Audio and Video APIs are explained. The morning session concludes with an exercise.

The afternoon starts out with HTML5 Canvas. Canvas API is explained. Following this, a couple of HTML5 Canvas/Graphics libraries are explained. Students will work on building an HTML5 Applications from scratch using Canvas, Canvas Libraries that integrates Canvas with Audio, Video and Drag and Drop APIs. 

Please remember to bring your Lap Top

This is an all levels training

Summary

------MORNING------

- Introduction to HTML5

- Review of DOM and JavaScript

- Event Handling in HTML5

- Forms API

- Video and Audio API

------AFTERNOON------

-Canvas API

-Drag And Drop API

-Integrate Audio and Video API with Canvas

-HTML5 Graphic Libraries

-Developing Canvas Applications using Custom Libraries

------------------------------------------------------------

Please remember to bring your Lap Top

Contact: [masked]

 Benefits 

Career: Lay your own path to success. Learn HTML5 and taste the fruit of success that comes from being in demand. 

Make more money: HTML programmers make on average $30,000 more per year than professionals who only know Microsoft Office. 

Be in control on the web: HTML is the foundation of the web and knowing HTML is essential for developing and managing a successful online presence. 

Increase strategic value: Become indispensible to your employer. 

Get a promotion: If you are looking for a promotion or a new job then knowing HTML will increase your chances of success. 

Mobile applications: HTML is used for Cross Platform Mobile Application Development; learn the language that is powering mobile applications. 

Value to businesses: HTML is of importance to all businesses because of its integral value to the web. 

Better work life balance: Knowing how to code can lead to a circumstance in your life where you have better control over your career choices and work options. Most employers allow programmers the freedom to decide their own schedule and also offer more opportunities to work from home for programmers than non programmers. 

A standard practice: It is integral to know how to program in todays competitive environment. If you have been looking for a language to learn then make HTML your 1st choice. It will give you a lot of power in a very little time. Let’s face it; sooner or later you will have to learn how to program. Why wait? 

You can do it: Learning to program is not as hard as you think. With our coaching you will be able to bridge the programming gap. 

Beneficial to all employers: Getting training in HTML5 is of value to all companies as it helps employees produce better quality work. HTML5 can make the difference between average quality output and excellent quality output. It is of value to any position that requires communication or data interaction. The skills learned in this class are applicable to all departments of any company including but not limited to IT, Data Analysis, Sales, Strategic planning and Marketing. The skills taught can be implemented in daily online tasks. 

Why:

-  HTML5 offers faster image downloads, especially for mobile users

- HTML5 offers improved SEO

- HTML5 offers Sophisticated animation effects

- HTML5 offers Easier Web and Mobile App Development

- BBC is turning towards HTML5 for application development

- Zynga used HTML5 to make Words With Friends, FarmVille Express, Zynga Poker Mobile Web and CityVille Express. Zynga continues to use HTML5 for product development globally.

- SAP is using HTML5 for Enterprise Mobile Apps

- HTML5 is one of the most desired skills by employer

http://startupsaturdays.eventbrite.com/

B. If you are already on Eventbrite then please select the number of tickets you would like to purchase from above. C. If you have an employer sponsored education program then please contact us at: [masked] can work with various reimbursement and employer sponsored educational programs.

description:
Get paired up with a random person at your skill level to hack on a project for 2 hours!

Thank you to DevBootCamp for providing free breakfast, a great space, and helpful TAs.

There will be three group levels: Level 1: HTML/CSS,  Level 2: Basic Javascript, and  Level 3: Advanced Javascript.

Dont have a project or idea?  Visit our website: www.pairuptocode.com for exercises and to share your progress.

Here is our agenda:

10:00 am: Doors Open

Register and get a sticker for your level.

Grab breakfast and say hello.

10:20am: Event Starts

Hack on your projects together for the next 2 hours.

description:
You are invited to join the Wild Equity Institute and the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service on a guided tour of the Antioch Dunes National Wildlife Refuge. This is an opportunity to visit a unique area normally closed to the public. The Antioch Dunes National Wildlife Refuge is home to three highly endangered species: the Lange’s Metalmark Butterfly, the Contra Costa Wallflower, and the Antioch Dunes Evening Primrose.

The hike is schedule to be an hours, but sometimes we get to chatting and looking at stuff that it goes a a bit longer.

Meet at the Antioch Dunes National Wildlife Refuge Entrance Gate, 501 Fulton Shipyard Road, Antioch, CA 94509. Take Highway 4 and exit A Street / Lone Tree Way. Turn North onto A Street. Turn right (East) onto Wilbur Avenue. Turn left (North) onto Fulton Shipyard Road. Cross over the railroad tracks and turn right into the second gravel driveway. The refuge is on your right. Here is a link with a map and directions http://wildequity.org/locations/3143

Wear sturdy shoes for this sandy 1.5 mile hike. No facilities.

You can learn more about these three species at:

Lange’s Metalmark Butterfly http://wildequity.org/pages/3046

Contra Costa Wallflower http://wildequity.org/pages/3047

Antioch Dunes Evening Primrose http://wildequity.org/pages/3048
name: Learn about Butterflies & Explore the Antioch Dunes National Wildlife Refuge

description:
Where to Meet: Let's meet in front of the Art Center/Gallery building (which is the entrance to the concert venue and where the public bathroom is), located to the left of the Villa Montalvo main building (Mansion), Saratoga at 10 AM and stroll on the hike trail from there.   

Your host Miki will be wearing a Meetup badge.

Parking: You can park in the first parking lot, or come up further and pass in front of the main building and Art Center to get to the other parking lot (which is probably closer to these buildings).

Montalvo is nestled in the beautiful foothills above Saratoga with 175 acres of hiking trails and gardens.

This gorgeous public park welcomes over 50,000 visitors every year to its woodland hiking trails and beautiful grounds. Parking is free and the grounds are open to the public exept on the days they have special events. (July 12 is clear of special events.)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EP2rgkk8Ci8

You can download a guide to Montalvo with a map of all trails (PDF Document) at http://media.montalvoarts.org/uploads/documents/2014/June/Montalvo%20Map_small929.pdf

We'll first condition ourselves by walking in the gardens and grounds, then hike up the trail.  From the beginning walk to the hike, we'll go for about 45 minutes, and head back, to make the entire hike about 1 hour and 30 minutes. 

• These trails have more elevation gains than our usual flat trails. So you will get some good exercise in your legs and heart as well.  

• Wear a pair of good closed walking shoes or hiking shoes with good traction.

• Those of you who have walking poles, this will be a good place to use them.  

After the walk, we can go to an optional lunch/snack/coffee at Big Basin Cafe in downtown Saratoga.

Bring hat, sun screen, bottle of water, light snacks.
name: Easy Paced Hike: Villa Montalvo Trail, Saratoga, Sat Aug 9, 10 AM

description:
We'll meet at the picnic tables between the bathrooms and the rock playground near the basketball court

If you've been struggling with your dogs house manners, walking on the leash, or aggression problems, or if you'd just like a more responsive, obedient dog, come on out and work with us.  Chances are, a few lessons on how to properly handle your dog will clear most of these problems up, resulting in a much more fulfilling relationship for you and your dog.


This course will be $35 to attend all 8 weeks of training.


This dog training program focuses on building a relationship with your dog based on love, respect, and clear communication.  We use rewards and gentle corrections to teach your dog the language you will use to communicate with them going forward.  Most dog problems are caused by a lack of love, respect, or clear communication, either by dog or handler.  This course will fix that for you.  By attending this 8 week program and doing all the homework, you should be able to expect your dog to "auto sit" anytime you come to a stop while he's walking with you on leash.  You should also be able to expect your dog to sit, down, on command, "auto-stay", and recall.  We'll also talk about leash/collar equipment, crates and crate training, and manners. 


It's not so much dog training, as it is human training for your dog.  It teaches you how to handle and communicate with your dog so that you become the leader in the relationship, instead of allowing your dog to train you ;)

We'll meet at the picnic tables between the bathrooms and the rock playground near the basketball court.  If you have trouble finding me, you can call me at 40eight- 4three9-4nine38.

Required Equipment:

- Water for both you and your dog

- A collar that fits properly (Flat nylon or leather, training collar [aka: "choke chain"], or a pinch collar.  If you're using a pinch collar, please make sure you also have another type of collar on your dog to be used as a back up.

- 6 foot leash

- 15 foot leash (3rd week)

- 30 foot (or longer) long line (5th week)


- Comfortable footwear (flip flops are not recommended)


- Good attitude

- Lots and lots of patience

Optional Equipment:

- Treats for your dog

- Folding chair

- Sunscreen

Rules:

- Always keep your dog on leash and under control at all times!


- Please do not approach someone else's dog, or more importantly allow your dog to approach someone else's dog with out talking to that dog handler and ensuring it's ok first, and only when the dog's handler/owner is aware you are approaching.  No sneak attacks!


- Always clean up after yourself and your dog.  Even if you think no one saw your dog defecate behind the tree, it is your duty to clean up after your dog.


- Fun and joking around is an important aspect of our training, but  within reason.  Please treat your dog, and the trainer(s), and other class members with respect.

- If any inhumane treatment or abuse to your dog is witnessed, you will be asked to leave the class.

- Find time to do your home work.


Things you must know:

- Understand I use people and dogs as an example throughout the class -- Good and bad.  Everyone gets to participate in this, so please do not feel picked on. 


- There will be moments of fast paced walking or jogging.  If you have injuries or ailments which preclude you from this type of activity, don't do it.  Just step aside and allow the others to go b and I will bring the group back to you.  This is completely fine.  Don't worry about doing anything you don't feel comfortable doing.

- If you get tired or frustrated, feel free to take a break.  We can talk after class if you have any concerns.

- If you do not do the home work every week, you cannot expect to see noticeable results in your dogs behavior, but if you do the home work every week, by the end of the class you should see noticeable results that will make you much happier to have your dog around.

- If you think your dog is aggressive, or may be two aggressive for a group class, please contact me to schedule an evaluation of your dog.

- Week 1 starts off kind of rough and can be very frustrating for you.  Please be patient and remember this is a course that has helped hundreds of people learn to effectively handle the dog.  If you're patient with yourself and your dog, and you do the homework, you're going to do great!


We will have no class on 8/23,  or 9/20.  Those classes will be held on 9/27 and 10/4/14.

description:
For the fourth straight year, the Geek Club is going to the beach in Santa Cruz!

Every year, we have journeyed to Santa Cruz where we enjoy the Seabright Beach and the Boardwalk. The first of us will arrive early to claim a nice spot on the beach. We'll eat a potluck lunch (don't count on a grill, though) and play in the sand. Groups will take turns going over to the boardwalk, while others stay with our stuff. Come when you want, and stay as long as you want!

Please bring a food item or beverage to share. List what you are bringing so others can coordinate. Since we'll be spending all day on the beach, please consider bringing more substantial food items rather than snacks. Also, sunscreen and clothing layers are a must!

Dogs are permitted on Seabright Beach as long as they are on a leash.

Also -- If anyone can bring a canopy, it would be awesome. Please let us know if you can.

CARPOOLING:

We highly recommend carpooling. Gas is not cheap. Parking is scarce. The road is long and windy. Also, it is fun to carpool and get to know each other better. We just have to make sure we have space to haul everything as well.

In years past, we have met in groups in the south parking lot for Vallco Shopping Mall in Cupertino (near Steven's Creek Blvd.) It's a convenient location close to 280 and 85 (which leads to 17, and in turn Santa Cruz.)

As we all have different schedules for both coming and going, I'm going to just leave it to all of you to work out the carpooling in the comments.

USEFUL LINKS:

Info about Seabright Beach


Info about the Beach Boardwalk


Directions to Vallco Shopping Mall

WHAT PEOPLE ARE BRINGING:

Please leave what you are bringing in the comments. (Don't worry about doing this right away, but please make sure to post before the day of the event.)

[The list will go here when we have one.]

description:
The Urban Farmers Coop events are working/learning sessions where we all pitch into a project at the hosts location.

What to bring
For this event, please bring any of the following:

Gardening tools: gloves, a shovel, spading fork, trowel, weeding tools

Potluck item: that either contains something that you have picked from your yard, something that you would like in the future to come from your yard, or something that you have made.


Crop Sharing item(s): Food items you have harvested from your yard to exchange with other members (if you have any)

Some good positive energy

AGENDA

1) A bit of work

As people arrive we will all participate in a group working activity in the hosts location.

2) Demo and instruction

During the work portion we will have a short break out period to present some new material and gain some farming/gardening knowledge.

3) Pot Luck and Socializing

Finally we will all spend some time to socialize and eat the wonderful food from our gardens. During the pot luck we will have time to discuss the following:

Q & A about gardening/ farming. Anyone can ask anything about a gardening or farming topic for others in the group to give their insights.

News and updates from our members: each member share progress on urban farming projects.

Future MeetUps, Volunteers for future hosts, Ongoing discussion on our Urban Farmers coop group.

Crop Sharing-- Everyone that has harvested something from your yard please bring it and exchange it. Take what you DID NOT bring.

 

About Urban Farmers Cooperative
The Urban Farmers Cooperative events are working/learning sessions where we all pitch in on a project at the host's location. Here is what we do:

We meet to help out a fellow host farmer

We do some work, exchange ideas, and learn something at the same time

We bring food from our gardens and share all the wonderful foods we are raising

After the meeting we all take home something that we did not bring

By RSVPing YES to any of our MeetUps you are agreeing to our posted waiver:

http://www.meetup.com/urbanfarm/pages/Waiver%2C_Indemnification%2C_and_Hold_Harmless

Our goal is to bring our community together through safe and fun learning events.

We look forward to seeing you at our upcoming MeetUps.

description:
Come out and bleed for those in need!

This time we are donating at THE Stanford Blood Center of Mountain View located next to El Camino Hospital. The building will be on your left, opposite St. Francis High School playing fields.


To inform Carolyn Tong at the Stanford Blood Center, when you RSVP to this event, you will be asked to provide your:

• Email Address

• Full Name

• Donor Member ID number or Birth Date,


so she can help us reserve the afternoon time slots, instead of doing walk ins. If you never donated with Stanford before or don't have your Member ID number, then your birth date is what they will use to register your appointment, along with your name and email address. After I send your RSVP info over to Carolyn, she will email you your exact appointment time. There is no need for you to schedule yourself on their website, as Carolyn and I will get you set up.


As we get closer to the event date, I may have to close RSVPs if the appointments fill up, so please RSVP early, so we can fill those spots ourselves!


If for any reason you can't completely provide the required information upon RSVPing, you can message me at: [masked]. If you'd prefer to email Carolyn Tong yourself, please still send me a message/comment, so I know she already registered you. Carolyn's Email: [masked] (Let her know you are with the Atheist Community of San Jose for Afternoon Donation on August 9th in Mountain View.)

"Please remember to eat and drink plenty of fluids prior to donation, bring photo ID, a list of all medications you are currently taking, and a list of your travel history." -SBC (if you have a Stanford Blood Center Donor card, please bring it.)

And if you got a ACSJ shirt or hat, wear it to flaunt it!

Subway Brunch Location http://goo.gl/maps/FyoLw
