description:
Startup Finance: Valuation

About: Learn how to value a startup.

Finance is a powerful global force and valuation lies at its core. Valuation makes or breaks a company. It is critical to understand valuation as an investor, entrepreneur, consultant and employee.

There are many circumstances in which valuation is critical:

A. You are looking to raise funding for your company.

B. You are looking to invest in a startup.

C. You are looking to work for a startup and your success is tied to the startup’s success.

D. You are about to get paid in equity.

E. You are interested in selling your business.

This class is focused on startup valuation with entrepreneurial and non-public valuation needs in mind. We cover concepts such as pre-money, post money valuation and valuation equations used for private companies. We will be looking at Startup Valuation from the financial perspective. You can expect to walk away with a few equations and ideas on how to make financial projections.

This class is ideal for entrepreneurs, investors and anyone interested in working for or with a private company. Attendees to this seminar will walk away with a better understanding of the valuation process.  Attendees can expect to walk through a financial example of valuation.

Testimonials:

“This is one of the best finance classes I have ever taken.”

- Andrew

“I took the “Startup Finance Valuation” class; excellent job. This class is a must for all entrepreneurs. MBA classes do not teach how to value a startup, this class does.”

- Danny

“After taking this class I have a clear perspective on valuation. I recommend this class to all entrepreneurs. Thank you for a very informative class.”

- Bonnie

“I have been in banking for over 20 years and this class taught me valuable concepts not covered by all the classes I have taken throughout my career.”

- Yaakov

description:
This trip is finally happening! This will be a beginner-friendly trip to the Marin hostel in Rodeo beach. It’s a short, paved trip, and we won’t carry much weight, hence why this is a great introduction to touring.
The main aim of this trip is to visit the Point Bonita lighthouse on their sunset tour, though you can feel free to skip that.

Bike routes
Saturday:
We’ll leave from Embarcadero at 1pm. The road to the hostel is all paved. There is a climb, and it starts out mean, but it gentles off soon enough. We’ll stop at all the batteries to do some exploring (and catch our breath) so bring a lock if you’re concerned. You’re also welcome to go on ahead (or start later and meet us on the way, we should be a pretty obvious bunch). Map here: Embarcadero to Marin hostel, 12mi, 1200ft ascent.

Sunday:
I’ll probably go back through fire roads + ferry, because that’s fun and we won’t carry much load. This (Hostel to ferry on dirt, 12mi, 1140ft ascent) looks a likely route. This alternative route (Hostel to ferry paved, 5mi, 500ft ascent) is all paved and the easiest way back.
There are plenty of options for ferries (schedule here and here) but you can also ride back to SF fairly trivially.

I’ll bring copies of maps for everyone. I expect to be back in SF early afternoon, so I won’t plan for lunch, only a big breakfast + snacks.


Rodeo beach Marin hostel
We have booked two rooms of 5 (one double and 3 twins in each). The first 10 to rsvp who want to stay in those rooms will get a spot. The rest should book themselves in (you can cancel up to a certain date without incurring any fees). The group rooms will most likely be co-ed, so if you don’t want that, you can choose gender-specific dorms when you book individually. Whether you’re in the rooms of 5 or not, it’ll end up being around $30 a night. There is a bicyclist discount we should mention at check-in (which is when we actually pay).
Hostel FAQs here.

PEOPLE IN GROUP ROOMS SO FAR - FULL (cos 2 double beds):
Jean + Magnus - double
Ellie
Lincoln
Kuro Kurosaka
Kevin
Sacha
Sandy
Daphne C

PEOPLE ON WAITING LIST FOR GROUP ROOM (might want to book a dorm bed and cancel it if you get into the group rooms):
Greeshma

PEOPLE WITH THEIR OWN SLEEPING ARRANGEMENT:
Robert Huang
Lee T + 1
Jane
J Scott Matthews
Akiyo
Dan
Scott
Ryan LaBarre

If you were inclined to camp, there is free camping at Bicentennial (close to the lighthouse) or at Hawk camp (a few miles up a dirt road away from the lighthouse/hostel). You do have to book those and they get popular.

Point Bonita lighthouse sunset tour
We’ve got room for 17 people to come on the free, docent guided sunset tour of Point Bonita Lighthouse (see weekend sherpa and Sunset magazine for mild spoilers).
You can still join the trip if you don’t want to do the tour, or if you’re at this point in time not on the first 17. I’ll keep the rsvp updated in order so any cancellation will move down the list.
Those coming on the tour will need to have eaten and be ready to go at 7pm from the hostel. The tour starts at 730pm and finishes at 9pm. We’ll be riding there and back (in the dark).

PEOPLE WHO HAVE A SPOT ON THE TOUR - FULL FOR NOW:
Jean
Magnus
Ellie
Lincoln
Robert Huang
Ryan LaBarre
Lee T + 1
Kuro Kurosaka
Kevin
Sacha
Dan
Jane
J Scott Matthews
Akiyo
Scott
Daphne C

PEOPLE WAITING FOR A SPOT ON THE TOUR:
Greeshma


PEOPLE SKIPPING THE TOUR:
Sandy

Since this is not happening for a while, I wouldn't be surprised if there were some cancellations, so don't let the full tour deter you - I'll be going through the waitlist in order!


What to pack
Food for dinner and breakfast, any snacks
Pjs, clothes for two days, toiletries
Layers for evening tour - heat layer (fleece or down jacket), windproof layer
Bike lock (we will leave bikes behind during the tour)
Bike lights (blinky at the very least) and headlight - we will be riding back from the tour in the dark on a quiet, open-to-car-traffic road
Comfy shoes to walk in (1h30 tour standing)

The hostel provides bedsheets and towels, and has a full kitchen.


This is a trip where you could get away with a backpack if you haven’t got a rack/pannier setup yet. I’m not saying it’d be super comfortable but it should be manageable due to the short distances.

I'm limiting the group size to 25, but really there's no limit. It's 17 max going on the lighthouse tour, and 10 max in our group rooms, but you can book yourselves into the hostel if the trip is full and come on the ride either way.


If you have any questions, feel free to message me!

********************************************************

Important Notice: The Organizer, Assistant Organizers, and Event Organizers in this group are not professional leaders or guides. By signing up for a trip, or any other event organized by this group, you are acknowledging you are aware of the risks, dangers and hazards associated with the activity and freely accept and fully assume all such risks, dangers and hazards, and further agree to release and discharge the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, and Event Organizers of the NorCal Bicycle Touring and Camping Meetup Group against any and all liability arising from your participation in the group activities. 

Read these Safety Notes for Riders and this FAQ.  You can find some helpful ideas in these Touring Tips & Knowledge.
name: Beginner-friendly overnighter to Marin hostel, visiting Point Bonita lighthouse

description:
Hear ye, hear ye....

Calling all ladies for a ladies-only lunch and tea outing. If you love the femininity and genteelness of a bygone era. If you are really into period movies, sigh [and maybe also salivate :) ] at the sight of 1700s and 1800s ballgowns, hats, gloves and parasols, love Mr. Darcy, and would jump at the chance to get in a time machine to travel back in time to those periods, then join us for lunch and tea at Lisa's Tea Treasures, at the Pruneyard.

Their food is delicious and the prices are very reasonable. Here is the link so that you can check out the menu: http://www.lisastea.com/menu.aspx .

In case you are wondering why the attendee limit is 4 in this group, it's because I have scheduled this outing in two of my groups - this one and another one, for a total of 8 spots. I have limited it to 8 total in order to avoid the complication that comes once the reservation goes past that number. With a larger group, they require a credit card when the reservation is made, pre-ordering, they prefer everyone to order the same item - and if a person does not show up, they still charge the full price of the dish.

Well, now that you know the full scoop, sign up to join us for a grand ol' time. If you would like to wear a lovely hat, pearls, lace, or whatever other "lady-like" item of your choice, feel free to do so, but it is not required. I will probably wear a hat. :)

venue.name: Lisa's Tea Treasures
venue.address_1: Pruneyard Shopping Center, 1875 S Bascom Ave Ste 405

group.name: Urban Hiking & Happy Hour (& random urban adventures)

description:
Let's hike some of the secret stairs near the Oakland/Berkeley border. We will meet near the Highwire Coffee Roasters section out on the sidewalk. You may wish to arrive early to Rockridge Market hall to sample the cheeses and pick up a lunch or use the restroom.   At 1:40 sharp we will start the hike.  Phone help is not available for latecomers and those not ready to leave at 1:40 pm.

Our hike will take us to the areas surrounding the Claremont hotel.  We will do 1 or 2 of the walks from the book called Secret Stairs East Bay and possibly the  Claremont Canyon preserve if time permits.  There will be hills, views, paths, stairs and some areas of steepness. We will take a short lunch/snack break.

The walk will end in the Ashby area where we will have a long happy hour in a backyard not too far from the Ashby BART station.   For those who have attended our backyard happy hours in the past, note that this is the last party at Shannon's wonderful backyard before she moves away.  We will make a stop at the Berkeley Bowl to buy food and drink.

Please note that the the hike will end in the Ashby area and not back at Rockridge.  Attnding the happy hpour is optional.  We will take a short lunch/snack break.

Safety Disclaimer: The organizers of this meet-up are unpaid volunteers and not expert hiking guides. All participants agree to assume 100% responsibility for their own safety, conduct, and well-being and recognize that possible hazards exist while participating in outdoor (or any other) activities, and agree to participate solely at their own risk. If you RSVP “Yes” and/or attend any of our events, it shall be conclusively presumed that you understand and agree to this policy.
how_to_find_us: We will be near the Highwire Coffee Roasters section, outside on the sidewalk.
name: Secret Stairs in Oakland/Berkeley

description:
Come enjoy good company and music at the fabulous, 66 person capacity, Treasure Isle Cabana!

Bring whatever food and drink you like. There are plenty of stores and restaurants nearby if you wish to pick something up on the way.

Get your band together and belt out a song or two on the mic karaoke style, shred on the plastic guitars, hammer on the keys, or beat on the drums. If you need help rounding out your band or learning the Rock Band ropes there will be plenty of roadies on hand. Don't be shy.

If being a rock star is not your thing try your hand at tabletop games. Bring your favorite to play and share or sit in on something that looks interesting. Should be plenty of room to lay out even the most complicated board games.
name: Rock Band & Games at the Cabana

group.name: The San Francisco Libertarian Party Meetup Group

description: The Libertarian Party of San Francisco holds our regular monthly meetings on the 2nd Saturday each month, from 3-5pm, followed by a dinner social from 5-6pm. Currently we are meeting at the San Francisco Main Library, at Grove and Market (see http://mapq.st/h/1-AF... for map), in the 4th floor community meeting room. Occasionally another group will be using this room, in which case we will be in a community meeting room on the 1st floor. Everyone is welcome to come and be part of the discussion, however in order to vote on party business you must be registered to vote as a Libertarian if eligible, and become an LP member by completing a membership form. Sometimes our meetings include a guest speaker. After the meetings, those of us who want to hang out and chat over a meal head over to Ananda Fuara vegetarian restaurant at Market and Larkin streets for our social. You're welcome to come for just the social, just the meeting, or both. You can always check meeting details, or find out the latest LPSF news and happenings, on our Libertarian Party of San Francisco website (LPSF.org). Thanks for your commitment to freedom, and on behalf of our local chair Aubrey Freedman and the rest of our group,  we look forward to meeting you! -Starchild, LPSF Outreach Director and Meetup Group organizer

venue.name: San Francisco Main Library
venue.address_1: Grove & Larkin streets (4th floor community meeting room)

group.name: Conscious Girlfriend: For Happy, Healthy Lesbian/Queer Love

description:
Are you a single lesbian over 40 seeking meaningful connections with other women?

Have you found “speed dating” unsatisfying – or just feel turned-off by the idea?

Do you want to broaden your pool of potential dates in a fun, safe, growthful setting?

Would you like to learn more about what it really takes to create – and sustain! – the love of your life?

If you answered Yes to any of these questions… Conscious Connections is for you!

We’ve found that many women over 40 really want to “do it right this time.” We want a deeply intimate, connected, loving relationship that will last. Yet often we’re not sure how to:

• Find potential partners and begin the dating process

• Manage the vulnerability, fears and triggers that can come up

• Assess true compatibility (and gracefully say No to incompatible people)

• Pace the relationship appropriately (no more 2nd date U-Hauls!)

• Determine the right timing for getting physical

• Get clear on our relationship vision – rather than just “going along”

• Create a relationship better than any we’ve had before.

We’ve developed Conscious Connections to help!

How Does Conscious Connections Work?

At each Conscious Connections event, we eliminate the awkwardness, and give you ways to briefly connect one-on-one with 10 or more women present – so you can learn about them in authentic ways, while also learning more about yourself.

One by one, we”ll present ten 5-minute laser lessons about how to build intimacy, heal conflict, and create long-lasting, happy love. After each lesson, you’ll have five minutes to talk about the lesson with a different partner. (So, you’ll have ten 5-minute conversations in all.) We’ll end with a mixer during which you can reconnect with your conversation partners to exchange contact info — and/or connect with the other women present.

Lively. Fun. Compassionate. Thought-provoking. Friendly. Welcoming. Real.

A great new way to get to know other women – and learn tools for a great relationship, too!

You can RSVP here, but to make sure a spot gets held for you (since we only have room for 50 women!), please pre-pay the $25 fee at www.consciousgirlfriend.com/conscious-connections
name: Conscious Connections: The Next Generation of Speed Dating!

description:
The ragtag and occaisionally frustrating Minnesota Twins are coming to the Bay Area to play the Oakland A's. Let's get a group together and see the game!

We could tailgate before the game and bring the BBQs for our own Jucy Lucys, Jello Salad and Old Dutch and wash it all down with some Grain Belts before we head into the game.

Game time is 6:05pm. The suggestion is to each buy our own ticket(s) for the bleachers - seating is first come, first served out there - but that's where the cool kids sit and it's a great experience.

Tickets are $15

You can buy them here: http://purchase.tickets.com/buy/MLBEventInfo?agency=MLB&pid=7635115&tfl=Oakland_Athletics-Schedule-2014_Promotional_Schedule-na-a0

Also, for the baseball fans, that day will be Tony LaRusa Bobblehead day in honor of his Hall of Fame induction. If anyone wants a bobblehead, they might want to get to the stadium by 4pm - the line gets long and supplies are limited.

Someone will be in the parking lot for the tailgate starting around 3:00pm. P.S. Tailgate will be potluck, so bring your finest Jell-O Salad or traveler hotdish, or CheddarWursts.

P.P.S. We'll post the specific location for the tailgate on the day of the game.

description:
<strong style="font-size : medium">About the class
Learn to make mobile applications! It is simpler than you think.
We will review the technologies being used in making applications and give you enough guidance for you to come up with your own strategy.

This is a beginner level class and can be of assistance to you if you don’t have any background in programming and are interested in building an app. It is also very helpful to those interested in or are currently working with programmers.

We hope that you take time to come to this class and walk away with a better understanding of Mobile Application Development.

<strong style="font-size : medium">Please remember to bring your laptop

Please install the following before class:

X-Code: https://developer.apple.com/xcode/

This lathe will be able to turn plastics and wood into useful projects; legs, pens, poles, decorations, supports, rocket bodies, pea shooters, or whatever turns your fancy! Everyone is welcome.

description:
Progressive Talk is a monthly meetup to discuss the important political and social issues of the day. This two-hour meeting combines dinner with stimulating conversation, covering topics suggested by both the Organizer and club members.

If you would like to suggest a topic, please post it in the comments section below, with a link to a related webpage (such as a news article) that people can review before attending. The Organizer will also announce topics in the same manner. To ensure that everyone has a chance to review the upcoming discussion topics, please post your suggestions at least three days before the meeting.

The first hour of the meeting will center on topics suggested by the Organizer, while the second hour will focus on topics suggested by members. If there are many topics suggested by members, a quick informal vote will take place during the meeting to decide the topics for the second hour.

If you love good food and conversation about current affairs, please join us for a fun evening of progressive talk. Hope to see you there!
name: Progressive Talk

forbesmillsteakhouse.com

I look forward to enjoying this meetup with you!

description:
Synopsis: Sex. Danger. Jealousy. More Sex....the "Beast with two Backs"... suffice it to say you will probably want to bring wine for the picnic before this outdoor performance of Othello!

Even among Shakespeare's "greatest hits," Othello has a special place. Few works are this sexy, this dangerous, this relevant to the passions and evils of the modern world. Othello, a Moorish general in the Venetian army, and his new wife, Desdemona, seemingly have it all -- true love, success and happiness. But can anyone protect them from "honest" Iago, a master magician of deceit?

The inspiration for villains as varied as Milton's Satan and Breaking Bad's Walter White, Iago is one of the most hypnotically evil characters ever created. Witness Shakespeare's profound tragedy about the power of love and jealousy as performed by the Shady Shakespeare Theatre Company. Details & $10 Tickets: http://www.goldstar.com/events/saratoga-ca/othello?gtmEcf

PICNIC BEFORE PLAY at 5:30. Sanborn Park is a lovely place for a picnic at dusk! Surrounded by Redwoods with lots of grassy areas and picnic tables. As always, bring food to share and the beverage of your choice. Hopefully that beverage will be wine :)
name: Othello -- Shakespeare's Great Tragedy (under the stars!)

description:
A drag send-up of SEX AND THE CITY live on stage! Sex And The City: LIVE! features Heklina (Carrie Bradshaw) (Trannyshack / The Golden Girls) D'Arcy Drollinger (Samantha Jones) (Shit & Champagne), Lady Bear (Miranda Hobbs) (Roseanne) and Special Guest Alaska (Charlotte York) (Known to a wide national audience after being a star on Ru Paul’s Drag Race – SEASON #5). The show is directed by D’Arcy Drollinger.

The “girls” are four young professional women in search of the perfect relationship and, of course, the perfect orgasm. Each episode features multiple storylines that tackled relevant and modern social issues including sexuality, sexually transmitted diseases, safe sex, promiscuity, femininity and of course shoes - while exploring the difference between friendships and relationships. For tickets: http://www.eventbrite.com/e/sex-and-the-city-live-friday-august-8-2014-tickets-11359188639?aff=eorg
THIS IS FOR YOUR ONLINE RESERVATION ONLY FOR GENERAL ADMISSION SEATING. TOTAL TICKET PRICE IS $30. PLEASE BRING PRINTED TICKET ALONG WITH $15 CASH BALANCE TO THE EVENT. DOORS AT 7:15. I am planning on taking Bart there.

description:
Many of you missed this one in May, and others said, "Let's do it again", so we're heading back to Angel Island for more merriment, food, fun and sun.

PLEASE NOTE:  Either meet at the Tiburon ferry at 9:45 or on the island at the picnic area to the right of the dock, past the open field w/ the museum.  The hike starts at approx 10:45

The Plan:

We'll hike around the perimeter of the island (about 5 miles) almost entirely flat other than the initial rise to the perimeter trail.  Not a rough hike by any means, and of course the rating is contingent upon your condition. There are great views of the bay and bridges, so bring your cameras!  This is typically the most popular event of the year, so book your room now!

We'll leave the coolers/food at the picnic area and only hike w/ some snacks and vino.

The hike is optional, so if you want to come chill while we hike and then eat, drink, and be merry w/ the rest of us after the hike - do it!

It would be nice to have a few people stay w/ the coolers/food while we hike.

We'll leave the food and most of the vino at the picnic area, then hike around the island, bringing just snacks and some vino to enjoy on our vino/snack break along the trail.  There's a cool spot on the backside of the island w/ picnic tables and a great view of the Bay and the City, where we'll stop for refreshment(s).

What to bring:

Vino (and cups)

Snacks and vino for the hike.

Your appetite!

A cooler w/ ice and plenty of food

Food to BBQ (someone please bring a small gas stove - Thx Ed for bring one in May)

Sandwiches, wraps, bbq, paella, chicken, meats/cheeses/breads, salads, deserts, the works!  As always I'm hoping for plenty of ethnic food.  Not just boring hamburgers and hot dogs.  We're talking variety here, and lots of spicy food!

Plenty of Vino - we had some really nice bottles last time

Beer, water, soda, juice, whatever you want to whet your whistle

Chips, dips, snacks, and plenty to share

Layered clothing, sunscreen & hat

Hiking boots, or decent hiking shoes

$5 activity fee

Of course your sense of humour and desire for fun is an absolute must!

The hike is optional, so if you want to come chill while we hike and then eat, drink, and be merry w/ the rest of us after the hike - do it! 

It's always nice to have a few people stay w/ the coolers/food while we hike.  And yes, you get some vino while we're away!

Directions to ferry:

From US 101 heading Northbound Take the Tiburon Blvd exit, turn right, and follow Tiburon Blvd 4 miles into downtown Tiburon. Turn right on Main St. The ferry is located on the left at 21 Main St.

From US 101 heading Southbound Same exit as above, except take a left over the overpass. Instructions from overpass are the same as above.

Map and Parking Information: Park at any of the banks which will be closed and walk a few blocks to the ferry terminal.

The ferry costs $13.50 (Round trip).  NO CREDIT CARDS  - Bring cash.

Meet at the ferry dock at 9:45am -

Ferry leaves at 10:00am sharp - they won't wait.

GPS  37.873193,-122.455809

Return ferry runs 20 past ea hour. I.E. ferry leaves island at 3:20pm, 4:20pm, last ferry is at 5:20pm.

Typically several of us ride the last ferry then go to Guaymas for drinks, chips & salsa, and snacks, at the end of the day.  A great way to cap off the day.

This is the largest event of the year, and is posted to several Meetup sites, so plan on a full day of sun, fun, and meeting some cool people.
name: Day On Angel Island: Perimeter Trail Hike, BBQ/Picnic, Party - Lots of Fun!

description:
Portland is always a great place to ride a bike. Every year on the second Sunday of August, Portland becomes the best place to bike.
Every year Providence Bridge Pedal is held 2nd Sunday on Aug. On this one morning of the year, Portland’s Willamette River bridges welcome thousands of cyclists and walkers – from the Sellwood to the St. Johns, including the top decks of the Fremont and Marquam bridges.

With ride options that range from 3 to 36 miles, as well as a 5-mile walk, there’s something for everyone. Join in the celebration of Portland, the Willamette River bridges and cycling.

 

 

 

 

 

 

FLY TO PORTLAND AND CARPOOL IS OPTIONAL:
Saturday - San Jose to Portland
Driving will takes about 10 hours.
Air travel will takes about 1 hour 40 min.
Julia & Tom III's airline Schedule:
Sat Aug 9 Southwest #2777 (Depart SAN JOSE at 8:25PM - Arrive in PORTLAND at 10:00PM)
Tue Aug 12 Southwest #159 (Depart PORTLAND 7:15AM - Arrive in SAN JOSE at 9:10AM)

TRIP PLAN:
Sunday Morning - Bridge Pedal
24 miles Start 8:15AM - 9:15AM
Bridges crossed (in order) Hawthorne, Ross Island, Marquam, Burnside, Broadway, Fremont, St. Johns, and Steel.
Sunday Afternoon - Street Party
Premier food and music festival in Waterfront Park
Monday - Hiking & Wine Tasting Trip
* 6-hour tour of the Columbia Gorge waterfalls and wineries from Portland
* Relax on a gorgeous drive along the Columbia River and through the Cascade Mountains
* Explore waterfalls and admire views of wet forests
* Visit several wineries and enjoy wine samples

 

 

 

 

 

 


TRIP COST: Early-bird $198.00 Regular Rate: $208.00
This adventure includes 3 nights at Private Home, 5 meals, transportation & Sightseeing in Portland and Registration Fee for Bridge Pedal.

Please share the Gas in the end of the trip.
name: Portland Bridge Pedal and  Hiking & Wine Tasting Trip

Sunset SF presents the ultimate CRUSH PARTY

Green Velvet
Gorgon City
Icey - Official DJ Page
The Scumfrog

This isn't a party. It's a feast. A testament to overkill. A show with FOUR HEADLINERS. After last year's sold out Plump DJs / Krafty Kuts blowout Heineken Dome afterparty for the , we had to pull out all the stops. And that we did, bringing you a lineup that has seldom seen its equal in a San Francisco club show. GREEN VELVET is one of the few edm artists whose music has transcended the genre, and whose singing, writing, and musicianship have made him one of the most sought after artists in the world. DJ ICEY is one of the most influential producers of all time, the father of American breakbeat, and one of the finest live Djs on earth. GORGON CITY is one of the hottest production teams on the planet, on the heels of their #4 charting "Ready for Love". And then there's the SCUMFROG, a dj's dj with 25 years of experience making the underground into hallowed ground. They will be joined by local heroes, Lights Down Low Dj's Richie Panic and Corey Sleazemore plus Silent Frisco with Motion Potion Matt Haze and Dj Dials outside. This WILL SELL OUT. So get your tickets NOW.

description:
The Sunday Hikers are looking for shade cover this weekend and Regional Redwoods - French Trail here we come!

        8 : 30 am Start time at Canyon Meadows Staging Area in Redwood Regional Park !

        THE ROUTE : This is a 6.5 mile CHALLENGING hike ( Rated MODERATE PLUS - THIS HIKE IS NOT FOR BEGINNERS ! )

          The Proposed route is a 6 + mile loop hike with approx. 800 feet of elevation climb and follows : From Canyon Meadow to Stream/Tres Sendas/French/Orchard/Bridle/Stream trails.

        I have enclosed a PDF outlining the entire hike for your convenience. Please let me know if you are unable to open it

        http://www.regionalparksfoundation.org/document.doc?id=267

  Dog friendly hike as well - just make sure your dog can go the full distance of the hike  (6 miles). Water and restrooms are available at the start of our hike .

       If you have never experienced Redwood Regional Park you are in for a treat! Lets get out of the summer sun and see some cool trees !
how_to_find_us: Canyon Meadow staging area, Parking area towards the back of Canyon Meadows Staging Area, park as close as the parking lot will allow - we will plan to get on with hike by 8 : 30 am.
name: Shade Trees Hike in Redwood Regional Park - 6 mile French Trail -  Moderate Plus

description:
Elkhorn Slough is a favorite with the folk that I kayak with. Each paddle there brings something new to watch as natural life goes on around us. In the entire Bay Area, this is one of the best places to kayak.

Be on the beach in front of Monterey Bay Kayaks at around 9:30 a.m. and READY TO LAUNCH at 10:00am. After a 2-minute briefing we will head out for a leisurely paddle up the slough to a point just past Seal Bend. There we will either pause for lunch, or--if the group so desires--paddle all the way to Kirby Park. Lunch is in the boat or outside the boat at Kirby Park depending how far the group paddles. We will be with the tides in both directions so this is an excellent paddle for beginners or experienced kayakers. If you don't own your own kayak you can rent from Monterey Bay Kayaks. It's best to reserve a kayak in advance as they do sell out on nice days. To contact for rentals: www.montereybaykayaks.com or [masked]. If you are going to rent, please show up at MBK before 9:00am. If you are an absolute beginner, I recommend a sit-on-top kayak, and polyester or "wicking" underclothes. MBK will provide you with a wetsuit, PFD, paddle, and paddle jacket as part of their rental package. A wetsuit is always a good idea when paddling in cold water.

NOTE: We launch on time. Please show the group the courtesy of being there on time ready to go. There will be experienced paddlers in this group, or the always friendly and knowledgeable staff of MBK, to help you out.

If you have a marine VHF transceiver, we will be on channel 78.

There is a fee for parking in the Moss Landing Harbor Parking Lot. Get an envelope from the rusty kiosk on the bathroom building, and deposit your parking fee there as well. Note that you need only pay for parking, not launching, as we will not be using the launch ramp.

Please no children under the age of 18 or animals.  Thank you.
name: Paddle Elkhorn Slough

description:
Grab that trailbike - it's time for the monthly ride at Soquel Demonstration State Forest (a.k.a. SDSF, a.k.a. Demo), hosted by our friends at MBOSC - Mountain Bikers of Santa Cruz.

Intermediate to advanced riders will enjoy the monthly club ride at Demo featuring long climbs and technical descents.

Regular re-groups ensure a social, supportive environment. The route is determined by ride participants, but typically consists of a couple loops with an opportunity to bow out after the first. The ride is typically followed by lunch at the Summit Store.

Meet at 9:30am to unload your bike and socialize. Wheels roll promptly at 10:00 am. Cross the bridge at Highland Road and meet at the inside parking lot. (Click on the “i” on the map below for directions.) Car pooling is encouraged.

Full suspension bikes are recommended; body armor is optional. Helmets are required for all MBoSC rides. You don’t have to be a member to ride. This is a great opportunity to meet local riders and enjoy the abundance of trails in our corner of the world.

Check the weather - rain 48 hours before cancels the ride!
name: Soquel Demo Forest 2nd Sunday ride

group.name: Barks & Rec. - Bay Area dog-friendly adventures

description:
Let's do a hike in the city!

From Haight St x Buena Vista Park West St (not East, the street intersects 2 times with Haight) corner of Buena Vista Park, we'll head to the dog run area, then up to the top of the park. From there we'll head to Corona Heights Park through Masonic St. We'll enjoy the views from the top and end at the dog run at the bottom of the hill. There will be opportunities at the dog runs to have your dog off-leash, but since we'll be traversing through some busy city streets, it'll be good to have your dog on a leash.

Suggestions for what to bring:

• Water and snacks for you and your dog

• Leash


• Appropriate clothing for changing weather conditions

• Sun protection (sunscreen, hat, sunglasses)

Well behaved dogs only. There will be dogs big and small with a range of personalities, so please be mindful of this.

description:
What if there were a free tool that you could use any time, any place... to contact deep inner wisdom and healing?

What if this tool had been used for millennia - and also updated to suit the unique needs of contemporary Westerners?

What if this tool could help you feel more alive, purposeful, joyful, connected to yourself and to Spirit? - and could also help you heal past trauma, dysfunctional relationship patterns, anxiety, depression, addictions, compulsions, and almost anything else that causes you pain and imbalance?

Guess what? There IS such a tool, and it's called the shamanic journey.


The shamanic journeying method I teach comes from Core Shamanism, a technique synthesized by anthropologist Michael Harner based on his study of many diverse cultures throughout the world. As such, we all have equal birthright to it, no matter who we are or where we're from... and, it works for all of us.


Deceptively simple yet amazingly profound, the shamanic journey can transform your life. I know that's a bold claim! Yet I make it because it has transformed my own life, and the lives of hundreds of students and clients to whom I've taught it over the years.


At this class, suitable for beginners OR more advanced practitioners, we'll:

• Go over the basics of safe shamanic journeying. (There are some very important things NOT to do, as well as some practices and understandings that will help you journey more easily and effectively.)

• We'll do an initial journey to help everyone present make contact with an inner guide (or deepen your contact, if you're already working with a guide.)

• We'll explore the most powerful healing practices available in shamanism, how to prepare for them, and how to enlist your guides' assistance in implementing them.


• We'll do a second journey in which you can start on one of these advanced healing practices... or continue deepening your connection with your guide or with non-ordinary reality. (Everyone can journey! But everyone moves through the process at a different pace, and I aim to teach in a manner that allows each person support to go where they need to go, at their own speed and in their own way.)

• We'll close with some discussion and practice of how you can keep these powerful tools and understandings alive and growing in your life - even in a culture that doesn't understand or support them :)

If you haven't come to a Meetup with me before, check out the reviews for previous gatherings. These classes are always amazing - and I say that without boasting. I'm a good teacher, but what really makes the classes life-changing are the wise, loving, compassionate beings who work with me and through me - and who are available to work with and through you, too!

For more info about me, please feel free to check out my website, <a>www.EvolutionarySupport.com.</a>

<a>Oh, and a note about fees. The fee I charge is the lowest I'm aware of in the Bay Area for a day of powerful, guided shamanic practice. But I'm committed to making this work available to as many people as possible - so as long as there are at least 5 full-fee participants, I am open to working out partial scholarships with other folks who want to come on an as-needed basis.  So if you need that, let me know :)</a>

<a>Hope to see you on August 10!
</a>

In love and healing,

Ruth

description:
Conservation Photography Class
Fundamentals of Exposure
Gary Sharlow, Photographer, Education Manager

Sunday, August 10th at 1:00pm
In this three-hour classroom presentation, you will learn about the inner workings of your DSLR camera. This class is designed as an overview to help you better understand your camera, the digital workflow and how to make better images. We cover basic features of the DSLR camera to include choosing lenses and filters, ISO, white balance, shutter, aperture and program modes, EV, exposure, bracketing, focusing, resolution, histograms and more. The main objective is to help you understand the fundamentals of exposure so that you can get your camera out of auto mode and start making images the way you want them to look. Once you have the skills to get the correct exposure under any conditions, we can shift our efforts to proper techniques for focus, light metering, depth of field and some basic rules of composition.

Please Note: Entrance is via the Academy's Staff and Research Entrance at the back door located at 75 Nancy Pelosi Drive. You will not be permitted entry at the front door. Please arrive at least 10 minutes early.

Reservations: Members: $40, General $50. Seating is limited and advanced ticketing is required. To reserve a place today, buy a Member or Non-Member ticket online or over the phone at 1-[masked]
how_to_find_us: Business Entrance at the BACK of the Building
name: Fundamentals of Exposure Workshop

description:
Folks its that time of year again when Stern Grove opens its gates to the beautiful park and puts on FREE concerts every Sunday throughout the summer!

PLEASE NOTE THAT TO GUARANTEE A SPOT WITH OUR GROUP YOU MUST RSVP ON ONE BRICK WEBSITE HERE: http://sfbay.onebrick.org/event/?eventid=14965 - spots are limited!

No real British theme to this event - but who doesn't like a Sunday afternoon in the park listening to decent music, sipping on a glass or two and enjoying a picnic?

This event combines several of my passions in life (three mentioned above!) - one of the main one's being giving back to the community.  So why not join me in volunteering at Stern Grove?  Its an easy introduction to a wonderful volunteer organisation called One Brick (onebrick.org). The tasks are simple - prior to the concert and during the interval we are part of the bucket brigade going round collecting donations from the crowd.  In return for these tasks Stern Grove provide us free parking and seats at one or two of the picnic tables with the best views of the concert! Once the event is over we help clear those picnic tables, recycle a few bottles & things, and help organise the recycling bins for collection later.  

Legendary vocalist Darlene Love headlines the afternoon at the Grove with her powerhouse vocals and classic Motown sound.  Bay Area favorite Monophonics open the show with their signature psychedelic soul and heavy funk sound. More details here: http://www.sterngrove.org/home/concertsevents/2014-season/schedule/august-10/

Either join us volunteering (please RSVP on One Brick site) or just come down anyway to enjoy the show!  If you are not volunteering we recommend getting there for around 11a.m. to get a good spot in the park.  Volunteer - and you can just stroll up around 1:15pm!
how_to_find_us: Look out for Lily & I with our One Brick clipboards and orange gear at the volunteer station
name: Head down to Stern Grove (SF) for some Darlene Love!

If we finish this one block of "Belalp Path" we may also work on "Belalp Path" as it goes up higher on the other side of Buena Vista Ave.

We will work for about 2 hours, but it is OK to arrive late and only stay one hour.

Below is the bottom of Belalp Path.


Below photo shows pretty flowering plant that plants itself, Jupiter's Beard.


The bottom.

description:
Bethany Healed from Life in a Wheelchair; What Can You Overcome?

The film “Bethany’s Story”, produced by the non-profit health and wellness organization SanaView, documents a girl’s illness from its onset to recovery. It reveals how food, not medication, consistently proves to be a dominant factor in healing and reversing illness and disease. Illustrating these points are interviews with leading medical and nutrition experts such as Neal Barnard, MD, founder of Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine; Michael Gregor, MD, founder of NutritionFacts.org; Gabriel Cousens, MD; Dr. Brian Clement; Brenda Davis RD, and Lewis Mehl-Madrona, MD.

View the trailer of this film at http://sanaview.com/bethanys-story.aspx?affiliateswap=SMC.

At age thirteen, Bethany was left paralyzed from a series of bad reactions to medication. For years doctors told her she would never walk again. On her own, Bethany discovered and adopted a vegan (raw) plant-based diet and within a short amount of time she was out of her chair standing and walking. “Our body has this amazing ability to rejuvenate and repair and regenerate,” says Dr. Michael Gregor.

The film chronicles Bethany’s illness from onset to recovery and includes heart-wrenching accounts from her friends and family. Understanding and witnessing some of the incredible challenges this family encountered truly shows the impact serious health issues have on everyone. Hearing the scientific facts presented by all of the medical experts brings this solution fully to the forefront. As Dr. Gabriel Cousens states in the film, “These are not miracles. We have the science that makes it very clear,” shows that this is not just an anecdotal account of one odd story, but a scientifically proven solution. Dr. Brian Clement states that raw foods is not a fad but a proven solution that is here to stay.

The film's director and founder of the SanaView non-profit organization, Janet McKee, hopes the audience becomes inspired to begin making better choices with food and lifestyle:

"I’ve known for some time that food choices are critical for good physical health, but after working on this film, I have no doubt in my mind that there is no greater medicine than food for true healing of the body...Inspiration is the first step to helping others make positive changes, and this film is a key tool to create the desire in others," says McKee.

"We have had so many people tell us how the film has changed their lives, and some, too, who have had amazing recoveries from illness when they changed their diet. I feel such gratitude in my heart to have the opportunity to be part of this movement."

name: See the Film "Bethany's Story" with the Film's Executive Producer, Janet McKee

description:
As dementia continues to affect millions of elderly Americans, Alive Inside: A Story of Music & Memory reveals a remarkable, music-based breakthrough that has already transformed lives. Spearheaded by social worker Dan Cohen and captured on camera over the course of three years by filmmaker Michael Rossato-Bennett, we learn that songs from a patient's past can awaken memories and emotions that have been asleep for years, sometimes decades. Within a moment of hearing "I Get Around" by the Beach Boys, Alzheimer's patient Marylou jolts back to life, dancing around the living room and expressing a euphoria her husband hasn't witnessed since her illness took effect. Countless instances in Alive Inside provide proof that music stimulates activity in dementia-affected parts of the brain and transforms the quality of life of those often left to languish in silence. Through revealing conversations with renowned neurologist Oliver Sacks and musician Bobby McFerrin, as well as powerful firsthand experiments conducted by Cohen in nursing homes, this groundbreaking documentary demonstrates how connecting the elderly to the music they love not only combats memory loss but also supplements a broken health-care system often indifferent to interpersonal connections.
(Review from IMDB)

Dinner Discussion: Afterwards, we'll meet to discuss the film and the Enneagram over dinner at a nearby restaurant. Suggestions welcome!

Questions to Guide Discussion: We may discuss some or all of the topics here: Discussion Questions. It may help to refer to the list before watching the film.

Note About Experience Level: We will use the Enneagram numbers to identify the personality types. If you are new to the system, we strongly advise you to familiarize yourself with the various types and their numbers beforehand in order to better follow the conversation. Introductory information is available on the internet including The Enneagram Institute's "How to Begin with the Enneagram"

NR -- 73 minutes
name: Film & Enneagram: Alive Inside

description:
Van Zandt & Milmore pay tribute to Master of Horror Alfred Hitchcock, with this comedy whodunit.  Off-and-on New York couple Marnie and Jeff enter an even more complicated phase of their relationship when they think they spy their cross-courtyard neighbor do away with his wife.  After they draw their torn curtain, the lady vanishes, and suspicion places murder beyond a shadow of a doubt.  The bumbling witnesses sneak into their neighbor's apartment - 39 steps away - and the fun begins.  Among multiple door-slammings, body-snatchings, and a frantic flashlight chase scene, two questions remain: Who killed Lila Larswald?   And… if she's not dead…then who is?  The crazy farce plays out on a shadow-box set that allows the audience to be present in one apartment, while viewing the action in its mirror-image neighboring unit across the way.


Regular admission is $16
Senior admission $8

Note:  Since they are a small theater company, they cannot accept credit cards.  Cash or check only. 

Tickets are available at the Box Office, call [masked] or email [masked] for reservations.

This group really enjoyed the times we were at this venue.  Be aware that this is an outdoor theater, and dress appropriately/bring blankets, as we will be sitting on bleachers outside.

Bring a picnic and enjoy the show!!!


No one involved with the ORSVP group is paid. We do this for the love of community theater and for YOUR enjoyment!  Orinda Parks and Recreation charges for the use of the stage. The publishers/agents charge between $75 and $100 per performance.  The cost of lumber, fasteners and paint run well over $1,000. Used furniture, necessary props and costumes, etc., etc., all add up quickly.  We get no civic funding.  Ticket sales, program ads, and concessions are our only revenue, so your donations of cash or materials help tremendously.  If you are able to contribute, I would honor you greatly. And, of course, you are welcome to come down and participate in our fun!

- Geotty Chapple, President

description:
Our selection for August is:

<a href="http://www.amazon.com/American-Nations-History-Regional-Cultures/dp/0143122029"></a>The Sixth Extinction: An Unnatural History by Elizabeth Kolbert

A major book about the future of the world, blending intellectual and natural history and field reporting into a powerful account of the mass extinction unfolding before our eyes

Over the last half a billion years, there have been five mass extinctions, when the diversity of life on earth suddenly and dramatically contracted. Scientists around the world are currently monitoring the sixth extinction, predicted to be the most devastating extinction event since the asteroid impact that wiped out the dinosaurs. This time around, the cataclysm is us. In The Sixth Extinction, two-time winner of the National Magazine Award and New Yorker writer Elizabeth Kolbert draws on the work of scores of researchers in half a dozen disciplines, accompanying many of them into the field: geologists who study deep ocean cores, botanists who follow the tree line as it climbs up the Andes, marine biologists who dive off the Great Barrier Reef. She introduces us to a dozen species, some already gone, others facing extinction, including the Panamian golden frog, staghorn coral, the great auk, and the Sumatran rhino. Through these stories, Kolbert provides a moving account of the disappearances occurring all around us and traces the evolution of extinction as concept, from its first articulation by Georges Cuvier in revolutionary Paris up through the present day. The sixth extinction is likely to be mankind's most lasting legacy; as Kolbert observes, it compels us to rethink the fundamental question of what it means to be human.
name: The Sixth Extinction: An Unnatural History by Elizabeth Kolbert

description:
The full moon in August is a "super" full moon! It rises at 7:58 and the  sunset is at 8:05. We'll meet at our favorite full moon spot at the park indicated above. The park closes at 8:30.

The park is BIG.... so, to find us, use the address above and LOOK at the Google map. The green arrow points to the exact location where we meet. From 101, you'll go east on Embarcadero Rd, and pass the PA airport (will be on your left); take a left at the T; go past the duck pond (also on your left). After that, bear right and proceed to a gravel parking lot at the end of the road. The place where we drum is an area of soft gravel between the parking area and an arrangement of big concrete blocks.

There is no seating, so bring your chair, stool, or something else to sit on. There is an outhouse nearby. Dogs are allowed. Handicapped access is ok. This location is always cool and windy in the evenings so bring a jacket or sweater.


If your plans change at the last minute, please change your RSVP accordingly.

Extra drums and percussion instruments are always available.

description:
Make new friends who share your interest in polyamory here on the San Francisco Bay Area's peninsula!

Come on down to the cafe and revive yourself with food, folks, and frivolity!

This monthly social get-together is open to polyamorous or poly-curious people and their partners. It's an informal social, not a formal discussion group; you don't have to talk about being poly, but it's a safe place to. Our crowd skews young — mostly folks in their twenties and thirties — but well-behaved persons of all ages are welcome.

To find us, look in the back room for a stuffed animal on one of the tables, and the laughing, mingling crowd.  We've been getting roughly 30 people lately.  (If you want think it's crowded, maybe you could suggest a different venue?) Please RSVP to encourage folks here at Meetup.com by showing them we're well attended, and please review the event afterwards to share how great a time you had.

If possible, please support our continued use of this charming cafe by making a purchase. Coupa Cafe has a great menu and a wide selection of drinks and eats and treats.

Please note that we are a social group, and one dedicated to polyamory. While those who practice swinging and other forms of consensual non-monogamy are welcome at our events, aggressive 'cruising' is forbidden. Thank you for helping us maintain a friendly, no-pressure atmosphere. This is a female co-organized, diversity friendly event.

description:
San Francisco August Super Full Moon

Learn moon photography at the on San Francisco's Embarcadero during the “Golden Hours” of light. Shoot the moon over San Francisco with San Francisco Chronicle retired staff photographer Frederic Larson. Discover the tricks of the trade photographing the full moon as it rises during the magic moments of twilight. See how to plot landmarks, read a compass, and choose an angle as the moon rises; measure exposures then scan images; and finally lay out your art for publication. Explore principles of light mastered by professional photographers of National Geographic magazine.

What you will be covering is moon photography. The range of focal length recommended is long to medium telephoto lenses. A tripod is suggested as the class will be doing long explorers in low light situations. The class will incorporate expose times, f/stop settings and certain photographic techniques that are beneficial in nighttime photography. Main areas of emphasis will be capturing peak moment.

About the class: This is a 2 day Mobile Application Development Training with a commitment from 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM each day. No prior programming experience required.

2 day class with a commitment from 9:00 AM - 5:00 PM each day 

Learn to make applications for:

Android

iOS (iPhone and iPad)

Mobile Web

Don’t miss out on this awesome opportunity!

75 % of all Smart Phones in the World are Android Devices

15 % of all Smart Phones in the World are iOS Devices

Please remember to bring your laptop

No prior programming experience required

Agenda Day 1:

Intro to JavaScriptOverview of options for cross platform developmentAdopting the right strategyUser Interface FundamentalsWorking with Local DataWorking with Remote DataWorking with Media and the Filesystem Agenda Day 2:Using the cloud for your applicationIntegrating Contacts and Social APIsIntegrating Web ContentDeployment and DistributionApplying newly acquired skills

Is your enterprise ready for mobile?

This class also covers the topic of enterprise mobile solutions. 

The world of mobile application development is evolving very fast. A major driving factor behind these developments is the contributions made by the international community of developers in the form of open source platforms that enable the generation of native apps from a single code base.

Benefits

Access to all markets: The most valuable benefit of taking this class is that it covers multiple platforms in a single training

Mobile application development is here to stay: Smart phone companies have spent 100s of millions of dollars in research and development in order to deliver to the world a product that revolutionizes the way we live. 

To add some numbers to this: Apple spends about $1 billion on R&D each year. 

The result of all this investment is that we now have smart phones with more computing power than many desktops. The ability to make a smartphone is not readily accessible to individuals however the ability to make applications that utilize these smartphones is.

Impossible to avoid: Businesses have to adapt to the smartphone revolution, there is no way around it. This adaption ranges form sending and receiving emails to making presentations and word processing.

As a result there is a demand for experts who can help companies adapt to this change. Having a smartphone integration strategy has significant implications for a sustainable competitive advantage. 

Building cross platform applications saves time and money

group.name: Parents of Bay Area Young Writers

description:
Dear Parents,

This year, we’re inviting students to create stories about memorable, wacky Heroes and Villains. As always, we'll have 2 writing teachers and a maximum of 12 students per workshop.

San Jose Imagine-Nation Story & Illustration Camp for Children Ages 7-12

This week-long course will be hosted by Art Educator, Dr. Smita Garg, in her home (near Saratoga Ave exit, off 280 Fwy).

AUG 11-15: 9am-12pm - STORY WRITING

AUG 11-15: 1-4pm - STORY ILLUSTRATION
* Half Day or Full Day programs available

Students will

* practice the entire writing process

* focus in-depth on one story

* learn highly interactive, playful and hands-on writing games & exercises

* learn story structure based on the Hero’s Journey by Joseph Campbell

* have an opportunity to do a reading of their work on Friday

Our story writing students will travel through all the creative writing steps:

* Brainstorming

* Choosing a topic

* Organizing ideas

* Writing rough drafts

* Revising content

* Editing (grammar, spelling, punctuation)

* Publishing

The focus of the illustration class will be on practicing and developing drawing skills. We will use these skills in the visual development and presentation of story characters:

* Practice sketching with live models

* Learn to draw from observation

* Learn to convert ideas into images

* Use different art media, including pencils, pens, markers, watercolor, and collage papers

* Learn about different kinds of illustration styles

* Play fun 'artful' games

* Create a personal, illustrated story book by the end of the week

Feedback for our Workshops:

"My daughter had the pleasure of taking a week-long creative writing workshop from Shu-Hsien and Royd. Though my daughter is an advanced reader, I have had previous challenges creating an environment where she would get into writing. Shu-Hsien and Royd were able to get the group of kids to enthusiastically write. Students shared their works at the end of the week with oral readings. The teachers are excellent about using various strategies to tap into what works for the individual student and use interactive group work to start the thinking process moving for the young writers....My daughter came home from the workshop so happy and content, the way she can be after a long stretch of time engrossed in an activity."
  ~ Julie, Parent of 8-year-old writer

Writing Coaches Shu-Hsien Ho and Royd Hatta are passionate about teaching youth and teens how to organize their thoughts and write with power, clarity and ease. Since 1996, their students have learned to write essays, research reports, poems, short stories, and even their first novels. After working with Ms. Ho, one teen writer independently published her 400-page fantasy novel. Their students have gotten accepted into top colleges and universities, such as UC San Diego, Carnegie Mellon, Caltech, MIT, NYU, and Brown University. Ms. Ho has a B.A. from Pomona College and an M.A. from Lesley University. Mr. Hatta has a B.A. from the California State University at Long Beach, with specialties in history, art, theater, and philosophy. Ms. Ho and Mr. Hatta currently teach small group workshops for homeschooling groups and at the Chinese American International School in San Francisco. They run two thriving writers clubs with over 420 families: Bay Area Young Writers and Bay Area Teen Writers. In the last two years, Ms. Ho and Mr. Hatta published four anthologies of their students’ fiction: Strokes of Lightning, Real Heroes Wear Sneakers, Bones of Mystery, and Encroaching Ink. They are currently compiling and editing stories for the 2014 anthologies.

 

A local artist and art teacher, Smita Garg has taught art classes and workshops to children and adults throughout the San Francisco Bay Area including public and private schools; Next Door, a local women's shelter; the Moreland Area Community Center (MACC); the India Community Center (ICC), and the Art of Living Foundation's youth program. She believes that creating art is a powerful form of self-expression, inspiration, and healing. Smita Garg has a Doctorate in art education from the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign.

Regular Tuition:
$410 per student, Half-Day Programs
$595 per student, Full-Day Programs, includes lunch supervision

Special Offer if we receive a $150 Deposit per student by MARCH 1:
$310 per student, Half-Day Programs
$495 per student, Full-Day Programs, includes lunch supervision

RSVP online Today: http://www.meetup.com/Parents-of-Bay-Area-Young-Writers/events/166198732/

For more information, please contact Writing Coach Shu-Hsien Ho:

[masked] or <a>[masked]</a>

To register and reserve a seat, please write deposit checks to

“Beyond the Box Learning” and mail to:

Shu-Hsien Ho

Beyond the Box Learning

c/o UPS Store

530 Showers Drive #7-256

Mountain View CA 94040

Thank you! We look forward to working with your children.

description:
Ann Evanston

                         Steps to Building your Influential Voice

Bio:  Ann Evanston has been a creative intuitive all her life. As a Warrior she has loved choosing her own mission and fate, sometimes to the detriment of her success! When someone says “Go left”…she wants to go right! It wasn’t until she was introduced to Napoleon Hill that her business world changed. Then she realized that her gift to the world is bringing women in business together in the spirit of MasterMind to organize their knowledge and actually earn what they deserve. Crazy part, is she has always been a speaker….she actually started in toastmasters in the 7th grade! She competed in oratory in high school and had the honor of speaking on the same stage as the Reverend Jesse Jackson in 1985. WAAAAYYYYYY back in the 90’s she was a speaker for CareerTrack, Fred Pryor Seminars, and National Seminars Group. With over 600 speakers, she was in the top 1% of Back of Room sales and the only woman! As a business owner, no matter WHAT YOU SELL, speaking is one of the smartest strategies to getting clients now, but without a presentation that converts you are just inspiring, or very helpful. Ann now shows entrepreneurs how to get out of their own way, organize what they do, present it to audiences and sell more with ease. ANY business can use this skill as a gateway to closing more business.

$ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $$ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $ $

description:
Dear Uniting-the-Generations Community,

How will your participation in our community help make the world a better place for your children and future generations?

Imagine what it would be like to tap into the collective wisdom of diverse and dedicated individuals representing all four generations of your larger community?

Starting on Aug. 11th , 2014, you'll have the opportunity to participate in the 1st of 8 interactive workshops designed to discover new ways of looking at the crises we now face on so many fronts--social, financial & environmental.  "How will this help?  What can one community group do to change anything?" you may ask.

Fear grows out of a mistaken notion that these crises are so huge they can only be addressed from the top down.  The change that will truly solve most problems in our individual lives, our society and indeed our world is not just a change of policy, a new law, a new president or a tighter regulation, but a fundamental change of mind and heart.  The change required now must come from the grassroots--from individual changes that ultimately create a contagion of change in homes, neighborhoods and workplaces.  This change starts with you and me in the fundamental way we engage with the world.

Let's come together and collectively begin to increase our understanding and application of the new discoveries in such fields as neuroscience, epigenetics, quantum physics and the social sciences.  For too long science has separated to study.  These new sciences unite in ways that demand we begin the work of actually rewriting what we call the fabric and structure of reality, or our worldview.

When you join us you'll learn: 

• How you can identify the character & social conditions influencing the 4 different generations to better utilize the gifts each has to offer


• You will understand how these characteristics, conditions and the archetype each generation represents repeat throughout history to evolve humanity


• And space will be provided for you to connect to your new community to discover where you are now and what sort of future you want to build

"Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world. Indeed, it is the only thing that ever has."    


- Margaret Mead
name: The Generations and Repeating Cycles of History

group.name: Living a Life of Yes! Community

description:
In order to ensure a comfortable environment that allows all to share and be heard, this event is limited to 20.

The Goals

• Meet new people in a low-key, laid-back setting

• Share about yourself

• Learn about others

• Ask for and offer support

• Share and learn ways to live a life of yes!

Event Overview

Everyone will introduce themselves and if applicable, make an ask. An ask can range from "I need help finding a job" to "I'm looking to barter Spanish lessons for cooking lessons" to "I'm looking for feedback on my writing."

After intros, the group will share/brainstorm ideas on how to live a life of yes!. Activities, resources, philosophies, anything goes!

If time allows, relaxed mingling will follow, allowing people to follow up individually with others. And if we run out time, don't fret, you can connect online or at the next event!

The venue is a comfortable setting (couches and armchairs).

Logistical Details

Folks who register will be sent the exact address a few days before the event

For first time attendees, check out our rules

There is a small fee ($5) to offset Meetup Organizer's Meetup dues, curation time, and venue expenses (please look over the refund policy before signing up)

To bring: business cards, a positive outlook, note-taking items, and if you'd like, dinner/snacks for yourself (realize you may be coming from work and may be hungry; nearby places to get grub)!

There are no walk-ups. Meetup will close when all spots are taken or 5pm day of meetup, whichever comes first.

 

Make it a great day!

Saya

 

Curated by Mac & Cheese Productions, http://macncheeseproductions.com/

description:
As browsers become more powerful, our users are coming to expect more visually complex and engaging experiences. Some of the most impressive effects can come from appropriate use of 3D animation, taking advantage of the newest features in HTML5 and the power of WebGL. So we thought it was a good time to take a look at how these tools and techniques can factor into our own web applications today.

We'll be reading Tony Parisi's new book, Programming 3D Applications with HTML5 and WebGL. It takes the reader from the basics through some of the latest patterns and frameworks, and discusses both how and when to use them. 

Note: We're pushing the date of this meeting back a week to August 11 to accommodate the schedule of the author, Tony Parisi. We're excited that Tony plans to join us to discuss his book with the group, so read well, and prepare some interesting questions!

Looking forward to another lively discussion!
name: Discussion: Programming 3D Applications by Tony Parisi

group.name: SF Types, Theorems, and Programming Languages

description:
Writing code for the interpreters on this track of the meetup has produced such gems as:

Let "twice" (
Lam "f" (Lam "x" (App (Var "f") (App (Var "f") (Var "x")))))
(If (App (App (Var "twice") knot) (Const "true" BoolType))
(App (App (Var "twice") inc) (Const "1" IntType))
fortyTwo)

and:

'fac :: (I =>: I) ^^:
'n :: I ^:
If(equ('n)(1),1,times('n)('fac(minus('n)(1))))

I'm starting to feel as if I'd like something easier to read, maybe more like (for the latter):

fac ~ n, n =< 1 ?? 1 !! n * (fac (n - 1))

I'd like to explore some ideas about concise programming language syntax that has a straightforward mapping to an optionally-typed lambda calculus.

If you've ever come up with some favorite ideas of your own about what programming language syntax should look like, bring them along and we'll show and tell.

And don't forget the door code at Mixrank: *1111
name: A Digression on Syntax

description:
Hola a todos,

Come join us for some margarita / sangria / wine drinking fun all while chatting in Spanish! Rosa Mexicano (and that's correct, not "Mexicana" since it refers to a type of Mexican pink) is an awesome meeting spot for our group. We take over the side section in this large open-doored restaurant, next to the bar, enjoy some tapitas and get to know each other in Spanish. This Mega section attracts many members, so if you want to get a spot RSVP right away. Likewise, update your RSVP if your plans change to open up a spot, since we almost always have a waiting list.

So how does it work? Simple, show up, introduce yourself and chat in Spanish (ONLY). Most people are coming on their own as well, so you will be the "norm" if you are too. Everyone is very welcoming and friendly. All levels are welcome, with the only rule being it is a Spanish only event (occasionally, by the way, we do post "Spanish optional" events). This group has many native speakers who are regulars, many advanced speakers who lived in Spanish-speaking countries for years, and a fair amount of learners. We tend to stay on our feet to promote mingling and meeting and socializing with more people.

These events are FREE, but anyone joining will need to purchase one drink or food item. This is to keep our venues happy (and sorry, water doesn't count as "one" drink ;  ) This is important since without your participation in keeping venues happy they might make us "guarantee the bar" or pay for the space. As long as you order a little bit of this or that, it will be good enough. And, oh yea, don't forget to tip :  )

Hope you can come join our fun group soon!

Un abrazo a todos, y os veo muy pronto,

Rachel
how_to_find_us: Ask the bartender if there is any confusion as to where we are :  )
name: Monthly Mega Meetup @ Rosa Mexicano

description:
Join Bryan Vu (Google) as he shares his work on a deep dive into a new coin mixing protocol to improve anonymity in Bitcoin. The protocol is called CoinShuffle.

The key innovation in CoinShuffle is that it is decentralized and it does not require a mixing server. Among other advantages, this means that no mixing server learns which output addresses and input addresses in a mixing transaction belong together. Since CoinShuffle is based on the idea of CoinJoin, theft of coins is excluded as well. CoinShuffle does not require complex cryptography and performs well in practice, even in scenarios with a large number (about 50) of participants. Read the Bitcointalk thread here: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=567625.0
how_to_find_us: 20th Street and Mission. Next to T-Mobile
name: Bitcoin SF Devs Seminar: A deep dive into Coinshuffle & Decentralized coinjoin

description:
Increase the ROI in your Business with Strengths

Strengths Crash Course

Many of us fall for the illusion of being “well rounded.” When we run a business, often times we end up becoming the business instead of being the owners of one. One of the biggest mistakes business owners make is failing to play to their strengths and complementing with strength based teams! When you focus on strengths with your teams, engagement increases by more than 15%! How would an extra 15% engagement serve your business and impact your bottom line? Whether you have employees or not, you have a team, you just don’t know it yet. Do you invest the majority of you time playing to your Strengths or do you spend your time attempting to improve your weaknesses?

Come join us! These will be your takeaways:

•  Discover how Strengths add depth to branding yourself and your business

•  Maximize your Team Structure – How do you lead?

•  Creating a more engaged workforce – you are the leader of your business, are YOU engaged?

When we put our Authenticity to work, it pays! There’s something to be said about how you serve others when you take your “Good” to “Great” and your “Great” to “Genius!”

To get the most out of this event, take your StrengthsFinder Assessment: https://www.gallupstrengthscenter.com/Purchase/en-US/Product

Liz Ramos is a Coach, Entrepreneur, Speaker, and Owner of Authentic Lifestyle Designs. With over a decade of experience in Human Resource management, running multiple businesses and three levels of coaching certifications, she focuses on helping businesses yield higher results through the art of coaching and guiding leaders to leverage the power of Talents and Teams. On an international level, through key partnerships, Authentic Lifestyle Designs is a premier provider of Ultimate Life Coaching in Spanish, inspiring Happiness, Health, and Wealth worldwide. Liz knows what it’s like to focus most of our time building knowledge and skills while ignoring our true Authenticity and believes that discovering this and putting it to work is a cornerstone in the foundation of their business; this is her biggest craft, creating Awareness, Action, and Accountability around Authenticity.

description:
Nowadays, we are using JavaScript more and more on our webpages, and that means that we can end up with hundreds or even thousands of lines of JS. If you're not careful, your code can quickly become an unnavigable maze of spaghetti code. Most web developers are now using Object-oriented concepts to help them modularize their code and make it more re-usable.


In this evening workshop, we'll give an overview of Object-oriented JavaScript, and spend most of our time actually getting our hands dirty using those concepts.

As a prerequisite, you should be fairly familiar with JS, like by having attended our JS workshop and advanced JS workshops in jQuery and AJAX. Bring a laptop, a charger, and a smile.

If you're interested in being a teaching assistant, please let us know.


Thanks to Adobe </a>for the great space.

If you'd like to attend but cannot afford the cost, please <a href="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/viewform?formkey=dHRPTms0blNlTlo3cUpySFJENzBEdWc6MQ">request a GDI scholarship.

description:
Nina Zumel and John Mount present their new book, Practical Data Science with R. 

About Practical Data Science with R
Business analysts and developers are increasingly collecting, curating, analyzing, and reporting on crucial business data. The R language and its associated tools provide a straightforward way to tackle day-to-day data science tasks without a lot of academic theory or advanced mathematics.

Practical Data Science with R shows you how to apply the R programming language and useful statistical techniques to everyday business situations. Using examples from marketing, business intelligence, and decision support, it shows you how to design experiments (such as A/B tests), build predictive models, and present results to audiences of all levels.

Thanks to our hosts, Geekdom by Rackspace. 

About Geekdom SF

Geekdom San Francisco’s mission is to bring great people and like minded companies together to accelerate their growth. Our shared workspace provides easy access to: industry connections, mentorship, and events. Come be part of our growing community of developers and startups and build something great here.


www.geekdom.com/sanfrancisco // @geekdomsf
name: Why You Should Use the Book Practical Data Science with R

description:
Part 1: The Zen of Visualization: Exploring the dance between seeing and creating beautiful images.

A near death experience and the teachings of a Zen Buddhist monk transformed the vision and opened the heart of this photographic artist.  When seeing with the full awareness of physical, emotional and spiritual bodies, an energetic exchange takes place between the photographer and subject. Sharing this vision, one hopes that the viewer takes in the resulting photograph in such a way that they may sense beyond thought, the intention of the photographer, as well as discover their own inner wisdom.

“One should not only photograph things for what they are but for what else they are.” – Minor White 

Lisa Winston is a graduate of Rochester Institute of Technology an award-winning photographer and creative and spiritual mentor. Lisa will share photographs and direct experience of how her vision and creative process has evolved through contemplative inquiry. Her mantra is “Live in Beauty through the wisdom and alchemy of creative expression.”


Lisa's Web site:  http://ljwdivinesight.us

Part 2: Making What is Imagined Real.

“The camera doesn't make a bit of difference. All of them can record what you are seeing. But, you have to SEE”. - Ernst Haas

"My first step when I started a new architectural project was to review the publications I respected.  For a job in Florida, Southern California or another southern state it was Décor de Provence, Côté Sud and LUX.   The goal was twofold.  First, to become aware of new photographic styles and bring something new and valuable to my clients. Second, and most importantly, I was priming my mind’s eye for the critical first step in creating great photographs, the ability to see and form a mental image that would meet my clients goals. 

“You don't take a photograph, you make it.” Ansel Adams

The next and equally important step is working with the craft of photography to make what is imagined visible.  He will discuss how to use the camera’s manual settings and the Zone System to create consistent high-quality images that are also faster and easier to produce.

Glen Graves attended the Brooks Institute in the mid 1970s and established a successful career as a freelance commercial / architectural / personal photographer.  He has traveled nationwide working for companies such as General Motors, Ford, FTD, Formica, Delta Faucets, the Lear Corporation, the New York Port Authority and innumerable Architectural firms and related companies.  He has been published in Architectural Digest,  the Robb Report and every major shelter publication.  
He is now the happy warrior teaching photography classes and shooting for a few select clients. He is also Vice President and Educational Coordinator for the Marin Photography Club = FYI - Best job yet !!

Marin Photography Club members can attend for Free - non-members are asked for a $5.00 donation to fund future Education events. 

Glen's web site: http://www.ggravesphoto.com
